10038-8{_}808{_}He told their story, or, more properly, his own, and how they had been wrecked.
10038-8{_}809{_}"And so ye're the Father Superior up there?"
10038-8{_}810{_}says the Irishman, pausing to take breath.
10038-8{_}811{_}"No.
10038-8{_}812{_}Our Superior is Father Brachet.
10038-8{_}813{_}That's a well-built cabin!"
10038-8{_}814{_}The dogs halted, though they had at least five hundred yards still to travel before they would reach the well-built cabin.
10038-8{_}815{_}"_Mush!_" shouted the Indian.
10038-8{_}816{_}The dogs cleared the ice-reef, and went spinning along so briskly over the low hummocks that the driver had to run to keep up with them.
10038-8{_}817{_}The Boy was flying after when the priest, having caught sight of his face, called out: "Here!
10038-8{_}818{_}Wait!
10038-8{_}819{_}Stop a moment!"
10038-8{_}820{_}and hurried forward.
10038-8{_}821{_}He kicked through the ice-crust, gathered up a handful of snow, and began to rub it on the Boy's right cheek.
10038-8{_}822{_}"What in the name of--" The Boy was drawing back angrily.
10038-8{_}823{_}"Keep still," ordered the priest; "your cheek is frozen"; and he applied more snow and more friction.
10038-8{_}824{_}"You ought to watch one another in such weather as this.
10038-8{_}825{_}When a man turns dead-white like that, he's touched with frost-bite."
10038-8{_}826{_}After he had restored the circulation: "There now, don't go near the fire, or it will begin to hurt."
10038-8{_}827{_}"Thank you," said the Boy, a little shame-faced.
10038-8{_}828{_}"It's all right now, I suppose?"
10038-8{_}829{_}"I think so," said the priest.
10038-8{_}830{_}"You'll lose the skin, and you may be a little sore--nothing to speak of," with which he fell back to the Colonel's side.
10038-8{_}831{_}The dogs had settled down into a jog-trot now, but were still well on in front.
10038-8{_}832{_}"Is 'mush' their food?"
10038-8{_}833{_}asked the Boy.
10038-8{_}834{_}"_Mush?_ No, fish."
10038-8{_}835{_}"Why does your Indian go on like that about mush, then?"
10038-8{_}836{_}"Oh, that's the only word the dogs know, except--a--certain expressions we try to discourage the Indians from using.
10038-8{_}837{_}In the old days the dog-drivers used to say 'mahsh.'
10038-8{_}838{_}Now you never hear anything but swearing and 'mush,' a corruption of the French-Canadian _marche_."
10038-8{_}839{_}He turned to the Colonel: "You'll get over trying to wear cheechalko boots here--nothing like mucklucks with a wisp of straw inside for this country."
10038-8{_}840{_}"I agree wid ye.
10038-8{_}841{_}I got me a pair in St. Michael's," says O'Flynn proudly, turning out his enormous feet.
10038-8{_}842{_}"Never wore anything so comf'table in me life."
10038-8{_}843{_}"You ought to have drill parkis too, like this of mine, to keep out the wind."
10038-8{_}844{_}They were going up the slope now, obliquely to the cabin, close behind the dogs, who were pulling spasmodically between their little rests.
10038-8{_}845{_}Father Wills stooped and gathered up some moss that the wind had swept almost bare of snow.
10038-8{_}846{_}"You see that?"
10038-8{_}847{_}he said to O'Flynn, while the Boy stopped, and the Colonel hurried on.
10038-8{_}848{_}"Wherever you find that growing no man need starve."
10038-8{_}849{_}The Colonel looked back before entering the cabin and saw that the Boy seemed to have forgotten not alone the Indian, but the dogs, and was walking behind with the Jesuit, face upturned, smiling, as friendly as you please.
10038-8{_}850{_}Within a different picture.
10038-8{_}851{_}Potts and Mac were having a row about something, and the Colonel struck in sharply on their growling comments upon each other's character and probable destination.
10038-8{_}852{_}"Got plenty to eat?
10038-8{_}853{_}Two hungry men coming in.
10038-8{_}854{_}One's an Indian, and you know what that means, and the other's a Catholic priest."
10038-8{_}855{_}It was this bomb that he had hurried on to get exploded and done with before the said priest should appear on the scene.
10038-8{_}856{_}"A _what_?"
10038-8{_}857{_}Mac raised his heavy eyes with fight in every wooden feature.
10038-8{_}858{_}"A Jesuit priest is what I said."
10038-8{_}859{_}"He won't eat his dinner here."
10038-8{_}860{_}"That is exactly what he will do."
10038-8{_}861{_}"Not by--" Whether it was the monstrous proposition that had unstrung Mac, he was obliged to steady himself against the table with a shaking hand.
10038-8{_}862{_}But he set those square features of his like iron, and, says he, "No Jesuit sits down to the same table with me."
10038-8{_}863{_}"That means, then, that you'll eat alone."
10038-8{_}864{_}"Not if I know it."
10038-8{_}865{_}The Colonel slid in place the heavy wooden bar that had never before been requisitioned to secure the door, and he came and stood in the middle of the cabin, where he could let out all his inches.
10038-8{_}866{_}Just clearing the swing-shelf, he pulled his great figure up to its full height, and standing there like a second Goliath, he said quite softly in that lingo of his childhood that always came back to his tongue's tip in times of excitement: "Just as shuah as yo' bohn that priest will eat his dinner to-day in my cabin, sah; and if yo' going t' make any trouble, just say so now, and we'll get it ovah, and the place cleaned up again befoh our visitors arrive."
10038-8{_}867{_}"Mind what you're about, Mac," growled Potts.
10038-8{_}868{_}"You know he could lick the stuffin' out o' you."
10038-8{_}869{_}The ex-schoolmaster produced some sort of indignant sound in his throat and turned, as if he meant to go out.
10038-8{_}870{_}The Colonel came a little nearer.
10038-8{_}871{_}Mac flung up his head and squared for battle.
10038-8{_}872{_}Potts, in a cold sweat, dropped a lot of tinware with a rattle, while the Colonel said, "No, no.
10038-8{_}873{_}We'll settle this after the people go, Mac."
10038-8{_}874{_}Then in a whisper: "Look here: I've been trying to shield you for ten days.
10038-8{_}875{_}Don't give yourself away now--before the first white neighbour that comes to see us.
10038-8{_}876{_}You call yourself a Christian.
10038-8{_}877{_}Just see if you can't behave like one, for an hour or two, to a fellow-creature that's cold and hungry.
10038-8{_}878{_}Come, _you're_ the man we've always counted on!
10038-8{_}879{_}Do the honours, and take it out of me after our guests are gone."
10038-8{_}880{_}Mac seemed in a haze.
10038-8{_}881{_}He sat down heavily on some beanbags in the corner; and when the newcomers were brought in and introduced, he "did the honours" by glowering at them with red eyes, never breaking his surly silence.
10038-8{_}882{_}"Well!"
10038-8{_}883{_}says Father Wills, looking about, "I must say you're very comfortable here.
10038-8{_}884{_}If more people made homes like this, there'd be fewer failures."
10038-8{_}885{_}They gave him the best place by the fire, and Potts dished up dinner.
10038-8{_}886{_}There were only two stools made yet.
10038-8{_}887{_}The Boy rolled his section of sawed spruce over near the priest, and prepared to dine at his side.
10038-8{_}888{_}"No, no," said Father Wills firmly.
10038-8{_}889{_}"You shall sit as far away from this splendid blaze as you can get, or you will have trouble with that cheek."
10038-8{_}890{_}So the Boy had to yield his place to O'Flynn, and join Mac over on the bean-bags.
10038-8{_}891{_}"Why didn't you get a parki when you were at St.
10038-8{_}892{_}Michael's?"
10038-8{_}893{_}said the priest as this change was being effected.
10038-8{_}894{_}"We had just as much--more than we could carry.
10038-8{_}895{_}Besides, I thought we could buy furs up river; anyway, I'm warm enough."
10038-8{_}896{_}"No you are not," returned the priest smiling.
10038-8{_}897{_}"You must get a parki with a hood."
10038-8{_}898{_}"I've got an Arctic cap; it rolls down over my ears and goes all round my neck--just leaves a little place in front for my eyes."
10038-8{_}899{_}"Yes; wear that if you go on the trail; but the good of the parki hood is, that it is trimmed all round with long wolf-hair.
10038-8{_}900{_}You see"--he picked his parki up off the floor and showed it to the company--"those long hairs standing out all round the face break the force of the wind.
10038-8{_}901{_}It is wonderful how the Esquimaux hood lessens the chance of frost-bite."
10038-8{_}902{_}While the only object in the room that he didn't seem to see was Mac, he was most taken up with the fireplace.
10038-8{_}903{_}The Colonel laid great stress on the enormous services of the delightful, accomplished master-mason over there on the beanbags, who sat looking more than ever like a monkey-wrench incarnate.
10038-8{_}904{_}But whether that Jesuit was as wily as the Calvinist thought, he had quite wit enough to overlook the great chimney-builder's wrathful silence.
10038-8{_}905{_}He was not the least "professional," talked about the country and how to live here, saying incidentally that he had spent twelve years at the mission of the Holy Cross.
10038-8{_}906{_}The Yukon wasn't a bad place to live in, he told them, if men only took the trouble to learn how to live here.
10038-8{_}907{_}While teaching the Indians, there was a great deal to learn from them as well.
10038-8{_}908{_}"You must all come and see our schools," he wound up.
10038-8{_}909{_}"We'd like to awfully," said the Boy, and all but Mac echoed him.
10038-8{_}910{_}"We were so afraid," he went on, "that we mightn't see anybody all winter long."
10038-8{_}911{_}"Oh, you'll have more visitors than you want."
10038-8{_}912{_}"_Shall_ we, though?"
10038-8{_}913{_}Then, with a modified rapture: "Indians, I suppose, and--and missionaries."
10038-8{_}914{_}"Traders, too, and miners, and this year cheechalkos as well.
10038-8{_}915{_}You are directly on the great highway of winter travel.
10038-8{_}916{_}Now that there's a good hard crust on the snow you will have dog-trains passing every week, and sometimes two or three."
10038-8{_}917{_}It was good news!
10038-8{_}918{_}"We've already had one visitor before you," said the Boy, looking wonderfully pleased at the prospect the priest had opened out.
10038-8{_}919{_}"You must know Nicholas of Pymeut, don't you?"
10038-8{_}920{_}"Oh yes; we all know Nicholas"; and the priest smiled.
10038-8{_}921{_}"We _like_ him," returned the Boy as if some slighting criticism had been passed upon his friend.
10038-8{_}922{_}"Of course you do; so do we all"; and still that look of quiet amusement on the worn face and a keener twinkle glinting in the eyes.
10038-8{_}923{_}"We're afraid he's sick," the Boy began.
10038-8{_}924{_}Before the priest could answer, "He was educated at Howly Cross, he _says_," contributed O'Flynn.
10038-8{_}925{_}"Oh, he's been to Holy Cross, among other places."
10038-8{_}926{_}"What do you mean?"
10038-8{_}927{_}"Well, Nicholas is a most impartial person.
10038-8{_}928{_}He was born at Pymeut, but his father, who is the richest and most intelligent man in his tribe, took Nicholas to Ikogimeut when the boy was only six.
10038-8{_}929{_}He was brought up in the Russian mission there, as the father had been before him, and was a Greek--in religion--till he was fourteen.
10038-8{_}930{_}There was a famine that year down yonder, so Nicholas turned Catholic and came up to us.
10038-8{_}931{_}He was at Holy Cross some years, when business called him to Anvik, where he turned Episcopalian.
10038-8{_}932{_}At Eagle City, I believe, he is regarded as a pattern Presbyterian.
10038-8{_}933{_}There are those that say, since he has been a pilot, Nicholas makes six changes a trip in his religious convictions."
10038-8{_}934{_}Father Wills saw that the Colonel, to whom he most frequently addressed himself, took his pleasantry gravely.
10038-8{_}935{_}"Nicholas is not a bad fellow," he added.
10038-8{_}936{_}"He told me you had been kind to him."
10038-8{_}937{_}"If you believe that about his insincerity," said the Colonel, "are you not afraid the others you spend your life teaching may turn out as little credit to you--to Christianity?"
10038-8{_}938{_}The priest glanced at the listening Indian.
10038-8{_}939{_}"No," said he gravely; "I do not think _all_ the natives are like Nicholas.
10038-8{_}940{_}Andrew here is a true son of the Church.
10038-8{_}941{_}But even if it were otherwise, _we_, you know"--the Jesuit rose from the table with that calm smile of his--"we simply do the work without question.
10038-8{_}942{_}The issue is not in our hands."
10038-8{_}943{_}He made the sign of the cross and set back his stool.
10038-8{_}944{_}"Come, Andrew," he said; "we must push on."
10038-8{_}945{_}The Indian repeated the priest's action, and went out to see to the dogs.
10038-8{_}946{_}"Oh, are you going right away?"
10038-8{_}947{_}said the Colonel politely, and O'Flynn volubly protested.
10038-8{_}948{_}"We thought," said the Boy, "you'd sit awhile and smoke and--at least, of course, I don't mean smoke exactly--but--"  The Father smiled and shook his head.
10038-8{_}949{_}"Another time I would stay gladly."
10038-8{_}950{_}"Where are you going now?"
10038-8{_}951{_}"Andrew and I are on our way to the _Oklahoma_, the steamship frozen in the ice below here."
10038-8{_}952{_}"How far?"
10038-8{_}953{_}asked the Boy.
10038-8{_}954{_}"About seven miles below the Russian mission, and a mile or so up the Kuskoquim Slough."
10038-8{_}955{_}"Wrecked there?"
10038-8{_}956{_}"Oh no.
10038-8{_}957{_}Gone into winter quarters."
10038-8{_}958{_}"In a slew?"
10038-8{_}959{_}for it was so Father Wills pronounced s-l-o-u-g-h.  "Oh, that's what they call a blind river up in this country.
10038-8{_}960{_}They come into the big streams every here and there, and cheechalkos are always mistaking them for the main channel.
10038-8{_}961{_}Sometimes they're wider and deeper for a mile or so than the river proper, but before you know it they land you in a marsh.
10038-8{_}962{_}This place I'm going to, a little way up the Kuskoquim, out of danger when the ice breaks up, has been chosen for a new station by the N. A. T. and T. Company--rival, you know, to the old-established Alaska Commercial, that inherited the Russian fur monopoly and controlled the seal and salmon trade so long.
10038-8{_}963{_}Well, the younger company runs the old one hard, and they've sent this steamer into winter quarters loaded with provisions, ready to start for Dawson the instant the ice goes out."
10038-8{_}964{_}"Why, then, it's the very boat that'll be takin' us to the Klondyke."
10038-8{_}965{_}"You just goin' down to have a look at her?"
10038-8{_}966{_}asked Potts enviously.

10038-8{_}1192{_}CHAPTER III  TWO NEW SPISSIMENS  Medwjedew (zu Luka).
10038-8{_}1193{_}Tag' mal--wer bist du?
10038-8{_}1194{_}Ich kenne dich nicht.
10038-8{_}1195{_}Luka.

10038-8{_}1197{_}Medwjedew.
10038-8{_}1198{_}In meinem Revier mu√ü ich jeden kennen und dich kenn'ich nicht....  Luka.
10038-8{_}1199{_}Das kommt wohl daher Onkelchen, da√ü dein Revier nicht die ganze Erde umfasst ... 's ist da noch ein Endchen drau√üen geblieben....   One of the curious results of what is called wild life, is a blessed release from many of the timidities that assail the easy liver in the centres of civilisation.
10038-8{_}1200{_}Potts was the only one in the white camp who had doubts about the wisdom of having to do with the natives.
10038-8{_}1201{_}However, the agreeable necessity of going to Pymeut to invite Nicholas to the Blow-out was not forced upon the Boy.
10038-8{_}1202{_}They were still hard at it, four days after the Jesuit had gone his way, surrounding the Big Cabin with a false wall, that final and effectual barrier against Boreas--finishing touch warranted to convert a cabin, so cold that it drove its inmates to drink, into a dwelling where practical people, without cracking a dreary joke, might fitly celebrate a House-Warming.
10038-8{_}1203{_}In spite of the shortness of the days, Father Wills's suggestion was being carried out with a gratifying success.
10038-8{_}1204{_}Already manifest were the advantages of the stockade, running at a foot's distance round the cabin to the height of the eaves, made of spruce saplings not even lopped of their short bushy branches, but planted close together, after burning the ground cleared of snow.
10038-8{_}1205{_}A second visitation of mild weather, and a further two days' thaw, made the Colonel determine to fill in the space between the spruce stockade and the cabin with "burnt-out" soil closely packed down and well tramped in.
10038-8{_}1206{_}It was generally conceded, as the winter wore on, that to this contrivance of the "earthwork" belonged a good half of the credit of the Big Cabin, and its renown as being the warmest spot on the lower river that terrible memorable year of the Klondyke Rush.
10038-8{_}1207{_}The evergreen wall with the big stone chimney shouldering itself up to look out upon the frozen highway, became a conspicuous feature in the landscape, welcome as the weeks went on to many an eye wearied with long looking for shelter, and blinded by the snow-whitened waste.
10038-8{_}1208{_}An exception to what became a rule was, of all men, Nicholas.
10038-8{_}1209{_}When the stockade was half done, the Prince and an equerry appeared on the horizon, with the second team the camp had seen, the driver much concerned to steer clear of the softened snow and keep to that part of the river ice windswept and firm, if roughest of all.
10038-8{_}1210{_}Nicholas regarded the stockade with a cold and beady eye.
10038-8{_}1211{_}No, he hadn't time to look at it.
10038-8{_}1212{_}He had promised to "mush."
10038-8{_}1213{_}He wasn't even hungry.
10038-8{_}1214{_}It did little credit to his heart, but he seemed more in haste to leave his new friends than the least friendly of them would have expected.
10038-8{_}1215{_}"Oh, wait a sec.," urged the deeply disappointed Boy.
10038-8{_}1216{_}"I wanted awf'ly to see how your sled is made.
10038-8{_}1217{_}It's better 'n Father Wills'."
10038-8{_}1218{_}"Humph!"
10038-8{_}1219{_}grunted Nicholas scornfully; "him no got Innuit sled."
10038-8{_}1220{_}"Mac and I are goin' to try soon's the stockade's done--"  "Goo'-bye," interrupted Nicholas.
10038-8{_}1221{_}But the Boy paid no attention to the word of farewell.
10038-8{_}1222{_}He knelt down in the snow and examined the sled carefully.
10038-8{_}1223{_}"Spruce runners," he called out to Mac, "and--jee!
10038-8{_}1224{_}they're shod with ivory!
10038-8{_}1225{_}_Jee!_ fastened with sinew and wooden pegs.
10038-8{_}1226{_}Hey?"

10038-8{_}1228{_}"Nail?"
10038-8{_}1229{_}says Nicholas.
10038-8{_}1230{_}"Huh, no _nail!_" as contemptuously as though the Boy had said "bread-crumbs."
10038-8{_}1231{_}"Well, she's a daisy!
10038-8{_}1232{_}When you comin' back?"
10038-8{_}1233{_}"Comin' pretty quick; goin' pretty quick.
10038-8{_}1234{_}Goo'-bye!

10038-8{_}1319{_}*       *       *       *       *  This was all very fine ... but Father Wills!
10038-8{_}1320{_}The last thing at night and the first thing in the morning the Boy looked the problem in the face, and devised now this, now that, adroit and disarming fashion of breaking the news to Mac.

10038-8{_}1434{_}The great feast-day had certainly not dawned propitiously.

10038-8{_}1436{_}*       *       *       *       *  On the low left bank of the Yukon a little camp.
10038-8{_}1437{_}On one side, a big rock hooded with snow.
10038-8{_}1438{_}At right angles, drawn up one on top of the other, two sleds covered with reindeer-skins held down by stones.

10038-8{_}1440{_}Burning before it on a hearth of greenwood, a little fire struggling with a veering wind.
10038-8{_}1441{_}Mac had seen from far off the faint blue banners of smoke blowing now right, now left, then tossed aloft in the pallid sunshine.
10038-8{_}1442{_}He looked about sharply for the Boy, as he had been doing this two hours.

10038-8{_}1448{_}The priest glanced up and nodded pleasantly.

10038-8{_}1475{_}The child stared at him fixedly, but suddenly, for no reason on earth, it smiled again.

10038-8{_}1496{_}"In a little village up on the Kuskoquim.

10038-8{_}1499{_}"His family came up there from the coast in a bidarra only last summer--all dead now.

10038-8{_}1513{_}The priest nodded, taking Mac's unheard of civility as a matter of course.

10038-8{_}1559{_}In ten minutes they were on the trail, Andrew leading, with Father Wills' dogs, Kaviak lying in the sled muffled to the eyes, still looking round out of the corners--no, strangely enough, the Kaviak eye had no corners, but fixedly he stared sideways at Mac.
10038-8{_}1560{_}"Farva," seeming not to take the smallest notice, trudged along on one side of him, the priest on the other, and behind came Nicholas and the other Indians with the second sled.
10038-8{_}1561{_}It was too windy to talk much even had they been inclined.

10038-8{_}1700{_}CHAPTER IV  THE BLOW-OUT  "How good it is to invite men to the pleasant feast."
10038-8{_}1701{_}Comfortable as rock fireplace and stockade made the cabin now, the Colonel had been feeling all that morning that the official House-Warming was fore-doomed to failure.
10038-8{_}1702{_}Nevertheless, as he was cook that week, he could not bring himself to treat altogether lightly his office of Master of the Feast.
10038-8{_}1703{_}There would probably be no guests.
10038-8{_}1704{_}Even their own little company would likely be incomplete, but t here was to be a spread that afternoon, "anyways."
10038-8{_}1705{_}Even had the Colonel needed any keeping up to the mark, the office would have been cheerfully undertaken by O'Flynn or by Potts, for whom interest in the gustatory aspect of the occasion was wholly undimmed by the threatened absence of Mac and the "little divvle."
10038-8{_}1706{_}"There'll be the more for us," said Potts enthusiastically.
10038-8{_}1707{_}O'Flynn's argument seemed to halt upon a reservation.
10038-8{_}1708{_}He looked over the various contributions to the feast, set out on a board in front of the water-bucket, and, "It's mate I'm wishin' fur," says he.
10038-8{_}1709{_}"We've got fish."
10038-8{_}1710{_}"That's only mate on Fridays.
10038-8{_}1711{_}We've had fish fur five days stiddy, an' befure that, bacon three times a day wid sivin days to the week, an' not enough bacon ayther, begob, whin all's said and done!
10038-8{_}1712{_}Not enough to be fillin', and plenty to give us the scurrvy.
10038-8{_}1713{_}May the divil dance on shorrt rations!"
10038-8{_}1714{_}"No scurvy in this camp for a while yet," said the Colonel, throwing some heavy objects into a pan and washing them vigorously round and round.
10038-8{_}1715{_}"Pitaties!"
10038-8{_}1716{_}O'Flynn's eyes dwelt lovingly on the rare food.
10038-8{_}1717{_}"Ye've hoarded 'em too long, man, they've sprouted."
10038-8{_}1718{_}"That won't prevent you hoggin' more'n your share, I'll bet," said Potts pleasantly.
10038-8{_}1719{_}"I don't somehow like wasting the sprouts," observed the Colonel anxiously.
10038-8{_}1720{_}"It's such a wonderful sight--something growing."
10038-8{_}1721{_}He had cut one pallid slip, and held it tenderly between knife and thumb.
10038-8{_}1722{_}"Waste 'em with scurvy staring us in the face?
10038-8{_}1723{_}Should think not.
10038-8{_}1724{_}Mix 'em with cold potaters in a salad."
10038-8{_}1725{_}"No.
10038-8{_}1726{_}Make slumgullion," commanded O'Flynn.
10038-8{_}1727{_}"What's that?"
10038-8{_}1728{_}quoth the Colonel.
10038-8{_}1729{_}"Be the Siven!
10038-8{_}1730{_}I only wonder I didn't think of it befure.
10038-8{_}1731{_}Arre ye listening, Kentucky?
10038-8{_}1732{_}Ye take lots o' wathur, an' if ye want it rich, ye take the wathur ye've boiled pitaties or cabbage in--a vegetable stock, ye mind--and ye add a little flour, salt, and pepper, an' a tomater if ye're in New York or 'Frisco, and ye boil all that together with a few fish-bones or bacon-rin's to make it rale tasty."
10038-8{_}1733{_}"Yes--well?"
10038-8{_}1734{_}"Well, an' that's slumgullion."
10038-8{_}1735{_}"Don't sound heady enough for a 'Blow-Out,'" said the Colonel.
10038-8{_}1736{_}"We'll sober up on slumgullion to-morrow."
10038-8{_}1737{_}"Anyhow, it's mate I'm wishin' fur," sighed O'Flynn, subsiding among the tin-ware.
10038-8{_}1738{_}"What's the good o' the little divvle and his thramps, if he can't bring home a burrud, or so much as the scut iv a rabbit furr the soup?"

10038-8{_}1740{_}"An' punch, glory be!"

10038-8{_}1742{_}"I've been thinkin' a good deal about the punch."

10038-8{_}1744{_}"There's very little whiskey left, and I propose to brew a mild bowl--"  "To hell with your mild bowls!"
10038-8{_}1745{_}"A good enough punch, sah, but one that--that--a--well, that the whole kit and boodle of us can drink.
10038-8{_}1746{_}Indians and everybody, you know ... Nicholas and Andrew may turn up.
10038-8{_}1747{_}I want you two fellas to suppoht me about this.

10038-8{_}1749{_}Whereupon, having cut the ground from under their feet, he turned decisively, and stirred the mush-pot with a magnificent air and a newly-whittled birch stick.
10038-8{_}1750{_}To give the Big Cabin an aspect of solid luxury, they had spread the Boy's old buffalo "robe" on the floor, and as the morning wore on Potts and O'Flynn made one or two expeditions to the Little Cabin, bringing back selections out of Mac's hoard "to decorate the banquet-hall," as they said.
10038-8{_}1751{_}On the last trip Potts refused to accompany his pardner--no, it was no good.
10038-8{_}1752{_}Mac evidently wouldn't be back to see, and the laugh would be on them "takin' so much trouble for nothin'."
10038-8{_}1753{_}And O'Flynn wasn't to be long either, for dinner had been absurdly postponed already.
10038-8{_}1754{_}When the door opened the next time, it was to admit Mac, Nicholas with Kaviak in his arms, O'Flynn gesticulating like a windmill, and, last of all, the Boy.
10038-8{_}1755{_}Kaviak was formally introduced, but instead of responding to his hosts' attentions, the only thing he seemed to care about, or even see, was something that in the hurly-burly everybody else overlooked--the decorations.
10038-8{_}1756{_}Mac's stuffed birds and things made a remarkably good show, but the colossal success was reserved for the minute shrunken skin of the baby white hare set down in front of the great fire for a hearthrug.
10038-8{_}1757{_}If the others failed to appreciate that joke, not so Kaviak.
10038-8{_}1758{_}He gave a gurgling cry, struggled down out of Nicholas's arms, and folded the white hare to his breast.
10038-8{_}1759{_}"Where are the other Indians?"
10038-8{_}1760{_}said Mac.
10038-8{_}1761{_}"Looking after the dogs," said Father Wills; and as the door opened, "Oh yes, give us that," he said to Andrew.
10038-8{_}1762{_}"I thought"--he turned to the Colonel--"maybe you'd like to try some Yukon reindeer."
10038-8{_}1763{_}"Hooray!"
10038-8{_}1764{_}"Mate?
10038-8{_}1765{_}Arre ye sayin' mate, or is an angel singin'?"
10038-8{_}1766{_}"Now I _know_ that man's a Christian," soliloquised Potts.
10038-8{_}1767{_}"Look here: it'll take a little time to cook," said Mac, "and it's worth waitin' for.

10038-8{_}1769{_}"Y-yes," said the Colonel, looking as if he had enough to think about already.
10038-8{_}1770{_}"Yes, we always wash them first of all," said Father Wills, noticing how Mac held the little heathen off at arm's length.
10038-8{_}1771{_}"Nicholas used to help with that at Holy Cross."
10038-8{_}1772{_}He gave the new order with the old authoritative gesture.

10038-8{_}1775{_}"Go and get it."
10038-8{_}1776{_}Under Nicholas's hands Kaviak was forced to relinquish not only the baby hare, but his own elf locks.

10038-8{_}1778{_}"Be the Siven!
10038-8{_}1779{_}he's got as manny bones as a skeleton!"
10038-8{_}1780{_}"Poor little codger!"
10038-8{_}1781{_}The Colonel stood an instant, skillet in hand staring.
10038-8{_}1782{_}"What's that he's got round his neck?"
10038-8{_}1783{_}said the Boy, moving nearer.
10038-8{_}1784{_}Kaviak, seeing the keen look menacing his treasure, lifted a shrunken yellow hand and clasped tight the dirty shapeless object suspended from a raw-hide necklace.
10038-8{_}1785{_}Nicholas seemed to hesitate to divest him of this sole remaining possession.
10038-8{_}1786{_}"You must get him to give it up," said Father Wills, "and burn it."
10038-8{_}1787{_}Kaviak flatly declined to fall in with as much as he understood of this arrangement.

10038-8{_}1789{_}the Boy pursued.

10038-8{_}1793{_}Mac insinuated himself brusquely between the victim and his persecutors.

10038-8{_}1797{_}Mac demanded of Nicholas.
10038-8{_}1798{_}The Pymeut pilot nodded.
10038-8{_}1799{_}"Tell him, if he'll lend the thing to me to wash, he shall have it back."

10038-8{_}1802{_}"How shall I clean this thing thoroughly?"

10038-8{_}1806{_}"He shall have it to-morrow," said Mac.
10038-8{_}1807{_}With his back to Kaviak, the Boy, O'Flynn, and Potts crowding round him, Mac ripped open the little bird-skin pouch, and took out three objects--an ivory mannikin, a crow's feather, and a thing that Father Wills said was a seal-blood plug.
10038-8{_}1808{_}"What's it for?"
10038-8{_}1809{_}"Same as the rest.
10038-8{_}1810{_}It's an amulet; only as it's used to stop the flow of blood from the wound of a captive seal, it is supposed to be the best of all charms for anyone who spits blood."
10038-8{_}1811{_}"I'll clean 'em all after the Blow-Out," said Mac, and he went out, buried the charms in the snow, and stuck up a spruce twig to mark the spot.
10038-8{_}1812{_}Meanwhile, to poor Kaviak it was being plainly demonstrated what an awful fate descended on a person so unlucky as to part with his amulet.
10038-8{_}1813{_}He stood straight up in the bucket like a champagne-bottle in a cooler, and he could not have resented his predicament more if he had been set in crushed ice instead of warm water.

10038-8{_}1815{_}It was quite clear Nicholas was trying to drown him.
10038-8{_}1816{_}He took the treatment so to heart, that he kept on howling dismally for some time after he was taken out, and dried, and linimented and dosed by Mac, whose treachery about the amulet he seemed to forgive, since "Farva" had had the air of rescuing him from the horrors he had endured in that water-bucket, where, for all Kaviak knew, he might have stayed till he succumbed to death.
10038-8{_}1817{_}The Boy contributed a shirt of his own, and helped Mac to put it on the incredibly thin little figure.
10038-8{_}1818{_}The shirt came down to Kaviak's heels, and had to have the sleeves rolled up every two minutes.
10038-8{_}1819{_}But by the time the reindeer-steak was nearly done Kaviak was done, too, and O'Flynn had said, "That Spissimen does ye credit, Mac."
10038-8{_}1820{_}Said Spissimen was now staring hungrily out of the Colonel's bunk, holding towards Mac an appealing hand, with half a yard of shirt-sleeve falling over it.
10038-8{_}1821{_}Mac pretended not to see, and drew up to the table the one remaining available thing to sit on, his back to his patient.
10038-8{_}1822{_}When the dogs had been fed, and the other Indians had come in, and squatted on the buffalo-skin with Nicholas, the first course was sent round in tin cups, a nondescript, but warming, "camp soup."
10038-8{_}1823{_}"Sorry we've got so few dishes, gentlemen," the Colonel had said.
10038-8{_}1824{_}"We'll have to ask some of you to wait till others have finished."
10038-8{_}1825{_}"Farva," remarked Kaviak, leaning out of the bunk and sniffing the savoury steam.

10038-8{_}1827{_}But not even so damning a suspicion as that could cool the collector's kindness for his new Spissimen.
10038-8{_}1828{_}"You come here," he said.
10038-8{_}1829{_}Kaviak didn't understand.
10038-8{_}1830{_}The Boy got up, limped over to the bunk, lifted the child out, and brought him to Mac's side.

10038-8{_}1832{_}The Spissimen imbibed greedily, audibly, and beamed.
10038-8{_}1833{_}Mac, with unimpaired gravity, took no notice of the huge satisfaction this particular remedy was giving his patient, except to say solemnly, "Don't bubble in it."
10038-8{_}1834{_}The next course was fish a la Pymeut.

10038-8{_}1848{_}"Well?"

10038-8{_}1865{_}Potts had to bestir himself and wash dishes before he could indulge in his "line."

10038-8{_}1867{_}"Colonel's a daisy cook, ain't he?"

10038-8{_}1869{_}The Jesuit assented cordially.

10038-8{_}1878{_}"Beyond that, we can't tell you why he's a Colonel unless it's because he ain't a Judge;" and the boss of the camp laughed with the rest, for the Denver man had scored.
10038-8{_}1879{_}By the time they got to the California apricots and boiled rice everybody was feeling pretty comfortable.
10038-8{_}1880{_}When, at last, the table was cleared, except for the granite-ware basin full of punch, and when all available cups were mustered and tobacco-pouches came out, a remarkably genial spirit pervaded the company--with three exceptions.
10038-8{_}1881{_}Potts and O'Flynn waited anxiously to sample the punch before giving way to complete satisfaction, and Kaviak was impervious to considerations either of punch or conviviality, being wrapped in slumber on a corner of the buffalo-skin, between Mac's stool and the natives, who also occupied places on the floor.
10038-8{_}1882{_}Upon O'Flynn's first draught he turned to his next neighbour:  "Potts, me bhoy, 'tain't s' bad."
10038-8{_}1883{_}"I'll bet five dollars it won't make yer any happier."
10038-8{_}1884{_}"Begob, I'm happy enough!
10038-8{_}1885{_}Gentlemen, wud ye like I should sing ye a song?"
10038-8{_}1886{_}"Yes."
10038-8{_}1887{_}"Yes," and the Colonel thumped the table for order, infinitely relieved that the dinner was done, and the punch not likely to turn into a _casus belli_.
10038-8{_}1888{_}O'Flynn began a ditty about the Widdy Malone that woke up Kaviak and made him rub his round eyes with astonishment.
10038-8{_}1889{_}He sat up, and hung on to the back of Mac's coat to make sure he had some anchorage in the strange new waters he had so suddenly been called on to navigate.
10038-8{_}1890{_}The song ended, the Colonel, as toast-master, proposed the health of--he was going to say Father Wills, but felt it discreeter to name no names.
10038-8{_}1891{_}Standing up in the middle of the cabin, where he didn't have to stoop, he lifted his cup till it knocked against the swing-shelf, and called out, "Here's to Our Visitors, Neighbours, and Friends!"
10038-8{_}1892{_}Whereupon he made a stately circular bow, which ended by his offering Kaviak his hand, in the manner of one who executes a figure in an old-fashioned dance.
10038-8{_}1893{_}The smallest of "Our Visitors," still keeping hold of Mac, presented the Colonel with the disengaged half-yard of flannel undershirt on the other side, and the speech went on, very flowery, very hospitable, very Kentuckian.
10038-8{_}1894{_}When the Colonel sat down there was much applause, and O'Flynn, who had lent his cup to Nicholas, and didn't feel he could wait till it came back, began to drink punch out of the dipper between shouts of:  "Hooray!
10038-8{_}1895{_}Brayvo!
10038-8{_}1896{_}Here's to the Kurrnul!
10038-8{_}1897{_}God bless him!
10038-8{_}1898{_}That's rale oratry, Kurrnul!
10038-8{_}1899{_}Here's to Kentucky--and ould Ireland."
10038-8{_}1900{_}Father Wills stood up, smiling, to reply.
10038-8{_}1901{_}_"Friends"_ (the Boy thought the keen eyes rested a fraction of a moment longer on Mac than on the rest),--_"I think in some ways this is the pleasantest House-Warming I ever went to.
10038-8{_}1902{_}I won't take up time thanking the Colonel for the friendly sentiments he's expressed, though I return them heartily.
10038-8{_}1903{_}I must use these moments you are good enough to give me in telling you something of what I feel is implied in the founding of this camp of yours.
10038-8{_}1904{_}"Gentlemen, the few white dwellers in the Yukon country have not looked forward"_ (his eyes twinkled almost wickedly) _"with that pleasure you might expect in exiles, to the influx of people brought up here by the great Gold Discovery.
10038-8{_}1905{_}We knew what that sort of craze leads to.
10038-8{_}1906{_}We knew that in a barren land like this, more and more denuded of wild game every year, more and more the prey of epidemic disease--we knew that into this sorely tried and hungry world would come a horde of men, all of them ignorant of the conditions up here, most of them ill-provided with proper food and clothing, many of them (I can say it without offence in this company)--many of them men whom the older, richer communities were glad to get rid of.
10038-8{_}1907{_}Gentlemen, I have ventured to take you into our confidence so far, because I want to take you still farther--to tell you a little of the intense satisfaction with which we recognise that good fortune has sent us in you just the sort of neighbours we had not dared to hope for.
10038-8{_}1908{_}It means more to us than you realise.
10038-8{_}1909{_}When I heard a few weeks ago that, in addition to the boat-loads that had already got some distance up the river beyond Holy Cross--"_  "Going to Dawson?"
10038-8{_}1910{_}"Oh, yes, Klondyke mad--"  "They'll be there before us, boys!"
10038-8{_}1911{_}"Anyways, they'll get to Minook."
10038-8{_}1912{_}The Jesuit shook his head.
10038-8{_}1913{_}"It isn't so certain.
10038-8{_}1914{_}They probably made only a couple of hundred miles or so before the Yukon went to sleep."
10038-8{_}1915{_}"Then if grub gives out they'll be comin' back here?"
10038-8{_}1916{_}suggested Potts.
10038-8{_}1917{_}_"Small doubt of it,"_ agreed the priest.
10038-8{_}1918{_}_"And when I heard there were parties of the same sort stranded at intervals all along the Lower River--"_  "You sure?"
10038-8{_}1919{_}He nodded.
10038-8{_}1920{_}_"And when Father Orloff of the Russian mission told us that he was already having trouble with the two big rival parties frozen in the ice below Ikogimeut--"_  "Gosh!
10038-8{_}1921{_}Wonder if any of 'em were on our ship?"
10038-8{_}1922{_}_"Well, gentlemen, I do not disguise from you that, when I heard of the large amount of whiskey, the small amount of food, and the low type of manners brought in by these gold-seekers, I felt my fears justified.
10038-8{_}1923{_}Such men don't work, don't contribute anything to the decent social life of the community, don't build cabins like this.
10038-8{_}1924{_}When I came down on the ice the first time after you'd camped, and I looked up and saw your solid stone chimney"_ (he glanced at Mac), _"I didn't know what a House-Warming it would make; but already, from far off across the ice and snow, that chimney warmed my heart.
10038-8{_}1925{_}Gentlemen, the fame of it has gone up the river and down the river.
10038-8{_}1926{_}Father Orloff is coming to see it next week, and so are the white traders from Anvik and Andreiefsky, for they've heard there's nothing like it in the Yukon.
10038-8{_}1927{_}Of course, I know that you gentlemen have not come to settle permanently.
10038-8{_}1928{_}I know that when the Great White Silence, as they call the long winter up here, is broken by the thunder of the ice rushing down to the sea, you, like the rest, will exchange the snow-fields for the gold-fields, and pass out of our ken.
10038-8{_}1929{_}Now, I'm not usually prone to try my hand at prophecy; but I am tempted to say, even on our short acquaintance, that I am tolerably sure that, while we shall be willing enough to spare most of the new-comers to the Klondyke, we shall grudge to the gold-fields the men who built this camp and warmed this cabin.
10038-8{_}1930{_}"_ (His eye rested reflectively on Mac.)
10038-8{_}1931{_}_"I don't wish to sit down leaving an impression of speaking with entire lack of sympathy of the impulse that brings men up here for gold.
10038-8{_}1932{_}I believe that, even with the sort in the two camps below Ikogimeut--drinking, quarrelling, and making trouble with the natives at the Russian mission--I believe that even with them, the gold they came up here for is a symbol--a fetich, some of us may think.
10038-8{_}1933{_}When such men have it in their hands, they feel dimly that they are laying tangible hold at last on some elusive vision of happiness that has hitherto escaped them.
10038-8{_}1934{_}Behind each man braving the Arctic winter up here, is some hope, not all ignoble; some devotion, not all unsanctified.
10038-8{_}1935{_}Behind most of these men I seem to see a wife or child, a parent, or some dear dream that gives that man his share in the Eternal Hope.
10038-8{_}1936{_}Friends, we call that thing we look for by different names; but we are all seekers after treasure, all here have turned our backs on home and comfort, hunting for the Great Reward--each man a new Columbus looking for the New World.
10038-8{_}1937{_}Some of us looking north, some south, some"_--he hesitated the briefest moment, and then with a faint smile, half sad, half triumphant, made a little motion of his head--_"some of us ... looking upwards.
10038-8{_}1938{_}"_  But quickly, as though conscious that, if he had raised the moral tone of the company, he had not raised its spirits, he hurried on:  _"Before I sit down, gentlemen, just one word more.
10038-8{_}1939{_}I must congratulate you on having found out so soon, not only the wisdom, but the pleasure of looking at this Arctic world with intelligent eyes, and learning some of her wonderful lessons.
10038-8{_}1940{_}It is so that, now the hardest work is finished, you will keep up your spirits and avoid the disease that attacks all new-comers who simply eat, sleep, and wait for the ice to go out.
10038-8{_}1941{_}When I hear cheechalkos complaining of boredom up here in this world of daily miracles, I think of the native boy in the history-class, who, called on to describe the progress of civilisation, said: 'In those days men had as many wives as they liked, and that was called polygamy.
10038-8{_}1942{_}Now they have only one wife, and that's called monotony.
10038-8{_}1943{_}'"_  While O'Flynn howled with delight, the priest wound up:  _"Gentlemen, if we find monotony up here, it's not the country's fault, but a defect in our own civilisation.
10038-8{_}1944{_}"_ Wherewith he sat down amid cheers.
10038-8{_}1945{_}"Now, Colonel, is Mac goin' to recite some Border ballads?"
10038-8{_}1946{_}inquired the Boy, "or will he make a speech, or do a Highland fling?"
10038-8{_}1947{_}The Colonel called formally upon Mr. MacCann.
10038-8{_}1948{_}Mac was no sooner on his legs than Kaviak, determined not to lose his grasp of the situation, climbed upon the three-legged stool just vacated, and resumed his former relations with the friendly coat-tail.
10038-8{_}1949{_}Everybody laughed but Mac, who pretended not to know what was going on behind his back.
10038-8{_}1950{_}"Gentlemen," he began harshly, with the air of one about to launch a heavy indictment, "there's one element largely represented here by numbers and by interests"--he turned round suddenly toward the natives, and almost swung Kaviak off into space--"one element not explicitly referred to in the speeches, either of welcome or of thanks.
10038-8{_}1951{_}But, gentlemen, I submit that these hitherto unrecognised Natives are our real hosts, and a word about them won't be out of place.
10038-8{_}1952{_}I've been told to-day that, whether in Alaska, Greenland, or British America, they call themselves _Innuits,_ which means human beings.
10038-8{_}1953{_}They believed, no doubt, that they were the only ones in the world.
10038-8{_}1954{_}I've been thinking a great deal about these Esquimaux of late--"  "Hear, hear!"
10038-8{_}1955{_}"About their origin and their destiny."
10038-8{_}1956{_}(Mac was beginning to enjoy himself.
10038-8{_}1957{_}The Boy was beginning to be bored and to drum softly with his fingers.)
10038-8{_}1958{_}"Now, gentlemen, Buffon says that the poles were the first portions of the earth's crust to cool.
10038-8{_}1959{_}While the equator, and even the tropics of Cancer and of Capricorn, were still too boiling hot to support life, up here in the Arctic regions there was a carboniferous era goin' on--"  "Where's the coal, then?"
10038-8{_}1960{_}sneered Potts.
10038-8{_}1961{_}"It's bein' discovered ... all over ... ask him" (indicating Father Wills, who smiled assent).
10038-8{_}1962{_}"Tropical forests grew where there are glayshers now, and elephants and mastodons began life here."

10038-8{_}1964{_}interrupted the Boy, sitting up very straight.

10038-8{_}1967{_}"Good Lord!
10038-8{_}1968{_}then the Garden o' Eden was up here."

10038-8{_}1970{_}"Course!
10038-8{_}1971{_}_This_ was the cradle o' the human race.
10038-8{_}1972{_}Blow the Ganges!
10038-8{_}1973{_}Blow the Nile!
10038-8{_}1974{_}It was our Yukon that saw the first people, 'cause of course the first people lived in the first place got ready for 'em."
10038-8{_}1975{_}"That don't follow.
10038-8{_}1976{_}Read your Bible."
10038-8{_}1977{_}"If I'm not right, how did it happen there were men here when the North was first discovered?"
10038-8{_}1978{_}"Sh!"
10038-8{_}1979{_}"Mac's got the floor."
10038-8{_}1980{_}"Shut up!"
10038-8{_}1981{_}But the Boy thumped the table with one hand and arraigned the schoolmaster with the other.
10038-8{_}1982{_}"Now, Mac, I put it to you as a man o' science: if the race had got a foothold in any other part o' the world, what in Sam Hill could make 'em come up here?"
10038-8{_}1983{_}"_We're_ here."
10038-8{_}1984{_}"Yes, tomfools after gold.
10038-8{_}1985{_}They never dreamed there was gold.
10038-8{_}1986{_}No, Sir_ee!_ the only thing on earth that could make men stay here, would be that they were born here, and didn't know any better.
10038-8{_}1987{_}Don't the primitive man cling to his home, no matter what kind o' hole it is?
10038-8{_}1988{_}He's _afraid_ to leave it.
10038-8{_}1989{_}And these first men up here, why, it's plain as day--they just hung on, things gettin' worse and worse, and colder and colder, and some said, as the old men we laugh at say at home, 'The climate ain't what it was when I was a boy,' and nobody believed 'em, but everybody began to dress warmer and eat fat, and--"  "All that Buffon says is--"  "Yes--and they invented one thing after another to meet the new conditions--kaiaks and bidarras and ivory-tipped harpoons"--he was pouring out his new notions at the fastest express rate--"and the animals that couldn't stand it emigrated, and those that stayed behind got changed--"  "Dry up."

10038-8{_}2253{_}But Yagorsha says that long ago a great chief lived in the North who was a mighty hunter.
10038-8{_}2254{_}It was always summer up here then, and the big chief chased the big game from one end of the year to another, from mountain to mountain and from river to sea.
10038-8{_}2255{_}He killed the biggest moose with a blow of his fist, and caught whales with his crooked thumb for a hook.
10038-8{_}2256{_}One long day in summer he'd had a tremendous chase after a wonderful bird, and he came home without it, deadbeat and out of temper.
10038-8{_}2257{_}He lay down to rest, but the sunlight never winked, and the unending glare maddened him.
10038-8{_}2258{_}He rolled, and tossed, and roared, as only the Yukon roars when the ice rushes down to the sea.
10038-8{_}2259{_}But he couldn't sleep.
10038-8{_}2260{_}Then in an awful fury he got up, seized the day in his great hands, tore it into little bits, and tossed them high in the air.
10038-8{_}2261{_}So it was dark.
10038-8{_}2262{_}And winter fell on the world for the first time.
10038-8{_}2263{_}During months and months, just to punish this great crime, there was no bright sunshine; but often in the long night, while the chief was wearying for summer to come again, he'd be tantalised by these little bits of the broken day that flickered in the sky.

10038-8{_}3455{_}What did any risk matter?

10038-8{_}3463{_}No more anxiety for those one loves.
10038-8{_}3464{_}Gold, plenty of gold, while one is young and can spend it gaily--gold to buy back the Orange Grove, to buy freedom and power, to buy wings, and to buy happiness!
10038-8{_}3465{_}On the stairs they passed Brother Paul and the native.

10038-8{_}3470{_}CHAPTER VII  KAVIAK'S CRIME    "My little son, who look'd from thoughtful eyes,    And moved and spoke in quiet grown-up wise,    Having my law the seventh time disobey'd,    I struck him, and dismiss'd    With hard words and unkiss'd...."   Even with the plague and Brother Paul raging at the mission--even with everyone preoccupied by the claims of dead and dying, the Boy would have been glad to prolong his stay had it not been for "nagging" thoughts of the Colonel.
10038-8{_}3471{_}As it was, with the mercury rapidly rising and the wind fallen, he got the Pymeuts on the trail next day at noon, spent what was left of the night at the Kachime, and set off for camp early the following day.
10038-8{_}3472{_}He arrived something of a wreck, and with an enormous respect for the Yukon trail.
10038-8{_}3473{_}It did him good to sight the big chimney, and still more to see the big Colonel putting on his snow-shoes near the bottom of the hill, where the cabin trail met the river trail.
10038-8{_}3474{_}When the Boss o' the camp looked up and saw the prodigal coming along, rather groggy on his legs, he just stood still a moment.
10038-8{_}3475{_}Then he kicked off his web-feet, turned back a few paces uphill, and sat down on a spruce stump, folded his arms, and waited.
10038-8{_}3476{_}Was it the knapsack on his back that bowed him so?
10038-8{_}3477{_}"Hello, Kentucky!"
10038-8{_}3478{_}But the Colonel didn't look up till the Boy got quite near, chanting in his tuneless voice:     "'Grasshoppah sett'n on a swee' p'tater vine,      Swee' p'tater vine, swee' p'tater vine--'"  "What's the matter, hey, Colonel?

10038-8{_}3481{_}"We thought you were dead."
10038-8{_}3482{_}"You ought t' known me better.
10038-8{_}3483{_}Were you just sendin' out a rescue-party of one?"
10038-8{_}3484{_}The Colonel nodded.
10038-8{_}3485{_}"That party would have started before, but I cut my foot with the axe the day you left.
10038-8{_}3486{_}Where have you been, in the name o' the nation?"
10038-8{_}3487{_}"Pymeut an' Holy Cross."
10038-8{_}3488{_}"Holy Cross?
10038-8{_}3489{_}Holy Moses!
10038-8{_}3490{_}_You?_"  "Yes; and do you know, one thing I saw there gave me a serious nervous shock."
10038-8{_}3491{_}"That don't surprise me.
10038-8{_}3492{_}What was it?"
10038-8{_}3493{_}"Sheets.
10038-8{_}3494{_}When I came to go to bed--a real bed, Colonel, on legs--I found I was expected to sleep between sheets, and I just about fainted."
10038-8{_}3495{_}"That the only shock you had?"
10038-8{_}3496{_}"No, I had several.
10038-8{_}3497{_}I saw an angel.
10038-8{_}3498{_}I tell you straight, Colonel--you can bank on what I'm sayin'--that Jesuit outfit's all right."
10038-8{_}3499{_}"Oh, you think so?"
10038-8{_}3500{_}The rejoinder came a little sharply.
10038-8{_}3501{_}"Yes, sir, I just do.
10038-8{_}3502{_}I think I'd be bigoted not to admit it."
10038-8{_}3503{_}"So, you'll be thick as peas in a pod with the priests now?"
10038-8{_}3504{_}"Well, I'm the one that can afford to be.
10038-8{_}3505{_}They won't convert _me!_ And, from my point o' view, it don't matter what a man is s' long's he's a decent fella."
10038-8{_}3506{_}The Colonel's only answer was to plunge obliquely uphill.
10038-8{_}3507{_}"Say, Boss, wait for me."
10038-8{_}3508{_}The Colonel looked back.
10038-8{_}3509{_}The Boy was holding on to a scrub willow that put up wiry twigs above the snow.
10038-8{_}3510{_}"Feel as if I'd never get up the last rungs o' this darn ice-ladder!"
10038-8{_}3511{_}"Tired?
10038-8{_}3512{_}H'm!
10038-8{_}3513{_}Something of a walk to Holy Cross even on a nice mild day like this."
10038-8{_}3514{_}The Colonel made the reflection with obvious satisfaction, took off his knapsack, and sat down again.
10038-8{_}3515{_}The Boy did the same.
10038-8{_}3516{_}"The very day you lit out Father Orloff came up from the Russian mission."
10038-8{_}3517{_}"What's he like?"
10038-8{_}3518{_}"Oh, little fella in petticoats, with a beard an' a high pot-hat, like a Russian.

10038-8{_}3520{_}Since that day we haven't seen a human creature.

10038-8{_}3527{_}Kept on bragging they hadn't cold feet, and swore they'd get near to the diggins as their dogs'd take 'em.
10038-8{_}3528{_}The half-breed said they might do a hundred miles more, but probably wouldn't get beyond Anvik."
10038-8{_}3529{_}"Crazy fools!

10038-8{_}3531{_}"B'lieve you, sonny."

10038-8{_}3533{_}"Ain't to be had now for love or money."
10038-8{_}3534{_}"Lord, Colonel, if we had a team--"  "Yes, I know.
10038-8{_}3535{_}We'll probably owe our lives to the fact that we haven't."
10038-8{_}3536{_}It suddenly occurred to the Boy that, although he had just done a pretty good tramp and felt he'd rather die than go fifty feet further, it was the Colonel who was most tired.
10038-8{_}3537{_}"How's everybody?"
10038-8{_}3538{_}"Oh, I s'pose we might all of us be worse off."
10038-8{_}3539{_}"What's the matter?"
10038-8{_}3540{_}He was so long answering that the Boy's eyes turned to follow the serious outward gaze of the older man, even before he lifted one hand and swept it down the hill and out across the dim, grey prospect.
10038-8{_}3541{_}"This," said the Colonel.
10038-8{_}3542{_}Their eyes had dropped down that last stretch of the steep snow slope, across the two miles of frozen river, and ran half round the wide horizon-line, like creatures in a cage.
10038-8{_}3543{_}Whether they liked it or whether they didn't, for them there was no way out.
10038-8{_}3544{_}"It's the awful stillness."
10038-8{_}3545{_}The Colonel arraigned the distant ice-plains.
10038-8{_}3546{_}They sat there looking, listening, as if they hoped their protest might bring some signal of relenting.
10038-8{_}3547{_}No creature, not even a crystal-coated willow-twig, nothing on all the ice-bound earth stirred by as much as a hair; no mark of man past or present broke the grey monotony; no sound but their two voices disturbed the stillness of the world.
10038-8{_}3548{_}It was a quiet that penetrated, that pricked to vague alarm.
10038-8{_}3549{_}Already both knew the sting of it well.
10038-8{_}3550{_}"It's the kind of thing that gets on a fella's nerves," said the Colonel.
10038-8{_}3551{_}"I don't know as I ever felt helpless in any part of the world before.
10038-8{_}3552{_}But a man counts for precious little up here.
10038-8{_}3553{_}Do you notice how you come to listen to the silence?"
10038-8{_}3554{_}"Oh, yes, I've noticed."
10038-8{_}3555{_}"Stop."
10038-8{_}3556{_}Again he lifted his hand, and they strained their ears.
10038-8{_}3557{_}"I've done that by the hour since you left and the daft gold-diggers went up trail after you.
10038-8{_}3558{_}The other fellas feel it, too.
10038-8{_}3559{_}Don't know what we'd have done without Kaviak.
10038-8{_}3560{_}Think we ought to keep that kid, you know."
10038-8{_}3561{_}"I could get on without Kaviak if only we had some light.
10038-8{_}3562{_}It's this villainous twilight that gets into my head.
10038-8{_}3563{_}All the same, you know"--he stood up suddenly--"we came expecting to stand a lot, didn't we?"
10038-8{_}3564{_}The elder man nodded.
10038-8{_}3565{_}"Big game, big stakes.
10038-8{_}3566{_}It's all right."
10038-8{_}3567{_}Eventless enough after this, except for the passing of an Indian or two, the days crawled by.
10038-8{_}3568{_}The Boy would get up first in the morning, rake out the dead ashes, put on a couple of back-logs, bank them with ashes, and then build the fire in front.
10038-8{_}3569{_}He broke the ice in the water-bucket, and washed; filled coffee-pot and mush-kettle with water (or ice), and swung them over the fire; then he mixed the corn-bread, put it in the Dutch oven, covered it with coals, and left it to get on with its baking.
10038-8{_}3570{_}Sometimes this part of the programme was varied by his mixing a hoe-cake on a board, and setting it up "to do" in front of the fire.
10038-8{_}3571{_}Then he would call the Colonel--    "'Wake up Massa,      De day am breakin';    Peas in de pot, en de    Hoe-cake bakin''"--  for it was the Colonel's affair to take up proceedings at this point--make the coffee and the mush and keep it from burning, fry the bacon, and serve up breakfast.
10038-8{_}3572{_}Saturday brought a slight variation in the early morning routine.
10038-8{_}3573{_}The others came straggling in, as usual, but once a week Mac was sure to be first, for he had to get Kaviak up.
10038-8{_}3574{_}Mac's view of his whole duty to man seemed to centre in the Saturday scrubbing of Kaviak.
10038-8{_}3575{_}Vainly had the Esquimer stood out against compliance with this most repulsive of foreign customs.
10038-8{_}3576{_}He seemed to be always ready with some deep-laid scheme for turning the edge of Mac's iron resolution.
10038-8{_}3577{_}He tried hiding at the bottom of the bed.
10038-8{_}3578{_}It didn't work.
10038-8{_}3579{_}The next time he crouched far back under the lower bunk.
10038-8{_}3580{_}He was dragged out.
10038-8{_}3581{_}Another Saturday he embedded himself, like a moth, in a bundle of old clothes.
10038-8{_}3582{_}Mac shook him out.
10038-8{_}3583{_}He had been very sanguine the day he hid in the library.
10038-8{_}3584{_}This was a wooden box nailed to the wall on the right of the door.
10038-8{_}3585{_}Most of the bigger books--Byron, Wordsworth, Dana's "Mineralogy," and two Bibles--he had taken out and concealed in the lower bunk very skilfully, far back behind the Colonel's feet.
10038-8{_}3586{_}Copps's "Mining" and the two works on "Parliamentary Law" piled at the end of the box served as a pillow.
10038-8{_}3587{_}After climbing in and folding himself up into an incredibly small space, Kaviak managed with superhuman skill to cover himself neatly with a patchwork quilt of _Munsey, Scribner, Century, Strand_, and _Overland_ for August, '97.
10038-8{_}3588{_}No one would suspect, glancing into that library, that underneath the usual top layer of light reading, was matter less august than Law, Poetry, Science, and Revelation.
10038-8{_}3589{_}It was the base Byron, tipping the wink to Mac out of the back of the bunk, that betrayed Kaviak.
10038-8{_}3590{_}It became evident that "Farva" began to take a dour pride in the Kid's perseverance.
10038-8{_}3591{_}One morning he even pointed out to the camp the strong likeness between Kaviak and Robert Bruce.
10038-8{_}3592{_}"No, sah; the Scottish chief had to have an object-lesson, but Kaviak--Lawd!--Kaviak could give points to any spider livin'!"
10038-8{_}3593{_}This was on the morning that the Esquimer thought to escape scrubbing, even at the peril of his life, by getting up on to the swing-shelf --how, no man ever knew.
10038-8{_}3594{_}But there he sat in terror, like a very young monkey in a wind-rocked tree, hardly daring to breathe, his arms clasped tight round the demijohn; but having Mac to deal with, the end of it was that he always got washed, and equally always he seemed to register a vow that, s'help him, Heaven!
10038-8{_}3595{_}it should never happen again.
10038-8{_}3596{_}After breakfast came the clearing up.
10038-8{_}3597{_}It should have been done (under this r√©gime) by the Little Cabin men, but it seldom was.
10038-8{_}3598{_}O'Flynn was expected to keep the well-hole in the river chopped open and to bring up water every day.
10038-8{_}3599{_}This didn't always happen either, though to drink snow-water was to invite scurvy, Father Wills said.
10038-8{_}3600{_}There was also a daily need, if the Colonel could be believed, for everybody to chop firewood.
10038-8{_}3601{_}"We got enough," was Potts' invariable opinion.
10038-8{_}3602{_}"For how long?
10038-8{_}3603{_}S'pose we get scurvy and can't work; we'd freeze to death in a fortnight."
10038-8{_}3604{_}"Never saw a fireplace swalla logs whole an' never blink like this one."
10038-8{_}3605{_}"But you got no objection to sittin' by while the log-swallerin' goes on."
10038-8{_}3606{_}The Colonel or the Boy cooked the eternal beans, bacon and mush dinner, after whatever desultory work was done; as a matter of fact, there was extraordinarily little to occupy five able-bodied men.
10038-8{_}3607{_}The fun of snow-shoeing, mitigated by frostbite, quickly degenerated from a sport into a mere means of locomotion.
10038-8{_}3608{_}One or two of the party went hunting, now and then, for the scarce squirrel and the shy ptarmigan.
10038-8{_}3609{_}They tried, with signal lack of success, to catch fish, Indian fashion, through a hole in the ice.
10038-8{_}3610{_}But, for the most part, as winter darkened round them, they lounged from morning till night about the big fireplace, and smoked, and growled, and played cards, and lived as men do, finding out a deal about each other's characters, something about each other's opinions, and little or nothing about each other's history.
10038-8{_}3611{_}In the appalling stillness of the long Arctic night, any passer-by was hailed with enthusiasm, and although the food-supply in the Big Cabin was plainly going to run short before spring, no traveller--white, Indian, or Esquimaux--was allowed to go by without being warmed and fed, and made to tell where he came from and whither he was bound--questions to tax the sage.
10038-8{_}3612{_}Their unfailing hospitality was not in the least unexpected or unusual, being a virtue practised even by scoundrels in the great North-west; but it strained the resources of the little camp, a fourth of whose outfit lay under the Yukon ice.
10038-8{_}3613{_}In the state of lowered vitality to which the poor, ill-cooked food, the cold and lack of exercise, was slowly reducing them, they talked to one another less and less as time went on, and more and more--silently and each against his will--grew hyper-sensitive to the shortcomings and even to the innocent "ways" of the other fellow.
10038-8{_}3614{_}Not Mac's inertia alone, but his trick of sticking out his jaw became an offence, his rasping voice a torture.
10038-8{_}3615{_}The Boy's occasional ebullition of spirits was an outrage, the Colonel's mere size intolerable.
10038-8{_}3616{_}O'Flynn's brogue, which had amused them, grew to be just part of the hardship and barbarism that had overtaken them like an evil dream, coercing, subduing all the forces of life.
10038-8{_}3617{_}Only Kaviak seemed likely to come unscathed through the ordeal of the winter's captivity; only he could take the best place at the fire, the best morsel at dinner, and not stir angry passions; only he dared rouse Mac when the Nova Scotian fell into one of his bear-with-a-sore-head moods.
10038-8{_}3618{_}Kaviak put a stop to his staring angrily by the hour into the fire, and set him to whittling out boats and a top, thereby providing occupation for the morrow, since it was one man's work to break Kaviak of spinning the one on the table during mealtime, and sailing the other in the drinking-water bucket at all times when older eyes weren't watching.
10038-8{_}3619{_}The Colonel wrote up his journal, and read the midsummer magazines and Byron, in the face of Mac's "I do not like Byron's thought; I do not consider him healthy or instructive."
10038-8{_}3620{_}In one of his more energetic moods the Colonel made a four-footed cricket for Kaviak, who preferred it to the high stool, and always sat on it except at meals.
10038-8{_}3621{_}Once in a while, when for hours no word had been spoken except some broken reference to a royal flush or a jack-pot, or O'Flynn had said, "Bedad!
10038-8{_}3622{_}I'll go it alone," or Potts had inquired anxiously, "Got the joker?
10038-8{_}3623{_}Guess I'm euchred, then," the Boy in desperation would catch up Kaviak, balance the child on his head, or execute some other gymnastic, soothing the solemn little heathen's ruffled feelings, afterwards, by crooning out a monotonous plantation song.
10038-8{_}3624{_}It was that kind of addition to the general gloom that, at first, would fire O'Flynn to raise his own spirits, at least, by roaring out an Irish ditty.
10038-8{_}3625{_}But this was seldomer as time went on.
10038-8{_}3626{_}Even Jimmie's brogue suffered, and grew less robust.
10038-8{_}3627{_}In a depressed sort of way Mac was openly teaching Kaviak his letters, and surreptitiously, down in the Little Cabin, his prayers.
10038-8{_}3628{_}He was very angry when Potts and O'Flynn eavesdropped and roared at Kaviak's struggles with "Ow Farva."
10038-8{_}3629{_}In fact, Kaviak did not shine as a student of civilisation, though that told less against him with O'Flynn, than the fact that he wasn't "jolly and jump about, like white children."
10038-8{_}3630{_}Moreover, Jimmie, swore there was something "bogey" about the boy's intermittent knowledge of English.
10038-8{_}3631{_}Often for days he would utter nothing but "Farva" or "Maw" when he wanted his plate replenished, then suddenly he would say something that nobody could remember having taught him or even said in his presence.
10038-8{_}3632{_}It was not to be denied that Kaviak loved sugar mightily, and stole it when he could.
10038-8{_}3633{_}Mac lectured him and slapped his minute yellow hands, and Kaviak stole it all the same.
10038-8{_}3634{_}When he was bad--that is, when he had eaten his daily fill of the camp's scanty store (in such a little place it was not easy to hide from such a hunter as Kaviak)--he was taken down to the Little Cabin, smacked, and made to say "Ow Farva."
10038-8{_}3635{_}Nobody could discover that he minded much, though he learnt to try to shorten the ceremony by saying "I solly" all the way to the cabin.
10038-8{_}3636{_}As a rule he was strangely undemonstrative; but in his own grave little fashion he conducted life with no small intelligence, and learned, with an almost uncanny quickness, each man's uses from the Kaviak point of view.
10038-8{_}3637{_}The only person he wasn't sworn friends with was the handy-man, and there came to be a legend current in the camp, that Kaviak's first attempt at spontaneously stringing a sentence under that roof was, "Me got no use for Potts."
10038-8{_}3638{_}The best thing about Kaviak was that his was no craven soul.
10038-8{_}3639{_}He was obliged to steal the sugar because he lived with white people who were bigger than he, and who always took it away when they caught him.
10038-8{_}3640{_}But once the sugar was safe under his shirt, he owned up without the smallest hesitation, and took his smacking like a man.
10038-8{_}3641{_}For the rest, he flourished, filled out, and got as fat as a seal, but never a whit less solemn.
10038-8{_}3642{_}One morning the Colonel announced that now the days had grown so short, and the Trio were so late coming to breakfast, and nobody did any work to speak of, it would be a good plan to have only two meals a day.
10038-8{_}3643{_}The motion was excessively unpopular, but it was carried by a plain, and somewhat alarming, exposition of the state of supplies.
10038-8{_}3644{_}"We oughtn't to need as much food when we lazy round the fire all day," said the Colonel.

10038-8{_}3646{_}They knocked off supper, and all but the aborigine knew what it meant sometimes to go hungry to bed.

10038-8{_}3968{_}*       *       *       *       *  Three hours later, when they were all sitting round the fire, Kaviak dosed, and warm, and asleep in the lower bunk, the door opened, and in walked a white man followed by an Indian.

10038-8{_}3979{_}That gentleman had thrown back his hood, pulled off his great moose-skin gauntlets and his beaver-lined cap, and now, with a little help, dragged the drill parki over his head, and after that the fine lynx-bordered deer-skin, standing revealed at last as a well-built fellow, of thirty-eight or so, in a suit of mackinaws, standing six feet two in his heelless salmon-skin snow-boots.

10038-8{_}4034{_}The Colonel took it up, and read aloud the Father's thanks for all the white camp's kindness to Kaviak, and now that the sickness was about gone from Holy Cross, how the Fathers felt that they must relieve their neighbours of further trouble with the little native.
10038-8{_}4035{_}"I've said I'd take him back with me when I come up river about Christmas."

10038-8{_}4054{_}"I'll give you twenty-eight for that musk-rat coat," said Mac.
10038-8{_}4055{_}Benham turned, stared back at him a moment, and then laughed.
10038-8{_}4056{_}"Oh, well, I suppose I can get another made for Rainey before the first boat goes down."
10038-8{_}4057{_}"Then is it on account o' the bread," the Colonel was saying, "that the old-timer calls himself a Sour-dough?"

10038-8{_}4059{_}They crowded out after Benham.
10038-8{_}4060{_}"Coming?"
10038-8{_}4061{_}The Boy, who was last, held the door open.
10038-8{_}4062{_}Mac shook his head.
10038-8{_}4063{_}It wasn't one of the bitter nights; they'd get down yonder, and talk by the fire, till he went in and disturbed them.
10038-8{_}4064{_}That was all he had wanted.
10038-8{_}4065{_}For Mac was the only one who had noticed that Kaviak had waked up.
10038-8{_}4066{_}He was lying as still as a mouse.
10038-8{_}4067{_}Alone with him at last, Mac kept his eyes religiously turned away, sat down by the fire, and watched the sparks.
10038-8{_}4068{_}By-and-by a head was put up over the board of the lower bunk.
10038-8{_}4069{_}Mac saw it, but sat quite still.
10038-8{_}4070{_}"Farva."
10038-8{_}4071{_}He meant to answer the appeal, half cleared his throat, but his voice felt rusty; it wouldn't turn out a word.
10038-8{_}4072{_}Kaviak climbed timidly, shakily out, and stood in the middle of the floor in his bare feet.
10038-8{_}4073{_}"Farva!"
10038-8{_}4074{_}He came a little nearer till the small feet sank into the rough brown curls of the buffalo.
10038-8{_}4075{_}The child stooped to pick up his wooden cricket, wavered, and was about to fall.
10038-8{_}4076{_}Mac shot out a hand, steadied him an instant without looking, and then set the cricket in front of the fire.
10038-8{_}4077{_}He thereupon averted his face, and sat as before with folded arms.
10038-8{_}4078{_}He hadn't deliberately meant to make Kaviak be the first to "show his hand" after all that had happened, but something had taken hold of him and made him behave as he hadn't dreamed of behaving.
10038-8{_}4079{_}It was, perhaps, a fear of playing the fool as much as a determination to see how much ground he'd lost with the youngster.
10038-8{_}4080{_}The child was observing him with an almost feverish intensity.
10038-8{_}4081{_}With eyes fixed upon the wooden face to find out how far he might venture, shakily he dragged the cricket from where Mac placed it, closer, closer, and as no terrible change in the unmoved face warned him to desist, he pulled it into its usual evening position between Mac's right foot and the fireplace.
10038-8{_}4082{_}He sank down with a sigh of relief, as one who finishes a journey long and perilous.
10038-8{_}4083{_}The fire crackled and the sparks flew gaily.
10038-8{_}4084{_}Kaviak sat there in the red glow, dressed only in a shirt, staring with incredulous, mournful eyes at the Farva who had--  Then, as Mac made no sign, he sighed again, and held out two little shaky hands to the blaze.

10038-8{_}4086{_}Kaviak had started nervously.

10038-8{_}4088{_}asked Mac.
10038-8{_}4089{_}Kaviak nodded.
10038-8{_}4090{_}"Hungry?"
10038-8{_}4091{_}He nodded again, and fell to coughing.
10038-8{_}4092{_}Mac got up and brought the newly purchased coat to the fire.
10038-8{_}4093{_}"It's for you," he said, as the child's big eyes grew bigger with admiration.

10038-8{_}4096{_}He stood up, and his bare feet fluttered up and down feebly, but with huge delight.
10038-8{_}4097{_}As the parki was held ready the child tumbled dizzily into it, and Mac held him fast an instant.
10038-8{_}4098{_}In less than five minutes Kaviak was once more seated on the cricket, but very magnificent now in his musk-rat coat, so close up to Mac that he could lean against his arm, and eating out of a plenty-bowl on his knees a discreet spoonful of mush drowned in golden syrup--a supper for a Sultan if only there had been more!
10038-8{_}4099{_}When he had finished, he set the bowl down, and, as a puppy might, he pushed at Mac's arm till he found a way in, laid his head down on "Farva's" knee with a contented sigh, and closed his heavy eyes.

10038-8{_}4107{_}It had been moved, seconded, and carried by acclamation that they should celebrate Christmas, not so much by a feast of reason as by a flow of soul and a bang-up dinner, to be followed by speeches and some sort of cheerful entertainment.
10038-8{_}4108{_}"We're goin' to lay ourselves out on this entertainment," said the Boy, with painful misgivings as to the "bang-up dinner."

10038-8{_}4110{_}But, in making out the bill of fare, facts had to be faced.
10038-8{_}4111{_}"We've got our everyday little rations of beans and bacon, and we've got Potts's cake, and we've got one skinny ptarmigan to make a banquet for six hungry people!"

10038-8{_}4113{_}"And one thing we can get, even up here"--the Colonel was looking at Kaviak--"and that's a little Christmas-tree."

10038-8{_}4117{_}And he took steps that it should be, for he began stealing away Kaviak's few cherished possessions--his amulet, his top from under the bunk, his boats from out the water-bucket, wherewith to mitigate the barrenness of the Yukon tree, and to provide a pleasant surprise for the Esquimer who mourned his playthings as gone for ever.
10038-8{_}4118{_}Of an evening now, after sleep had settled on Kaviak's watchful eyes, the Boy worked at a pair of little snow-shoes, helped out by a ball of sinew he had got from Nicholas.
10038-8{_}4119{_}Mac bethought him of the valuable combination of zoological and biblical instruction that might be conveyed by means of a Noah's Ark.
10038-8{_}4120{_}He sat up late the last nights before the 25th, whittling, chipping, pegging in legs, sharpening beaks, and inking eyes, that the more important animals might be ready for the Deluge by Christmas.
10038-8{_}4121{_}The Colonel made the ark, and O'Flynn took up a collection to defray the expense of the little new mucklucks he had ordered from Nicholas.
10038-8{_}4122{_}They were to come "_sure_ by Christmas Eve," and O'Flynn was in what he called "a froightful fanteeg" as the short day of the 24th wore towards night, and never a sign of the one-eyed Pymeut.
10038-8{_}4123{_}Half a dozen times O'Flynn had gone beyond the stockade to find out if he wasn't in sight, and finally came back looking intensely disgusted, bringing a couple of white travellers who had arrived from the opposite direction; very cold, one of them deaf, and with frost-bitten feet, and both so tired they could hardly speak.
10038-8{_}4124{_}Of course, they were made as comfortable as was possible, the frozen one rubbed with snow and bandaged, and both given bacon and corn-bread and hot tea.
10038-8{_}4125{_}"You oughtn't to let yourself get into a state like this," said Mac, thinking ruefully of these strangers' obvious inability to travel for a day or two, and of the Christmas dinner, to which Benham alone had been bidden, by a great stretch of hospitality.

10038-8{_}4429{_}John Dillon was one of those frontiersmen rightly called typically American.
10038-8{_}4430{_}You see him again and again--as a cowboy in Texas, as a miner or herdsman all through the Far West; you see him cutting lumber along the Columbia, or throwing the diamond hitch as he goes from camp to camp for gold and freedom.

10038-8{_}4432{_}John Dillon was like the majority, tall, lean, muscular, not an ounce of superfluous flesh on his bones, a face almost gaunt in its clearness of cut, a thin straight nose, chin not heavy but well curved out, the eye orbit arched and deep, a frown fixed between thick eyebrows, and few words in his firm, rather grim-looking mouth.

10038-8{_}4777{_}When Mac and the Boy brought the sled home a couple of days later, it was found that a portion of its cargo consisted of a toy kyak and two bottles of hootchino, the maddening drink concocted by the natives out of fermented dough and sugar.
10038-8{_}4778{_}Apart from the question of drinking raised again by the "hootch," it is perhaps possible that, having so little else to do, they were ready to eat the more; it is also true that, busy or idle, the human body requires more nourishment in the North than it does in the South.
10038-8{_}4779{_}Certainly the men of the little Yukon camp began to find their rations horribly short commons, and to suffer a continual hunger, never wholly appeased.
10038-8{_}4780{_}It is conditions like these that bring out the brute latent in all men.
10038-8{_}4781{_}The day came to mean three scant meals.
10038-8{_}4782{_}Each meal came to mean a silent struggle in each man's soul not to let his stomach get the better of his head and heart.
10038-8{_}4783{_}At first they joked and laughed about their hunger and the scarcity.
10038-8{_}4784{_}By-and-by it became too serious, the jest was wry-faced and rang false.
10038-8{_}4785{_}They had, in the beginning, each helped himself from common dishes set in the middle of the rough plank table.
10038-8{_}4786{_}Later, each found how, without meaning to--hating himself for it--he watched food on its way to others' plates with an evil eye.
10038-8{_}4787{_}When it came to his turn, he had an ever-recurrent struggle with himself not to take the lion's share.
10038-8{_}4788{_}There were ironical comments now and then, and ill-concealed bitterness.
10038-8{_}4789{_}No one of the five would have believed he could feel so towards a human being about a morsel of food, but those who think they would be above it, have not wintered in the Arctic regions or fought in the Boer War.
10038-8{_}4790{_}The difficulty was frankly faced at last, and it was ordained in council that the Colonel should be dispenser of the food.
10038-8{_}4791{_}"Can't say I like the office," quoth he, "but here goes!"
10038-8{_}4792{_}and he cut the bacon with an anxious hand, and spooned out the beans solemnly as if he weighed each "go."
10038-8{_}4793{_}And the Trio presently retired to the Little Cabin to discuss whether the Colonel didn't show favouritism to the Boy, and, when Mac was asleep, how they could get rid of Kaviak.
10038-8{_}4794{_}So presently another council was called, and the Colonel resigned his office, stipulating that each man in turn should hold it for a week, and learn how ungrateful it was.
10038-8{_}4795{_}Moreover, that whoever was, for the nonce, occupying the painful post, should be loyally upheld by all the others, which arrangement was in force to the end.
10038-8{_}4796{_}And still, on grounds political, religious, social, trivial, the disaffection grew.
10038-8{_}4797{_}Two of the Trio sided against the odd man, Potts, and turned him out of the Little Cabin one night during a furious snowstorm, that had already lasted two days, had more than half buried the hut, and nearly snowed up the little doorway.
10038-8{_}4798{_}The Colonel and the Boy had been shovelling nearly all the day before to keep free the entrance to the Big Cabin and the precious "bottle" window, as well as their half of the path between the two dwellings.
10038-8{_}4799{_}O'Flynn and Potts had played poker and quarrelled as usual.
10038-8{_}4800{_}The morning after the ejection of Potts, and his unwilling reception at the Big Cabin, Mac and O'Flynn failed to appear for breakfast.
10038-8{_}4801{_}"Guess they're huffy," says Potts, stretching out his feet, very comfortable in their straw-lined mucklucks, before the big blaze.
10038-8{_}4802{_}"Bring on the coffee, Kaviak."
