10038-8{_}4804{_}"By the living Jingo, _I_ will then!"
10038-8{_}4805{_}says Potts, and helps himself under the Colonel's angry eyes.
10038-8{_}4806{_}The other two conferred a moment, then drew on their parkis and mittens, and with great difficulty, in spite of yesterday's work, got the door open.
10038-8{_}4807{_}It was pretty dark, but there was no doubt about it, the Little Cabin had disappeared.
10038-8{_}4808{_}"Look!
10038-8{_}4809{_}isn't that a curl of smoke?"
10038-8{_}4810{_}said the Boy.
10038-8{_}4811{_}"Yes, by George!
10038-8{_}4812{_}they're snowed under!"
10038-8{_}4813{_}"Serve 'em right!"
10038-8{_}4814{_}A heavy sigh from the Colonel.
10038-8{_}4815{_}"Yes, but _we'll_ have to dig 'em out!"
10038-8{_}4816{_}"Look here, Colonel"--the Boy spoke with touching solemnity--"_not before breakfast!_"  "Right you are!"
10038-8{_}4817{_}laughed the Colonel; and they went in.
10038-8{_}4818{_}It was that day, after the others had been released and fed, that the Boy fell out with Potts concerning who had lost the hatchet--and they came to blows.
10038-8{_}4819{_}A black eye and a bloody nose might not seem an illuminating contribution to the question, but no more was said about the hatchet after the Colonel had dragged the Boy off the prostrate form of his adversary.
10038-8{_}4820{_}But the Colonel himself lost his temper two days later when O'Flynn broached the seal set months before on the nearly empty demijohn.
10038-8{_}4821{_}For those famous "temperance punches" the Colonel had drawn on his own small stock.
10038-8{_}4822{_}He saw his blunder when O'Flynn, possessing himself of the demijohn, roared out:  "It's my whisky, I tell you!
10038-8{_}4823{_}I bought it and paid furr it, and but for me it would be at the bottom o' the Yukon now."
10038-8{_}4824{_}"Yes, and you'd be at the bottom of the Yukon yourself if you hadn't been dragged out by the scruff o' your neck.
10038-8{_}4825{_}And you'd be in a pretty fix now, if we left you alone with your whisky, which is about all you've got."
10038-8{_}4826{_}"We agreed," Potts chipped in, "that it should be kept for medicinal purposes only."
10038-8{_}4827{_}Sullenly O'Flynn sipped at his grog.
10038-8{_}4828{_}Potts had "hogged most of the hootch."
10038-8{_}4829{_}*       *       *       *       *  "Look here, Boy," said Mac at supper, "I said I wouldn't eat off this plate again."
10038-8{_}4830{_}"Oh, dry up!
10038-8{_}4831{_}One tin plate's like another tin plate."
10038-8{_}4832{_}"Are you reflecting on the washer-up, Mr.

10038-8{_}4836{_}He held it up as if to shy it at the Boy.
10038-8{_}4837{_}The young fellow turned with a flash in his eye and stood taut.

10038-8{_}4839{_}But MacCann thought better of it.

10038-8{_}4846{_}"Maybe you can't hand it up for more as often as you like, but you'll always find it there," he said when McCann came back.
10038-8{_}4847{_}And the laugh went against the dainty pioneer, who to the end of the chapter ate from a plate nailed fast to the table.
10038-8{_}4848{_}"I begin to understand," says the Colonel to the Boy, under cover of the others' talk, "why it's said to be such a devil of a test of a fellow's decency to winter in this infernal country."
10038-8{_}4849{_}"They say it's always a man's pardner he comes to hate most," returned the Boy, laughing good-humouredly at the Colonel.
10038-8{_}4850{_}"Naturally.
10038-8{_}4851{_}Look at the row in the Little Cabin."
10038-8{_}4852{_}"That hasn't been the only row," the Boy went on more thoughtfully.
10038-8{_}4853{_}"I say, Colonel"--he lowered his voice--"do you know there'll have to be a new system of rations?

10038-8{_}4855{_}"I know it," said the Colonel very gravely.
10038-8{_}4856{_}"Was there a miscalculation?"

10038-8{_}4858{_}There'll be a hell of a row."
10038-8{_}4859{_}He looked up, and saw Potts watching them suspiciously.
10038-8{_}4860{_}It had come to this: if two men talked low the others pricked their ears.
10038-8{_}4861{_}"But lack of grub," resumed the Colonel in his usual voice, as though he had not noticed, "is only one of our difficulties.
10038-8{_}4862{_}Lack of work is just about as bad.
10038-8{_}4863{_}It breeds a thousand devils.
10038-8{_}4864{_}We're a pack o' fools.
10038-8{_}4865{_}Here we are, all of us, hard hit, some of us pretty well cleaned out o' ready cash, and here's dollars and dollars all round us, and we sit over the fire like a lot of God-forsaken natives."
10038-8{_}4866{_}"Dollars!
10038-8{_}4867{_}Where?"
10038-8{_}4868{_}"Growin' on the trees, boys; a forest full."
10038-8{_}4869{_}"Oh, timber."
10038-8{_}4870{_}Enthusiasm cooled.
10038-8{_}4871{_}"Look at what they say about those fellows up at Anvik, what they made last year."
10038-8{_}4872{_}"They've got a saw-mill."
10038-8{_}4873{_}"_Now_ they have.

10038-8{_}4875{_}We ought to have set to, as soon as the cabins were built, and cut wood for the summer traffic.
10038-8{_}4876{_}But since there are five of us, we can make a good thing of it yet."
10038-8{_}4877{_}The Colonel finally carried the day.
10038-8{_}4878{_}They went at it next morning, and, as the projector of the work had privately predicted, a better spirit prevailed in the camp for some time.
10038-8{_}4879{_}But here were five men, only one of whom had had any of the steadying grace of stiff discipline in his life, men of haphazard education, who had "chucked" more or less easy berths in a land of many creature comforts ... for this--to fell and haul birch and fir trees in an Arctic climate on half-rations!
10038-8{_}4880{_}It began to be apparent that the same spirit was invading the forest that had possession of the camp; two, or at most three, did the work, and the rest shirked, got snow-blindness and rheumatism, and let the others do his share, counting securely, nevertheless, on his fifth of the proceeds, just as he counted (no matter what proportion he had contributed) on his full share of the common stock of food.
10038-8{_}4881{_}"I came out here a Communist--" said the Boy one day to the Colonel.
10038-8{_}4882{_}"And an agnostic," smiled the older man.
10038-8{_}4883{_}"Oh, I'm an agnostic all right, now and for ever.
10038-8{_}4884{_}But this winter has cured my faith in Communism."
10038-8{_}4885{_}Early February brought not only lengthening daylight, but a radical change in the weather.
10038-8{_}4886{_}The woodsmen worked in their shirt-sleeves, perspired freely, and said in the innocence of their hearts, "If winter comes early up here, spring does the same."
10038-8{_}4887{_}The whole hillside was one slush, and the snow melting on the ill-made Little Cabin roof brought a shower-bath into the upper bunk.
10038-8{_}4888{_}Few things in nature so surely stir the pulse of man as the untimely coming of a few spring days, that have lost their way in the calendar, and wandered into winter.
10038-8{_}4889{_}No trouble now to get the Big Chimney men away from the fireside.
10038-8{_}4890{_}They held up their bloodless faces in the faint sunshine, and their eyes, with the pupils enlarged by the long reign of night, blinked feebly, like an owl's forced to face the morning.
10038-8{_}4891{_}There were none of those signs in the animal world outside, of premature stir and cheerful awaking, that in other lands help the illusion that winter lies behind, but there was that even more stimulating sweet air abroad, that subtle mixture of sun and yielding frost, that softened wind that comes blowing across the snow, still keen to the cheek, but subtly reviving to the sensitive nostril, and caressing to the eyes.
10038-8{_}4892{_}The Big Chimney men drew deep breaths, and said in their hearts the battle was over and won.
10038-8{_}4893{_}Kaviak, for ever following at Mac's heels "like a rale Irish tarrier," found his allegiance waver in these stirring, blissful days, if ever Farva so belied character and custom as to swing an axe for any length of time.
10038-8{_}4894{_}Plainly out of patience, Kaviak would throw off the musk-rat coat, and run about in wet mucklucks and a single garment--uphill, downhill, on important errands which he confided to no man.
10038-8{_}4895{_}It is part of the sorcery of such days that men's thoughts, like birds', turn to other places, impatient of the haven that gave them shelter in rough weather overpast.
10038-8{_}4896{_}The Big Chimney men leaned on their axes and looked north, south, east, west.
10038-8{_}4897{_}Then the Colonel would give a little start, turn about, lift his double-bitter, and swing it frontier fashion, first over one shoulder, then over the other, striking cleanly home each time, working with a kind of splendid rhythm more harmonious, more beautiful to look at, than most of the works of men.
10038-8{_}4898{_}This was, perhaps, the view of his comrades, for they did a good deal of looking at the Colonel.
10038-8{_}4899{_}He said he was a modest man and didn't like it, and Mac, turning a little rusty under the gibe, answered:  "Haven't you got the sense to see we've cut all the good timber just round here?"
10038-8{_}4900{_}and again he turned his eyes to the horizon line.
10038-8{_}4901{_}"Mac's right," said the Boy; and even the Colonel stood still a moment, and they all looked away to that land at the end of the world where the best materials are for the building of castles--it's the same country so plainly pointed out by the Rainbow's End, and never so much as in the springtime does it lure men with its ancient promise.
10038-8{_}4902{_}"Come along, Colonel; let's go and look for real timber--"  "And let's find it nearer water-level--where the steamers can see it right away."
10038-8{_}4903{_}"What about the kid?"
10038-8{_}4904{_}"Me come," said Kaviak, with a highly obliging air.
10038-8{_}4905{_}"No; you stay at home."
10038-8{_}4906{_}"No; go too."
10038-8{_}4907{_}"Go too, thou babbler!
10038-8{_}4908{_}Kaviak's a better trail man than some I could mention."
10038-8{_}4909{_}"We'll have to carry him home," objected Potts.
10038-8{_}4910{_}"Now don't tell us you'll do any of the carryin', or we'll lose confidence in you, Potts."
10038-8{_}4911{_}The trail was something awful, but on their Canadian snowshoes they got as far as an island, six miles off.
10038-8{_}4912{_}One end of it was better wooded than any easily accessible place they had seen.
10038-8{_}4913{_}"Why, this is quite like real spruce," said the Boy, and O'Flynn admitted that even in California "these here would be called 'trees' wid no intintion o' bein' sarcaustic."
10038-8{_}4914{_}So they cut holes in the ice, and sounded for the channel.
10038-8{_}4915{_}"Yes, sir, the steamers can make a landin' here, and here's where we'll have our wood-rack."
10038-8{_}4916{_}They went home in better spirits than they had been in since that welter of gold had lain on the Big Cabin table.
10038-8{_}4917{_}*       *       *       *       *  But a few days sufficed to wear the novelty off the new wood camp for most of the party.
10038-8{_}4918{_}Potts and O'Flynn set out in the opposite direction one morning with a hand-sled, and provisions to last several days.
10038-8{_}4919{_}They were sick of bacon and beans, and were "goin' huntin'."
10038-8{_}4920{_}No one could deny that a moose or even a grouse--anything in the shape of fresh meat--was sufficiently needed.
10038-8{_}4921{_}But Potts and O'Flynn were really sick and sore from their recent slight attack of wood-felling.
10038-8{_}4922{_}They were after bigger game, too, as well as grouse, and a few days "off."
10038-8{_}4923{_}It had turned just enough colder to glaze the trail and put it in fine condition.
10038-8{_}4924{_}They went down the river to the _Oklahoma,_ were generously entertained by Captain Rainey, and learned that, with earlier contracts on his hands, he did not want more wood from them than they had already corded.
10038-8{_}4925{_}They returned to the camp without game, but with plenty of whisky, and information that freed them from the yoke of labour, and from the lash of ironic comment.
10038-8{_}4926{_}In vain the Colonel urged that the _Oklahoma_ was not the only steamer plying the Yukon, that with the big rush of the coming season the traffic would be enormous, and a wood-pile as good as a gold mine.
10038-8{_}4927{_}The cause was lost.
10038-8{_}4928{_}"You won't get us to make galley-slaves of ourselves on the off-chance of selling.

10038-8{_}4934{_}The Boy and the Colonel turned into their bunks at eleven o'clock.

10038-8{_}5143{_}Two days after, three men with a child stood in front of the larger cabin, saying good-bye to their two comrades who were starting out on snow-shoes to do a little matter of 625 miles of Arctic travelling, with two weeks' scant provisioning, some tea and things for trading, bedding, two rifles, and a kettle, all packed on one little hand-sled.
10038-8{_}5144{_}There had been some unexpected feeling, and even some real generosity shown at the last, on the part of the three who were to profit by the exodus--falling heir thereby to a bigger, warmer cabin and more food.

10038-8{_}5187{_}CHAPTER X  PRINCESS MUCKLUCK    "We all went to Tibbals to see the Kinge, who used my mother    and my aunt very gratiouslie; but we all saw a great chaunge    betweene the fashion of the Court as it was now, and of y in ye    Queene's, for we were all lowzy by sittinge in Sr Thomas    Erskin's chamber."
10038-8{_}5188{_}_Memoir: Anne Countess of Dorset_, 1603.
10038-8{_}5189{_}It was the 26th of February, that first day that they "hit the Long Trail."
10038-8{_}5190{_}Temperature only about twenty degrees, the Colonel thought, and so little wind it had the effect of being warmer.
10038-8{_}5191{_}Trail in fair condition, weather gray and steady.
10038-8{_}5192{_}Never men in better spirits.
10038-8{_}5193{_}To have left the wrangling and the smouldering danger of the camp behind, that alone, as the Boy said, was "worth the price of admission."
10038-8{_}5194{_}Exhilarating, too, to men of their temperament, to have cut the Gordian knot of the difficulty by risking themselves on this unprecedented quest for peace and food.
10038-8{_}5195{_}Gold, too?
10038-8{_}5196{_}Oh, yes--with a smile to see how far that main object had drifted into the background--they added, "and for gold."
10038-8{_}5197{_}They believed they had hearkened well to the counsel that bade them "travel light."
10038-8{_}5198{_}"Remember, every added ounce is against you."
10038-8{_}5199{_}"Nobody in the North owns anything that's heavy," had been said in one fashion or another so often that it lost its ironic sound in the ears of men who had come so far to carry away one of the heaviest things under the sun.
10038-8{_}5200{_}The Colonel and the Boy took no tent, no stove, not even a miner's pick and pan.
10038-8{_}5201{_}These last, General Lighter had said, could be obtained at Min√≥ok; and "there isn't a cabin on the trail," Dillon had added, "without 'em."
10038-8{_}5202{_}For the rest, the carefully-selected pack on the sled contained the marmot-skin, woollen blankets, a change of flannels apiece, a couple of sweaters, a Norfolk jacket, and several changes of foot-gear.
10038-8{_}5203{_}This last item was dwelt on earnestly by all.
10038-8{_}5204{_}"Keep your feet dry," John Dillon had said, "and leave the rest to God Almighty."
10038-8{_}5205{_}They were taking barely two weeks' rations, and a certain amount of stuff to trade with the up-river Indians, when their supplies should be gone.
10038-8{_}5206{_}They carried a kettle, an axe, some quinine, a box of the carbolic ointment all miners use for foot-soreness, O'Flynn's whisky, and two rifles and ammunition.
10038-8{_}5207{_}In spite of having eliminated many things that most travellers would count essential, they found their load came to a little over two hundred pounds.
10038-8{_}5208{_}But every day would lessen it, they told each other with a laugh, and with an inward misgiving, lest the lightening should come all too quickly.
10038-8{_}5209{_}They had seen in camp that winter so much of the frailty of human temper that, although full of faith by now in each other's native sense and fairness, they left nothing to a haphazard division of labour.
10038-8{_}5210{_}They parcelled out the work of the day with absolute impartiality.
10038-8{_}5211{_}To each man so many hours of going ahead to break trail, if the snow was soft, while the other dragged the sled; or else while one pulled in front, the other pushed from behind, in regular shifts by the watch, turn and turn about.
10038-8{_}5212{_}The Colonel had cooked all winter, so it was the Boy's turn at that--the Colonel's to decide the best place to camp, because it was his affair to find seasoned wood for fuel, his to build the fire in the snow on green logs laid close together--his to chop enough wood to cook breakfast the next morning.
10038-8{_}5213{_}All this they had arranged before they left the Big Chimney.
10038-8{_}5214{_}That they did not cover more ground that first day was a pure chance, not likely to recur, due to an unavoidable loss of time at Pymeut.
10038-8{_}5215{_}Knowing the fascination that place exercised over his companion, the Colonel called a halt about seven miles off from the Big Chimney, that they might quickly despatch a little cold luncheon they carried in their pockets, and push on without a break till supper.
10038-8{_}5216{_}"We've got no time to waste at Pymeut," observes the Colonel significantly.
10038-8{_}5217{_}"I ain't achin' to stop at Pymeut," says his pardner with a superior air, standing up, as he swallowed his last mouthful of cold bacon and corn-bread, and cheerfully surveyed the waste.
10038-8{_}5218{_}"Who says it's cold, even if the wind is up?
10038-8{_}5219{_}And the track's bully.
10038-8{_}5220{_}But see here, Colonel, you mustn't go thinkin' it's smooth glare-ice, like this, all the way."
10038-8{_}5221{_}"Oh, I was figurin' that it would be."
10038-8{_}5222{_}But the Boy paid no heed to the irony.
10038-8{_}5223{_}"And it's a custom o' the country to get the wind in your face, as a rule, whichever way you go."
10038-8{_}5224{_}"Well, I'm not complainin' as yet."
10038-8{_}5225{_}"Reckon you needn't if you're blown like dandelion-down all the way to Min√≥ok.

10038-8{_}5227{_}the wind's stronger!
10038-8{_}5228{_}Say, Colonel, let's rig a sail."
10038-8{_}5229{_}"Foolishness."
10038-8{_}5230{_}"No, sir.
10038-8{_}5231{_}We'll go by Pymeut in an ice-boat, lickety split.
10038-8{_}5232{_}And it'll be a good excuse for not stopping, though I think we ought to say good-bye to Nicholas."
10038-8{_}5233{_}This view inclined the Colonel to think better of an ice-boat.
10038-8{_}5234{_}He had once crossed the Bay of Toronto in that fashion, and began to wonder if such a mode of progression applied to sleds might not aid largely in solving the Min√≥ok problem.
10038-8{_}5235{_}While he was wondering the Boy unlashed the sled-load, and pulled off the canvas cover as the Colonel came back with his mast.
10038-8{_}5236{_}Between them, with no better tools than axe, jack-knives, and a rope, and with fingers freezing in the south wind, they rigged the sail.
10038-8{_}5237{_}The fact that they had this increasingly favourable wind on their very first day showed that they were specially smiled on by the great natural forces.
10038-8{_}5238{_}The superstitious feeling that only slumbers in most breasts, that Mother Nature is still a mysterious being, who has her favourites whom she guards, her born enemies whom she baulks, pursues, and finally overwhelms, the age-old childishness stirred pleasantly in both men, and in the younger came forth unabashed in speech:  "I tell you the omens are good!
10038-8{_}5239{_}This expedition's goin' to get there."
10038-8{_}5240{_}Then, with the involuntary misgiving that follows hard upon such boasting, he laughed uneasily and added, "I mean to sacrifice the first deer's tongue I don't want myself, to Yukon Inua; but here's to the south wind!"
10038-8{_}5241{_}He turned some corn-bread crumbs out of his pocket, and saw, delighted, how the gale, grown keener, snatched eagerly at them and hurried them up the trail.
10038-8{_}5242{_}The ice-boat careened and strained eagerly to sail away.
10038-8{_}5243{_}The two gold-seekers, laughing like schoolboys, sat astride the pack; the Colonel shook out the canvas, and they scudded off up the river like mad.
10038-8{_}5244{_}The great difficulty was the steering; but it was rip-roaring fun, the Boy said, and very soon there were natives running down to the river, to stare open-mouthed at the astounding apparition, to point and shout something unintelligible that sounded like "Muchtaravik!"
10038-8{_}5245{_}"Why, it's the Pymeuts!
10038-8{_}5246{_}Pardner, we'll be in Min√≥ok by supper-ti--"  The words hadn't left his lips when he saw, a few yards in front of them, a faint cloud of steam rising up from the ice--that dim danger-signal that flies above an air-hole.
10038-8{_}5247{_}The Colonel, never noticing, was heading straight for the ghastly trap.
10038-8{_}5248{_}"God, Colonel!
10038-8{_}5249{_}Blow-hole!"
10038-8{_}5250{_}gasped the Boy.
10038-8{_}5251{_}The Colonel simply rolled off the pack turning over and over on the ice, but keeping hold of the rope.
10038-8{_}5252{_}The sled swerved, turned on her side, and slid along with a sound of snapping and tearing.
10038-8{_}5253{_}While they were still headed straight for the hole, the Boy had gathered himself for a clear jump to the right, but the sled's sudden swerve to the left broke his angle sharply.
10038-8{_}5254{_}He was flung forward on the new impetus, spun over the smooth surface, swept across the verge and under the cloud, clutching wildly at the ragged edge of ice as he went down.
10038-8{_}5255{_}All Pymeut had come rushing pell-mell.
10038-8{_}5256{_}The Colonel was gathering himself up and looking round in a dazed kind of way as Nicholas flashed by.
10038-8{_}5257{_}Just beyond, in that yawning hole, fully ten feet wide by fifteen long, the Boy's head appeared an instant, and then was lost like something seen in a dream.
10038-8{_}5258{_}Some of the Pymeuts with quick knives were cutting the canvas loose.
10038-8{_}5259{_}One end was passed to Nicholas; he knotted it to his belt, and went swiftly, but gingerly, forward nearer the perilous edge.
10038-8{_}5260{_}He had flung himself down on his stomach just as the Boy rose again.
10038-8{_}5261{_}Nicholas lurched his body over the brink, his arms outstretched, straining farther, farther yet, till it seemed as if only the counterweight of the rest of the population at the other end of the canvas prevented his joining the Boy in the hole.
10038-8{_}5262{_}But Nicholas had got a grip of him, and while two of the Pymeuts hung on to the half-stunned Colonel to prevent his adding to the complication, Nicholas, with a good deal of trouble in spite of Yagorsha's help, hauled the Boy out of the hole and dragged him up on the ice-edge.
10038-8{_}5263{_}The others applied themselves lustily to their end of the canvas, and soon they were all at a safe distance from the yawning danger.
10038-8{_}5264{_}The Boy's predominant feeling had been one of intense surprise.
10038-8{_}5265{_}He looked round, and a hideous misgiving seized him.
10038-8{_}5266{_}"Anything the matter with you, Colonel?"
10038-8{_}5267{_}His tone was so angry that, as they stared at each other, they both fell to laughing.
10038-8{_}5268{_}"Well, I rather thought that was what _I_ was going to say"; and Kentucky heaved a deep sigh of relief.
10038-8{_}5269{_}The Boy's teeth began to chatter, and his clothes were soon freezing on him.
10038-8{_}5270{_}They got him up off the ice, and Nicholas and the sturdy old Pymeut story-teller, Yagorsha, walked him, or ran him rather, the rest of the way to Pymeut, for they were not so near the village as the travellers had supposed on seeing nearly the whole male population.
10038-8{_}5271{_}The Colonel was not far behind, and several of the bucks were bringing the disabled sled.
10038-8{_}5272{_}Before reaching the Kachime, they were joined by the women and children, Muckluck much concerned at the sight of her friend glazed in ice from head to heel.
10038-8{_}5273{_}Nicholas and Yagorsha half dragged, half pulled him into the Kachime.

10038-8{_}5275{_}It was already smoking viciously as though the seal-lamps weren't doing enough in that line, when Yagorsha and Nicholas laid the half-frozen traveller on the sleeping-bench.
10038-8{_}5276{_}The Pymeuts knew that the great thing was to get the ice-stiffened clothes off as quickly as might be, and that is to be done expeditiously only by cutting them off.

10038-8{_}6603{_}The Boy waited for him to quiet down.
10038-8{_}6604{_}"What's the first rule," demanded the Colonel, half sitting up, "of the most powerful Catholic Order?
10038-8{_}6605{_}Blind obedience to an old gentleman over in Italy."
10038-8{_}6606{_}"I said last night, you know," the Boy put in quite meekly, "that it all seemed very un-American."
10038-8{_}6607{_}"Huh!
10038-8{_}6608{_}Glad you can see that much."
10038-8{_}6609{_}The Colonel drove his huge fist at the provision-bag, as though to beat the stiffnecked beans into a feathery yielding.
10038-8{_}6610{_}"Blind submission don't come easy to most Americans.
10038-8{_}6611{_}The Great Republic was built upon revolt;" and he pulled the covers over his head.
10038-8{_}6612{_}"I know, I know.
10038-8{_}6613{_}We jaw an awful lot about freedom and about what's American.
10038-8{_}6614{_}There's plenty o' free speech in America and plenty o' machinery, but there's a great deal o' human nature, too, I guess."
10038-8{_}6615{_}The Boy looked out of the corner of his eye at the blanketed back of his big friend.
10038-8{_}6616{_}"And maybe there'll always be some people who--who think there's something in the New Testament notion o' sacrifice and service."
10038-8{_}6617{_}The Colonel rolled like an angry leviathan, and came to the surface to blow.
10038-8{_}6618{_}But the Boy dashed on, with a fearful joy in his own temerity.
10038-8{_}6619{_}"The difference between us, Colonel, is that I'm an unbeliever, and I know it, and you're a cantankerous old heathen, and you _don't_ know it."
10038-8{_}6620{_}The Colonel sat suddenly bolt upright.
10038-8{_}6621{_}"Needn't look at me like that.
10038-8{_}6622{_}You're as bad as anybody--rather worse.
10038-8{_}6623{_}Why are you _here?_ Dazzled and lured by the great gold craze.
10038-8{_}6624{_}An' you're not even poor.
10038-8{_}6625{_}You want _more_ gold.
10038-8{_}6626{_}You've got a home to stay in; but you weren't satisfied, not even in the fat lands down below."
10038-8{_}6627{_}"Well," said the Colonel solemnly, blinking at the fire, "I hope I'm a Christian, but as to bein' satisfied--"  "Church of England can't manage it, hey?"
10038-8{_}6628{_}"Church of England's got nothing to do with it.
10038-8{_}6629{_}It's a question o' character.
10038-8{_}6630{_}Satisfied!
10038-8{_}6631{_}We're little enough, God knows, but we're too big for that."
10038-8{_}6632{_}The Boy stood up, back to the fire, eyes on the hilltops whitening in the starlight.
10038-8{_}6633{_}"Perhaps--not--all of us."
10038-8{_}6634{_}"Yes, sah, all of us."
10038-8{_}6635{_}The Colonel lifted his head with a fierce look of most un-Christian pride.
10038-8{_}6636{_}Behind him the hills, leaving the struggling little wood far down the slope, went up and up into dimness, reaching to the near-by stars, and looking down to the far-off camp fire by the great ice-river's edge.
10038-8{_}6637{_}"Yes, sah," the Colonel thundered again, "all that have got good fightin' blood in 'em, like you and me.
10038-8{_}6638{_}'Tisn't as if we came of any worn-out, frightened, servile old stock.
10038-8{_}6639{_}You and I belong to the free-livin', hard-ridin', straight-shootin' Southerners.
10038-8{_}6640{_}The people before us fought bears, and fought Indians, and beat the British, and when there wasn't anything else left to beat, turned round and began to beat one another.
10038-8{_}6641{_}It was the one battle we found didn't pay.
10038-8{_}6642{_}We finished that job up in '65, and since then we've been lookin' round for something else to beat.
10038-8{_}6643{_}We've got down now to beatin' records, and foreign markets, and breedin' prize bulls; but we don't breed cowards--yet; and we ain't lookin' round for any asylums.
10038-8{_}6644{_}The Catholic Church is an asylum.
10038-8{_}6645{_}It's for people who never had any nerve, or who have lost it."
10038-8{_}6646{_}The Colonel turned about, wagged his head defiantly at the icy hills and the night, and in the after-stillness fell sound asleep in the snow.
10038-8{_}6647{_}CHAPTER XII  THE GREAT WHITE SILENCE    "--paa dit Firmament     Den klare Nordlyslampe taendt...."   Innocently thinking that they had seen Arctic travelling at its worst, and secretly looking upon themselves as highly accomplished trailmen, they had covered the forty-one miles from Holy Cross to Anvik in less than three days.
10038-8{_}6648{_}The Colonel made much of the pleasant and excellent man at the head of the Episcopal mission there, and the Boy haunted Benham's store, picking up a little Ingalik and the A. C. method of trading with the Indians, who, day and night, with a number of stranded Klondykers, congregated about the grateful warmth of the big iron stove.
10038-8{_}6649{_}The travellers themselves did some business with the A. C. agent, laying in supplies of fresh meat, and even augmenting their hitherto carefully restricted outfit, for they were going far beyond the reach of stores, or even of missions.
10038-8{_}6650{_}Anvik was the last white settlement below Nulato; Nulato was said to be over two hundred miles to the northward.
10038-8{_}6651{_}And yet after all their further preparation and expense, each man kept saying in his heart, during those first days out from Anvik, that the journey would be easy enough but for their "comforts"--the burden on the sled.
10038-8{_}6652{_}By all the rules of arithmetic, the daily subtraction of three meals from the store should have lightened the load.
10038-8{_}6653{_}It seemed to have the opposite effect.
10038-8{_}6654{_}By some process of evil enchantment every ounce grew to weigh a pound, every pound a hundredweight.
10038-8{_}6655{_}The sled itself was bewitched.
10038-8{_}6656{_}Recall how lightsomely it ran down the snowy slope, from the Big Chimney Cabin to the river trail, that morning they set forth.
10038-8{_}6657{_}The Boy took its pretty impetuosity for a happy augury--the very sled was eager for the mighty undertaking.
10038-8{_}6658{_}But never in all that weary march did it manifest again any such modest alacrity.
10038-8{_}6659{_}If, thereafter, in the long going "up river" there came an interval of downhill, the sled turned summersaults in the air, wound its forward or backward rope round willow scrub or alder, or else advanced precipitately with an evil, low-comedy air, bottom side up, to attack its master in the shins.
10038-8{_}6660{_}It either held back with a power superhuman, or it lunged forward with a momentum that capsized its weary conductor.
10038-8{_}6661{_}Its manners grew steadily worse as the travellers pushed farther and farther into the wilderness, beyond the exorcising power of Holy Cross, beyond the softening influences of Christian hospitality at Episcopal Anvik, even beyond Tischsocket, the last of the Indian villages for a hundred miles.
10038-8{_}6662{_}The two who had been scornful of the frailty of temper they had seen common in men's dealings up here in the North, began to realize that all other trials of brotherhood pale before the strain of life on the Arctic trail.
10038-8{_}6663{_}Beyond any question, after a while something goes wrong with the nerves.
10038-8{_}6664{_}The huge drafts on muscular endurance have, no doubt, something to do with it.
10038-8{_}6665{_}They worked hard for fourteen, sometimes seventeen, hours at a stretch; they were ill-fed, suffering from exposure, intense cold, and a haunting uncertainty of the end of the undertaking.
10038-8{_}6666{_}They were reasonable fellows as men go, with a respect for each other, but when hardship has got on the nerves, when you are suffering the agonies of snow-blindness, sore feet, and the pangs of hunger, you are not, to put it mildly, at your best as a member of the social order.
10038-8{_}6667{_}They sometimes said things they were ashamed to remember, but both men grew carefuller at crucial moments, and the talkative one more silent as time went on.
10038-8{_}6668{_}By the rule of the day the hard shift before dinner usually fell to the Boy.
10038-8{_}6669{_}It was the worst time in the twenty-four hours, and equally dreaded by both men.
10038-8{_}6670{_}It was only the first night out from Anvik, after an unusually trying day, the Boy was tramping heavily ahead, bent like an old man before the cutting sleet, fettered like a criminal, hands behind back, rope-wound, stiff, straining at the burden of the slow and sullen sled.
10038-8{_}6671{_}On a sudden he stopped, straightened his back, and remonstrated with the Colonel in unprintable terms, for putting off the halt later than ever they had yet, "after such a day."
10038-8{_}6672{_}"Can't make fire with green cotton-wood," was the Colonel's rejoiner.
10038-8{_}6673{_}"Then let's stop and rest, anyhow."
10038-8{_}6674{_}"Nuh!
10038-8{_}6675{_}We know where that would land us.
10038-8{_}6676{_}Men who stop to rest, go to sleep in the snow, and men who go to sleep in the snow on empty stomachs don't wake up."
10038-8{_}6677{_}They pushed on another mile.
10038-8{_}6678{_}When the Colonel at last called the halt, the Boy sank down on the sled too exhausted to speak.
10038-8{_}6679{_}But it had grown to be a practice with them not to trust themselves to talk at this hour.
10038-8{_}6680{_}The Colonel would give the signal to stop, simply by ceasing to push the sled that the boy was wearily dragging.
10038-8{_}6681{_}The Boy had invariably been feeling (just as the Colonel had before, during his shift in front) that the man behind wasn't helping all he might, whereupon followed a vague, consciously unreasonable, but wholly irresistible rage against the partner of his toil.
10038-8{_}6682{_}But however much the man at the back was supposed to spare himself, the man in front had never yet failed to know when the impetus from behind was really removed.
10038-8{_}6683{_}The Boy sat now on the sled, silent, motionless, while the Colonel felled and chopped and brought the wood.
10038-8{_}6684{_}Then the Boy dragged himself up, made the fire and the beef-tea.
10038-8{_}6685{_}But still no word even after that reviving cup--the usual signal for a few remarks and more social relations to be established.
10038-8{_}6686{_}Tonight no sound out of either.
10038-8{_}6687{_}The Colonel changed his footgear and the melted snow in the pot began to boil noisily.
10038-8{_}6688{_}But the Boy, who had again betaken himself to the sled, didn't budge.
10038-8{_}6689{_}No man who really knows the trail would have dared, under the circumstances, to remind his pardner that it was now his business to get up and fry the bacon.
10038-8{_}6690{_}But presently, without looking up, the hungry Colonel ventured:  "Get your dry things!"
10038-8{_}6691{_}"Feet aren't wet."
10038-8{_}6692{_}"Don't talk foolishness; here are your things."
10038-8{_}6693{_}The Colonel flung in the Boy's direction the usual change, two pairs of heavy socks, the "German knitted" and "the felt."
10038-8{_}6694{_}"Not wet," repeated the Boy.
10038-8{_}6695{_}"You know you are."
10038-8{_}6696{_}"Could go through water in these mucklucks."
10038-8{_}6697{_}"I'm not saying the wet has come in from outside; but you know as well as I do a man sweats like a horse on the trail."
10038-8{_}6698{_}Still the Boy sat there, with his head sunk between his shoulders.
10038-8{_}6699{_}"First rule o' this country is to keep your feet dry, or else pneumonia, rheumatism--God knows what!"
10038-8{_}6700{_}"First rule o' this country is mind your own business, or else--God knows what!"
10038-8{_}6701{_}The Colonel looked at the Boy a moment, and then turned his back.
10038-8{_}6702{_}The Boy glanced up conscience-stricken, but still only half alive, dulled by the weight of a crushing weariness.
10038-8{_}6703{_}The Colonel presently bent over the fire and was about to lift off the turbulently boiling pot.
10038-8{_}6704{_}The Boy sprang to his feet, ready to shout, "You do your work, and keep your hands off mine," but the Colonel turned just in time to say with unusual gentleness:  "If you _like_, I'll make supper to-night;" and the Boy, catching his breath, ran forward, swaying a little, half blind, but with a different look in his tired eyes.
10038-8{_}6705{_}"No, no, old man.
10038-8{_}6706{_}It isn't as bad as that."
10038-8{_}6707{_}And again it was two friends who slept side by side in the snow.
10038-8{_}6708{_}The next morning the Colonel, who had been kept awake half the night by what he had been thinking was neuralgia in his eyes, woke late, hearing the Boy calling:  "I say, Kentucky, aren't you _ever_ goin' to get up?"
10038-8{_}6709{_}"Get up?"
10038-8{_}6710{_}said the Colonel.
10038-8{_}6711{_}"Why should I, when it's pitch-dark?"
10038-8{_}6712{_}"_What?_"  "Fire clean out, eh?"
10038-8{_}6713{_}But he smelt the tea and bacon, and sat up bewildered, with a hand over his smarting eyes.
10038-8{_}6714{_}The Boy went over and knelt down by him, looking at him curiously.
10038-8{_}6715{_}"Guess you're a little snow-blind, Colonel; but it won't last, you know."
10038-8{_}6716{_}"Blind!"
10038-8{_}6717{_}"No, no, only _snow_-blind.
10038-8{_}6718{_}Big difference;" and he took out his rag of a handkerchief, got some water in a tin cup, and the eyes were bathed and bandaged.
10038-8{_}6719{_}"It won't last, you know.
10038-8{_}6720{_}You'll just have to take it easy for a few days."
10038-8{_}6721{_}The Colonel groaned.
10038-8{_}6722{_}For the first time he seemed to lose heart.
10038-8{_}6723{_}He sat during breakfast with bandaged eyes, and a droop of the shoulders, that seemed to say old age had come upon him in a single night.
10038-8{_}6724{_}The day that followed was pretty dark to both men.
10038-8{_}6725{_}The Boy had to do all the work, except the monotonous, blind, pushing from behind, in whatever direction the Boy dragged the sled.
10038-8{_}6726{_}Now, snow-blindness is not usually dangerous, but it is horribly painful while it lasts.
10038-8{_}6727{_}Your eyes swell up and are stabbed continually by cutting pains; your head seems full of acute neuralgia, and often there is fever and other complications.
10038-8{_}6728{_}The Colonel's was a bad case.
10038-8{_}6729{_}But he was a giant for strength and "sound as a dollar," as the Boy reminded him, "except for this little bother with your eyes, and you're a whole heap better already."
10038-8{_}6730{_}At a very slow rate they plodded along.
10038-8{_}6731{_}They had got into a region where there was no timber; but, as they couldn't camp without a fire, they took an extra rest that day at four o'clock, and regaled themselves on some cold grub.
10038-8{_}6732{_}Then they took up the line of march again.
10038-8{_}6733{_}But they had been going only about half an hour when the Colonel suddenly, without warning, stopped pushing the sled, and stood stock-still on the trail.
10038-8{_}6734{_}The Boy, feeling the removal of the pressure, looked round, went back to him, and found nothing in particular was the matter, but he just thought he wouldn't go any further.
10038-8{_}6735{_}"We can camp here."
10038-8{_}6736{_}"No, we can't," says the Boy; "there isn't a tree in sight."
10038-8{_}6737{_}But the Colonel seemed dazed.
10038-8{_}6738{_}He thought he'd stop anyhow--"right where he was."
10038-8{_}6739{_}"Oh, no," says the Boy, a little frightened; "we'll camp the minute we come to wood."
10038-8{_}6740{_}But the Colonel stood as if rooted.
10038-8{_}6741{_}The Boy took his arm and led him on a few paces to the sled.
10038-8{_}6742{_}"You needn't push hard, you know.
10038-8{_}6743{_}Just keep your hand there so, without looking, you'll know where I'm going."
10038-8{_}6744{_}This was very subtle of the Boy.
10038-8{_}6745{_}For he knew the Colonel was blind as a bat and as sensitive as a woman.
10038-8{_}6746{_}"We'll get through all right yet," he called back, as he stooped to take up the sledrope.
10038-8{_}6747{_}"I bet on Kentucky."
10038-8{_}6748{_}Like a man walking in his sleep, the Colonel followed, now holding on to the sled and unconsciously pulling a little, and when the Boy, very nearly on his last legs, remonstrated, leaning against it, and so urging it a little forward.
10038-8{_}6749{_}Oh, but the wood was far to seek that night!
10038-8{_}6750{_}Concentrated on the two main things--to carry forward his almost intolerable load, and to go the shortest way to the nearest wood--the Boy, by-and-by, forgot to tell his tired nerves to take account of the unequal pressure from behind.
10038-8{_}6751{_}If he felt it--well, the Colonel was a corker; if he didn't feel it--well, the Colonel was just about tuckered out.
10038-8{_}6752{_}It was very late when at last the Boy raised a shout.
10038-8{_}6753{_}Behind the cliff overhanging the river-bed that they were just rounding, there, spread out in the sparkling starlight, as far as he could see, a vast primeval forest.
10038-8{_}6754{_}The Boy bettered his lagging pace.
10038-8{_}6755{_}"Ha!
10038-8{_}6756{_}you haven't seen a wood like this since we left 'Frisco.
10038-8{_}6757{_}It's all right now, Kentucky;" and he bent to his work with a will.
10038-8{_}6758{_}When he got to the edge of the wood, he flung down the rope and turned--to find himself alone.
10038-8{_}6759{_}"Colonel!
10038-8{_}6760{_}Colonel!
10038-8{_}6761{_}Where are you?
10038-8{_}6762{_}_Colonel!_"  He stood in the silence, shivering with a sudden sense of desolation.
10038-8{_}6763{_}He took his bearings, propped a fallen fir sapling aslant by the sled, and, forgetting he was ready to drop, he ran swiftly hack along the way he came.
10038-8{_}6764{_}They had travelled all that afternoon and evening on the river ice, hard as iron, retaining no trace of footprint or of runner possible to verify even in daylight.
10038-8{_}6765{_}The Yukon here was fully three miles wide.
10038-8{_}6766{_}They had meant to hug the right bank, but snow and ice refashion the world and laugh at the trustful geography of men.
10038-8{_}6767{_}A traveller on this trail is not always sure whether he is following the mighty Yukon or some slough equally mighty for a few miles, or whether, in the protracted twilight, he has not wandered off upon some frozen swamp.
10038-8{_}6768{_}On the Boy went in the ghostly starlight, running, stumbling, calling at regular intervals, his voice falling into a melancholy monotony that sounded foreign to himself.
10038-8{_}6769{_}It occurred to him that were he the Colonel he wouldn't recognise it, and he began instead to call "Kentucky!
10038-8{_}6770{_}Ken-tuck-kee!"
10038-8{_}6771{_}sounding those fine barbaric syllables for the first time, most like, in that world of ice and silence.
10038-8{_}6772{_}He stood an instant after his voice died, and listened to the quiet.
10038-8{_}6773{_}Yes, the people were right who said nothing was so hard to bear in this country of hardship--nothing ends by being so ghastly--as the silence.
10038-8{_}6774{_}No bird stirs.
10038-8{_}6775{_}The swift-flashing fish are sealed under ice, the wood creatures gone to their underground sleep.
10038-8{_}6776{_}No whispering of the pointed firs, stiff, snowclotted; no swaying of the scant herbage sheathed in ice or muffled under winter's wide white blanket.
10038-8{_}6777{_}No greater hush can reign in the interstellar spaces than in winter on the Yukon.
10038-8{_}6778{_}"Colonel!"
10038-8{_}6779{_}Silence--like a negation of all puny things, friendship, human life--  "Colonel!"
10038-8{_}6780{_}Silence.
10038-8{_}6781{_}No wonder men went mad up here, when they didn't drown this silence in strong drink.
10038-8{_}6782{_}On and on he ran, till he felt sure he must have passed the Colonel, unless--yes, there were those air-holes in the river ice ...
10038-8{_}6783{_}He felt choked and stopped to breathe.
10038-8{_}6784{_}Should he go back?
10038-8{_}6785{_}It was horrible to turn.
10038-8{_}6786{_}It was like admitting that the man was not to be found--that this was the end.
10038-8{_}6787{_}"Colonel!"
10038-8{_}6788{_}He said to himself that he would go back, and build a fire for a signal, and return; but he ran on farther and farther away from the sled and from the forest.
10038-8{_}6789{_}Was it growing faintly light?
10038-8{_}6790{_}He looked up.
10038-8{_}6791{_}Oh, yes; presently it would be brighter still.
10038-8{_}6792{_}Those streamers of pale light dancing in the North; they would be green and scarlet and orange and purple, and the terrible white world would be illumined as by conflagration.
10038-8{_}6793{_}He stopped again.
10038-8{_}6794{_}That the Colonel should have dropped so far back as this, and the man in front not know--it was incredible.
10038-8{_}6795{_}What was that?
10038-8{_}6796{_}A shadow on the ice.
10038-8{_}6797{_}A frozen hummock?
10038-8{_}6798{_}No, a man.
10038-8{_}6799{_}Was it really....?
10038-8{_}6800{_}Glory hallelujah--it _was!_ But the shadow lay there ghastly still and the Boy's greeting died in his throat.
10038-8{_}6801{_}He had found the Colonel, but he had found him delivered over to that treacherous sleep that seldom knows a waking.
10038-8{_}6802{_}The Boy dropped down beside his friend, and wasn't far off crying.
10038-8{_}6803{_}But it was a tonic to young nerves to see how, like one dead, the man lay there, for all the calling and tugging by the arm.
10038-8{_}6804{_}The Boy rolled the body over, pulled open the things at the neck, and thrust his hand down, till he could feel the heart beating.
10038-8{_}6805{_}He jumped up, got a handful of snow, and rubbed the man's face with it.
10038-8{_}6806{_}At last a feeble protest--an effort to get away from the Boy's rude succour.
10038-8{_}6807{_}"Thank God!
10038-8{_}6808{_}Colonel!
10038-8{_}6809{_}Colonel!
10038-8{_}6810{_}wake up!"
10038-8{_}6811{_}He shook him hard.
10038-8{_}6812{_}But the big man only growled sullenly, and let his leaden weight drop back heavily on the ice.
10038-8{_}6813{_}The Boy got hold of the neck of the Colonel's parki and pulled him frantically along the ice a few yards, and then realised that only the terror of the moment gave him the strength to do that much.
10038-8{_}6814{_}To drag a man of the Colonel's weight all the way to the wood was stark impossibility.
10038-8{_}6815{_}He couldn't get him eighty yards.
10038-8{_}6816{_}If he left him and went for the sled and fuel, the man would be dead by the time he got back.
10038-8{_}6817{_}If he stayed, they would both be frozen in a few hours.
10038-8{_}6818{_}It was pretty horrible.
10038-8{_}6819{_}He felt faint and dizzy.
10038-8{_}6820{_}It occurred to him that he would pray.
10038-8{_}6821{_}He was an agnostic all right, but the Colonel was past praying for himself; and here was his friend--an agnostic--here he was on his knees.
10038-8{_}6822{_}He hadn't prayed since he was a little chap down in the South.
10038-8{_}6823{_}How did the prayers go?
10038-8{_}6824{_}"Our Father"--he looked up at the reddening aurora--"Our Father, who art in heaven--" His eyes fell again on his friend.
10038-8{_}6825{_}He leapt to his feet like a wild animal, and began to go at the Colonel with his fists.
10038-8{_}6826{_}The blows rained thick on the chest of the prostrate man, but he was too well protected to feel more than the shock.
10038-8{_}6827{_}But now they came battering down, under the ear--right, left, as the man turned blindly to avoid them--on the jaw, even on the suffering eyes, and that at last stung the sleeper into something like consciousness.
10038-8{_}6828{_}He struggled to his feet with a roar like a wounded bull, lunging heavily forward as the Boy eluded him, and he would have pounded the young fellow out of existence in no time had he stood his ground.
10038-8{_}6829{_}That was exactly what the Boy didn't mean to do--he was always just a little way on in front; but as the Colonel's half-insane rage cooled, and he slowed down a bit, the Boy was at him again like some imp of Satan.
10038-8{_}6830{_}Sound and lithe and quick-handed as he was, he was no match for the Colonel at his best.
10038-8{_}6831{_}But the Colonel couldn't see well, and his brain was on fire.
10038-8{_}6832{_}He'd kill that young devil, and then he'd lie down and sleep again.
10038-8{_}6833{_}Meanwhile Aurora mounted the high heavens; from a great corona in the zenith all the sky was hung with banners, and the snow was stained as if with blood.
10038-8{_}6834{_}The Boy looked over his shoulder, and saw the huge figure of his friend, bearing down upon him, with his discoloured face rage-distorted, and murder in his tortured eyes.
10038-8{_}6835{_}A moment's sense of the monstrous spectacle fell so poignant upon the Boy, that he felt dimly he must have been full half his life running this race with death, followed by a maniac bent on murder, in a world whose winter was strangely lit with the leaping fires of hell.
10038-8{_}6836{_}At last, on there in front, the cliff!
10038-8{_}6837{_}Below it, the sharp bend in the river, and although he couldn't see it yet, behind the cliff the forest, and a little hand-sled bearing the means of life.
10038-8{_}6838{_}The Colonel was down again, but it wasn't safe to go near him just yet.
10038-8{_}6839{_}The Boy ran on, unpacked the sled, and went, axe in hand, along the margin of the wood.
10038-8{_}6840{_}Never before was a fire made so quickly.
10038-8{_}6841{_}Then, with the flask, back to the Colonel, almost as sound asleep as before.
10038-8{_}6842{_}The Boy never could recall much about the hours that followed.
10038-8{_}6843{_}There was nobody to help, so it must have been he who somehow got the Colonel to the fire, got him to swallow some food, plastered his wounded face over with the carbolic ointment, and got him into bed, for in the morning all this was seen to have been done.
10038-8{_}6844{_}They stayed in camp that day to "rest up," and the Boy shot a rabbit.
10038-8{_}6845{_}The Colonel was coming round; the rest, or the ointment, or the tea-leaf poultice, had been good for snowblindness.
10038-8{_}6846{_}The generous reserve of strength in his magnificent physique was quick to announce itself.
10038-8{_}6847{_}He was still "frightfully bunged up," but "I think we'll push on to-morrow," he said that night, as he sat by the fire smoking before turning in.
10038-8{_}6848{_}"Right you are!"
10038-8{_}6849{_}said the Boy, who was mending the sled-runner.
10038-8{_}6850{_}Neither had referred to that encounter on the river-ice, that had ended in bringing the Colonel where there was succour.
10038-8{_}6851{_}Nothing was said, then or for long after, in the way of deliberate recognition that the Boy had saved his life.
10038-8{_}6852{_}It wasn't necessary; they understood each other.
10038-8{_}6853{_}But in the evening, after the Boy had finished mending the sled, it occurred to him he must also mend the Colonel before they went to bed.
10038-8{_}6854{_}He got out the box of ointment and bespread the strips of torn handkerchief.
10038-8{_}6855{_}"Don't know as I need that to-night," says the Colonel.

10038-8{_}6857{_}But the Boy brought the bandages round to the Colonel's side of the fire.
10038-8{_}6858{_}For an instant they looked at each other by the flickering light, and the Colonel laid his hand on the Boy's arm.
10038-8{_}6859{_}His eyes looked worse for the moment, and began to water.

10038-8{_}6861{_}"What in hell made you think of it?"
10038-8{_}6862{_}"Ask me an easy one," says the Boy.
10038-8{_}6863{_}"But I know what the Jesuit Fathers would say."

10038-8{_}6865{_}Humph!

10038-8{_}6868{_}It flashed over me when I looked back and saw you peltin' after me."

10038-8{_}6874{_}--ANATOLE FRANCE.
10038-8{_}6875{_}An old story now, these days of silent plodding through the driving snow.
10038-8{_}6876{_}But if outward conditions lacked variety, not so their cumulative effect upon poor human nature.
10038-8{_}6877{_}A change was going on in the travellers that will little commend them to the sentimentalist.
10038-8{_}6878{_}"I've come to think a snow-storm's all right to travel in, all right to sleep in," said the Colonel one morning; "but to cook in, eat in, make or break camp in--it's the devil's champion invention."
10038-8{_}6879{_}For three days they had worked like galley-slaves, and yet covered less than ten miles a day.
10038-8{_}6880{_}"And you never get rested," the Colonel went on; "I get up as tired as I go to bed."
10038-8{_}6881{_}Again the Boy only nodded.
10038-8{_}6882{_}His body, if not his temper, had got broken into the trail, but for a talkative person he had in these days strangely little to say.
10038-8{_}6883{_}It became manifest that, in the long run, the Colonel would suffer the most physically; but his young companion, having less patience and more ambition, more sheer untamed vitality in him, would suffer the most in spirit.
10038-8{_}6884{_}Every sense in him was becoming numbed, save the gnawing in his stomach, and that other, even more acute ache, queer compound of fatigue and anger.
10038-8{_}6885{_}These two sensations swallowed up all else, and seemed to grow by what they fed on.
10038-8{_}6886{_}The loaded sled was a nightmare.
10038-8{_}6887{_}It weighed a thousand tons.
10038-8{_}6888{_}The very first afternoon out from Anvik, when in the desperate hauling and tugging that rescued it from a bottomless snow-drift, the lashing slipped, the load loosened, tumbled off, and rolled open, the Colonel stood quite still and swore till his half-frozen blood circulated freely again.
10038-8{_}6889{_}When it came to repacking, he considered in detail the items that made up the intolerable weight, and fell to wondering which of them they could do without.
10038-8{_}6890{_}The second day out from Anvik they had decided that it was absurd, after all, to lug about so much tinware.
10038-8{_}6891{_}They left a little saucepan and the extra kettle at that camp.
10038-8{_}6892{_}The idea, so potent at Anvik, of having a tea-kettle in reserve--well, the notion lost weight, and the kettle seemed to gain.
10038-8{_}6893{_}Two pairs of boots and some flannels marked the next stopping-place.
10038-8{_}6894{_}On the following day, when the Boy's rifle kept slipping and making a brake to hold back the sled, "I reckon you'll have to plant that rifle o' yours in the next big drift," said the Colonel; "one's all we need, anyway."
10038-8{_}6895{_}"One's all you need, and one's all I need," answered the Boy stiffly.
10038-8{_}6896{_}But it wasn't easy to see immediate need for either.
10038-8{_}6897{_}Never was country so bare of game, they thought, not considering how little they hunted, and how more and more every faculty, every sense, was absorbed in the bare going forward.
10038-8{_}6898{_}The next time the Colonel said something about the uselessness of carrying two guns, the Boy flared up: "If you object to guns, leave yours."
10038-8{_}6899{_}This was a new tone for the Boy to use to the Colonel.
10038-8{_}6900{_}"Don't you think we'd better hold on to the best one?"
10038-8{_}6901{_}Now the Boy couldn't deny that the Colonel's was the better, but none the less he had a great affection for his own old 44 Marlin, and the Colonel shouldn't assume that he had the right to dictate.
10038-8{_}6902{_}This attitude of the "wise elder" seemed out of place on the trail.
10038-8{_}6903{_}"A gun's a necessity.
10038-8{_}6904{_}I haven't brought along any whim-whams."
10038-8{_}6905{_}"Who has?"
10038-8{_}6906{_}"Well, it wasn't me that went loadin' up at Anvik with fool thermometers and things."
10038-8{_}6907{_}"Thermometer!
10038-8{_}6908{_}Why, it doesn't weigh--"  "Weighs something, and it's something to pack; frozen half the time, too.
10038-8{_}6909{_}And when it isn't, what's the good of havin' it hammered into us how near we are to freezin' to death."
10038-8{_}6910{_}But it annoyed him to think how very little in argument a thermometer weighed against a rifle.
10038-8{_}6911{_}They said no more that day about lightening the load, but with a double motive they made enormous inroads upon their provisions.
10038-8{_}6912{_}A morning came when the Colonel, packing hurriedly in the biting cold, forgot to shove his pardner's gun into its accustomed place.
10038-8{_}6913{_}The Boy, returning from trail-breaking to the river, kicked at the butt to draw attention to the omission.
10038-8{_}6914{_}The Colonel flung down the end of the ice-coated rope he had lashed the load with, and, "Pack it yourself," says he.
10038-8{_}6915{_}The Boy let the rifle lie.
10038-8{_}6916{_}But all day long he felt the loss of it heavy on his heart, and no reconciling lightness in the sled.
10038-8{_}6917{_}The Colonel began to have qualms about the double rations they were using.
10038-8{_}6918{_}It was only the seventeenth night after turning their backs on the Big Chimney, as the Colonel tipped the pan, pouring out half the boiled beans into his pardner's plate, "That's the last o' the strawberries!
10038-8{_}6919{_}Don't go expectin' any more," says he.
10038-8{_}6920{_}"What!"
10038-8{_}6921{_}ejaculated the Boy, aghast; then quickly, to keep a good face: "You take my life when you do take the beans, whereby I live."
10038-8{_}6922{_}When the Colonel had disposed of his strawberries, "Lord!"
10038-8{_}6923{_}he sighed, trying to rub the stiffness out of his hands over the smoke, "the appetite a fella can raise up here is something terrible.
10038-8{_}6924{_}You eat and eat, and it doesn't seem to make any impression.
10038-8{_}6925{_}You're just as hungry as ever."
10038-8{_}6926{_}_"And the stuff a fella can eat!
10038-8{_}6927{_}"_  The Colonel recalled that speech of the Boy's the very next night, when, after "a hell of a time" getting the fire alight, he was bending forward in that attitude most trying to maintain, holding the frying-pan at long range over the feebly-smoking sticks.
10038-8{_}6928{_}He had to cook, to live on snow-shoes nowadays, for the heavy Colonel had illustrated oftener than the Boy, that going without meant breaking in, floundering, and, finally, having to call for your pardner to haul you out.
10038-8{_}6929{_}This was one of the many uses of a pardner on the trail.
10038-8{_}6930{_}The last time the Colonel had trusted to the treacherous crust he had gone in head foremost, and the Boy, happening to look round, saw only two snow-shoes, bottom side up, moving spasmodically on the surface of the drift.
10038-8{_}6931{_}The Colonel was nearly suffocated by the time he was pulled out, and after that object-lesson he stuck to snow-shoes every hour of the twenty-four, except those spent in the sleeping-bag.
10038-8{_}6932{_}But few things on earth are more exasperating than trying to work mounted on clumsy, long web-feet that keep jarring against, yet holding you off from, the tree you are felling, or the fire you are cooking over.
10038-8{_}6933{_}You are constrained to stand wholly out of natural relation to the thing you are trying to do--the thing you've got to do, if you mean to come out alive.
10038-8{_}6934{_}The Colonel had been through all this time and time again.
10038-8{_}6935{_}But as he squatted on his heels to-night, cursing the foot and a half of snow-shoe that held him away from the sullen fire, straining every muscle to keep the outstretched frying-pan over the best of the blaze, he said to himself that what had got him on the raw was that speech of the Boy's yesterday about the stuff he had to eat.
10038-8{_}6936{_}If the Boy objected to having his rice parboiled in smoked water he was damned unreasonable, that was all.
10038-8{_}6937{_}The culprit reappeared at the edge of the darkening wood.
10038-8{_}6938{_}He came up eagerly, and flung down an armful of fuel for the morning, hoping to find supper ready.
10038-8{_}6939{_}Since it wasn't, he knew that he mustn't stand about and watch the preparations.
10038-8{_}6940{_}By this time he had learned a good deal of the trail-man's unwritten law.
10038-8{_}6941{_}On no account must you hint that the cook is incompetent, or even slow, any more than he may find fault with your moment for calling halt, or with your choice of timber.
10038-8{_}6942{_}So the woodman turned wearily away from the sole spot of brightness in the waste, and went back up the hill in the dark and the cold, to busy himself about his own work, even to spin it out, if necessary, till he should hear the gruff "Grub's ready!"
10038-8{_}6943{_}And when that dinner-gong sounds, don't you dally!
10038-8{_}6944{_}Don't you wait a second.
10038-8{_}6945{_}You may feel uncomfortable if you find yourself twenty minutes late for a dinner in London or New York, but to be five minutes late for dinner on the Winter Trail is to lay up lasting trouble.
10038-8{_}6946{_}By the time the rice and bacon were done, and the flap-jack, still raw in the middle, was burnt to charcoal on both sides, the Colonel's eyes were smarting, in the acrid smoke, and the tears were running down his cheeks.

10038-8{_}7042{_}Now, the Colonel himself had enunciated the law that whenever one of them was ready to sleep the other must come too.
10038-8{_}7043{_}He didn't know it, but it is one of the iron rules of the Winter Trail.
10038-8{_}7044{_}In absence of its enforcement, the later comer brings into the warmed up sleeping-bag not only the chill of his own body, he lets in the bitter wind, and brings along whatever snow and ice is clinging to his boots and clothes.
10038-8{_}7045{_}The melting and warming-up is all to be done again.

10038-8{_}7056{_}You can't move away in a sleeping-bag.
10038-8{_}7057{_}In a city you may be alone, free.

10038-8{_}7065{_}There it went!
10038-8{_}7066{_}in again.
10038-8{_}7067{_}They tugged and hauled, and only dragged the lashing loose, while the sled seemed soldered to the hard-packed middle of the drift.
10038-8{_}7068{_}As they reloaded, the thermometer came to light.
10038-8{_}7069{_}The Colonel threw it out, with never a word.
10038-8{_}7070{_}They had no clothes now but what they stood in, and only one thing on the sled they could have lived without--their money, a packet of trading stores.
10038-8{_}7071{_}But they had thrown away more than they knew.
10038-8{_}7072{_}Day by day, not flannels and boots alone, not merely extra kettle, thermometer and gun went overboard, but some grace of courtesy, some decency of life had been left behind.
10038-8{_}7073{_}About three o'clock of this same day, dim with snow, and dizzy in a hurricane of wind, "We can't go on like this," said the Boy suddenly.
10038-8{_}7074{_}"Wish I knew the way we _could_ go on," returned the Colonel, stopping with an air of utter helplessness, and forcing his rigid hands into his pockets.
10038-8{_}7075{_}The Boy looked at him.

10038-8{_}7077{_}Here was only a big, slouching creature, with ragged beard, smoke-blackened countenance, and eyes that wept continually.

10038-8{_}7080{_}"What's the matter now?"
10038-8{_}7081{_}The Boy was too tired to turn his head round and look back, but he knew that the other man wasn't doing his share.
10038-8{_}7082{_}He remembered that other time when the Colonel had fallen behind.

10038-8{_}7086{_}No.

10038-8{_}7088{_}He was always peggin' out.
10038-8{_}7089{_}Yes, there he was, stoppin' to stroke himself.

10038-8{_}7149{_}*       *       *       *       *  The next morning, when they came to digging the sled out of the last night's snow-drift, the Boy found to his horror that he was weaker--yes, a good deal.
10038-8{_}7150{_}As they went on he kept stumbling.
10038-8{_}7151{_}The Colonel fell every now and then.
10038-8{_}7152{_}Sometimes he would lie still before he could pull himself on his legs again.
10038-8{_}7153{_}In these hours they saw nothing of the grim and splendid waste; nothing of the ranks of snow-laden trees; nothing of sun course or of stars, only the half-yard of dazzling trail in front of them, and --clairvoyant--the little store of flour and bacon that seemed to shrink in the pack while they dragged it on.
10038-8{_}7154{_}Apart from partial snow-blindness, which fell at intervals upon the Colonel, the tiredness of the eyes was like a special sickness upon them both.

10038-8{_}7172{_}Now, one man was content to let the very skin go if he could keep the flesh on his face, and one was little concerned even for that.
10038-8{_}7173{_}Life--life!
10038-8{_}7174{_}To push on and come out alive.

10038-8{_}7183{_}But the realisation would fade.

10038-8{_}7187{_}It was no longer difficult or even shocking to conceive one's partner giving out and falling by the way.

10038-8{_}7189{_}Imagination always pictured the other fellow down, one's self somehow forging ahead.

10038-8{_}7203{_}He found on the height only a cutting wind, and little enlightenment as to the true course.
10038-8{_}7204{_}North and east all nimbus still.
10038-8{_}7205{_}A brace of sun-dogs following the pale God of Day across the narrow field of primrose that bordered the dun-coloured west.
10038-8{_}7206{_}There would be more snow to-morrow, and meanwhile the wind was rising again.

10038-8{_}7212{_}His last clear thought had been an intense anxiety about his snow-shoes as they sailed away, two liberated kites, but as he went on falling, clutching at the air--falling--and felt the alder twigs snap under his hands, he said to himself, "This is death," but calmly, as if it were a small matter compared to losing one's snow-shoes.

10038-8{_}7220{_}That bluff face would be easier to climb up than to climb down, and either was impossible.

10038-8{_}7223{_}It was only this lying helpless, trapped, that was evil.
10038-8{_}7224{_}The endless Trail?

10038-8{_}7226{_}Suddenly the beauty that for days had been veiled shone out.

10038-8{_}7228{_}And he had only just been wakened to it.

10038-8{_}7252{_}It was in no normal state of ordinary waking senses that the work went on--with never a downward look, nor even up, eyes riveted to the patch of snow on which the mittened hands fell as steady and untrembling as steel hammers.

10038-8{_}7562{_}By-and-by, in spite of the limited English of the community, certain facts stood out: that Peetka held the white man in avowed detestation, that he was the leading spirit of the place, that they had all been suffering from a tobacco famine, and that much might be done by a judicious use of Black Jack and Long Green.
10038-8{_}7563{_}The Colonel set forth the magnificent generosity of which he would be capable, could he secure a good Leader.
10038-8{_}7564{_}But Peetka, although he looked at his empty pipe with bitterness, shook his head.
10038-8{_}7565{_}Everybody in the village would profit, the Colonel went on; everybody should have a present if--  Peetka interrupted with a snarl, and flung out low words of contemptuous refusal.
10038-8{_}7566{_}The Leader waked from a brief nap cramped and uneasy, and began to howl in sympathy.
10038-8{_}7567{_}His master stood up, the better to deliver a brutal kick.
10038-8{_}7568{_}This seemed to help the Leader to put up with cramp and confinement, just as one great discomfort will help his betters to forget several little ones.
10038-8{_}7569{_}But the Boy had risen with angry eyes.
10038-8{_}7570{_}Very well, he said impulsively; if he and his pardner couldn't get a third dog (two were very little good) they would not stock fresh meat here.
10038-8{_}7571{_}In vain the Colonel whispered admonition.
10038-8{_}7572{_}No, sir, they would wait till they got to the next village.
10038-8{_}7573{_}"Belly far," said a young hunter, placing ostentatiously in front his brace of grouse.
10038-8{_}7574{_}"We're used to going belly far.
10038-8{_}7575{_}Take all your game away, and go home."
10038-8{_}7576{_}A sorrowful silence fell upon the room.
10038-8{_}7577{_}They sat for some time like that, no one so much as moving, till a voice said, "We want tobacco," and a general murmur of assent arose.
10038-8{_}7578{_}Peetka roused himself, pulled out of his shirt a concave stone and a little woody-looking knot.
10038-8{_}7579{_}The Boy leaned forward to see what it was.
10038-8{_}7580{_}A piece of dried fungus--the kind you sometimes see on the birches up here.
10038-8{_}7581{_}Peetka was hammering a fragment of it into powder, with his heavy clasp-knife, on the concave stone.
10038-8{_}7582{_}He swept the particles into his pipe and applied to one of the fish-selling women for a match, lit up, and lounged back against the Leader, smiling disagreeably at the strangers.
10038-8{_}7583{_}A little laugh at their expense went round the room.
10038-8{_}7584{_}Oh, it wasn't easy to get ahead of Peetka!
10038-8{_}7585{_}But even if he chose to pretend that he didn't want cheechalko tobacco, it was very serious--it was desperate--to see all that Black Jack going on to the next village.
10038-8{_}7586{_}Several of the hitherto silent bucks remonstrated with Peetka--even one of the women dared raise her voice.
10038-8{_}7587{_}She had not been able to go for fish: where was _her_ tobacco and tea?
10038-8{_}7588{_}Peetka burst into voluble defence of his position.
10038-8{_}7589{_}Casting occasional looks of disdain upon the strangers, he addressed most of his remarks to the owner of Red and Spotty.
10038-8{_}7590{_}Although the Colonel could not understand a word, he saw the moment approaching when that person would go back on his bargain.
10038-8{_}7591{_}With uncommon pleasure he could have throttled Peetka.
10038-8{_}7592{_}The Boy, to create a diversion, had begun talking to a young hunter in the front row about "the Long Trail," and, seeing that several others craned and listened, he spoke louder, more slowly, dropping out all unnecessary or unusual words.
10038-8{_}7593{_}Very soon he had gained an audience and Peetka had lost one.
10038-8{_}7594{_}As the stranger went on describing their experiences the whole room listened with an attentiveness that would have been flattering had it been less strongly dashed with unbelief.
10038-8{_}7595{_}From beyond Anvik they had come?
10038-8{_}7596{_}Like that--with no dogs?
10038-8{_}7597{_}What!
10038-8{_}7598{_}From below Koserefsky?
10038-8{_}7599{_}Not really?
10038-8{_}7600{_}Peetka grunted and shook his head.
10038-8{_}7601{_}Did they think the Ingaliks were children?
10038-8{_}7602{_}Without dogs that journey was impossible.
10038-8{_}7603{_}Low whispers and gruff exclamations filled the room.
10038-8{_}7604{_}White men were great liars.
10038-8{_}7605{_}They pretended that in their country the bacon had legs, and could run about, and one had been heard to say he had travelled in a thing like a steamboat, only it could go without water under it--ran over the dry land on strips of iron--ran quicker than any steamer!
10038-8{_}7606{_}Oh, they were awful liars.
10038-8{_}7607{_}But these two, who pretended they'd dragged a sled all the way from Holy Cross, they were the biggest liars of all.
10038-8{_}7608{_}Just let them tell that yarn to Unookuk.
10038-8{_}7609{_}They all laughed at this, and the name ran round the room.
10038-8{_}7610{_}"Who is Unookuk?"
10038-8{_}7611{_}"Him guide."
10038-8{_}7612{_}"Him know."
10038-8{_}7613{_}"Where is him?"
10038-8{_}7614{_}asked the Boy.
10038-8{_}7615{_}"Him sick."
10038-8{_}7616{_}But there was whispering and consultation.
10038-8{_}7617{_}This was evidently a case for the expert.
10038-8{_}7618{_}Two boys ran out, and the native talk went on, unintelligible save for the fact that it centred round Unookuk.
10038-8{_}7619{_}In a few minutes the boys came back with a tall, fine-looking native, about sixty years old, walking lame, and leaning on a stick.
10038-8{_}7620{_}The semicircle opened to admit him.
10038-8{_}7621{_}He limped over to the strangers, and stood looking at them gravely, modestly, but with careful scrutiny.
10038-8{_}7622{_}The Boy held out his hand.
10038-8{_}7623{_}"How do you do?"
10038-8{_}7624{_}"How do you do?"

10038-8{_}7627{_}"Yes.

10038-8{_}7629{_}Peetka said something rude, before the strangers had time to answer, and all the room went into titters.
10038-8{_}7630{_}But Unookuk listened with dignity while the Colonel repeated briefly the story already told.

10038-8{_}7684{_}Kurilla gravely verified these facts.

10038-8{_}7695{_}"Oh, about three weeks ago."
10038-8{_}7696{_}Peetka made remarks in Ingalik.

10038-8{_}7698{_}asked Kurilla, politely cloaking his cross-examination.

10038-8{_}7706{_}asked the Boy.

10038-8{_}7708{_}"Nicholas!"
10038-8{_}7709{_}repeated several others.
10038-8{_}7710{_}It was plain the Pymeut pilot enjoyed a wide repute.
10038-8{_}7711{_}The Boy spoke of the famine and Ol' Chief's illness.
10038-8{_}7712{_}"It is true," said Unookuk gravely, and turning, he added something in Ingalik to the company.
10038-8{_}7713{_}Peetka answered back as surly as ever.
10038-8{_}7714{_}But the Boy went on, telling how the Shaman had cured Ol' Chief, and that turned out to be a surprisingly popular story.
10038-8{_}7715{_}Peetka wouldn't interrupt it, even to curse the Leader for getting up and stretching himself.
10038-8{_}7716{_}When the dog--feeling that for some reason discipline was relaxed--dared to leave his cramped quarters, and come out into the little open space between the white men and the close-packed assembly, the Boy forced himself to go straight on with his story as if he had not observed the liberty the Leader was taking.
10038-8{_}7717{_}When, after standing there an instant, the dog came over and threw himself down at the stranger's feet as if publicly adopting him, the white story-teller dared not meet Peetka's eye.
10038-8{_}7718{_}He was privately most uneasy at the Nigger dog's tactless move, and he hurried on about how Brother Paul caught the Sham√°n, and about the Penitential Journey--told how, long before that, early in the Fall, Nicholas had got lost, making the portage from St. Michael's, and how the white camp had saved him from starvation; how in turn the Pymeuts had pulled the speaker out of a blow-hole; what tremendous friends the Pymeuts were with these particular, very good sort of white men.
10038-8{_}7719{_}Here he seemed to allow by implication for Peetka's prejudice--there were two kinds of pale-face strangers--and on an impulse he drew out Muckluck's medal.
10038-8{_}7720{_}He would have them to know, so highly were these present specimens of the doubtful race regarded by the Pymeuts--such friends were they, that Nicholas' sister had given him this for an offering to Yukon Inua, that the Great Spirit might help them on their way.
10038-8{_}7721{_}He owned himself wrong to have delayed this sacrifice.
10038-8{_}7722{_}He must to-morrow throw it into the first blow-hole he came to--unless indeed... his eye caught Kurilla's.
10038-8{_}7723{_}With the help of his stick the old Guide pulled his big body up on his one stout leg, hobbled nearer and gravely eyed Muckluck's offering as it swung to and fro on its walrus-string over the Leader's head.
10038-8{_}7724{_}The Boy, quite conscious of some subtle change in the hitherto immobile face of the Indian, laid the token in his hand.
10038-8{_}7725{_}Standing there in the centre of the semicircle between the assembly and the dog, Kurilla turned the Great Katharine's medal over, examining it closely, every eye in the room upon him.
10038-8{_}7726{_}When he lifted his head there was a rustle of expectation and a craning forward.
10038-8{_}7727{_}"It is the same."
10038-8{_}7728{_}Kurilla spoke slowly like one half in a dream.
10038-8{_}7729{_}"When I go down river, thirty winter back, with the Great Dall, he try buy this off Nicholas's mother.
10038-8{_}7730{_}She wear it on string red Russian beads.
10038-8{_}7731{_}Oh, it is a thing to remember!"
10038-8{_}7732{_}He nodded his grey head significantly, but he went on with the bare evidence: "When _John J. Healy_ make last trip down this fall--Nicholas pilot you savvy--they let him take his sister, Holy Cross to Pymeut.
10038-8{_}7733{_}I see she wear this round neck."
10038-8{_}7734{_}The weight of the medal carried the raw-hide necklace slipping through his fingers.
10038-8{_}7735{_}Slowly now, with even impulse, the silver disc swung right, swung left, like the pendulum of a clock.
10038-8{_}7736{_}Even the Nigger dog seemed hypnotised, following the dim shine of the tarnished token.
10038-8{_}7737{_}"I say Nicholas's sister: 'It is thirty winters I see that silver picture first; I give you two dolla for him.'
10038-8{_}7738{_}She say 'No.'
10038-8{_}7739{_}I say, 'Gi' fi' dolla.'
10038-8{_}7740{_}'No.'
10038-8{_}7741{_}I sit and think far back--thirty winters back.
10038-8{_}7742{_}'I gi' ten dolla,' I say.
10038-8{_}7743{_}She say, 'I no sell; no--not for a hunner'--but she _give_ it him!
10038-8{_}7744{_}for to make Yukon Inua to let him go safe.
10038-8{_}7745{_}Hein?
10038-8{_}7746{_}Savvy?"
10038-8{_}7747{_}And lapsing into Ingalik, he endorsed this credential not to be denied.
10038-8{_}7748{_}"It is true," he wound up in English.
10038-8{_}7749{_}The "Autocratrix Russorum" was solemnly handed back.
10038-8{_}7750{_}"You have make a brave journey.
10038-8{_}7751{_}It is I who unnerstan'--I, too, when I am young, I go with Dall on the Long Trail.
10038-8{_}7752{_}_We had dogs._" All the while, from all about the Leader's owner, and out of every corner of the crowded room, had come a spirited punctuation of Kurilla's speech--nods and grunts.
10038-8{_}7753{_}"Yes, perhaps _these_ white men deserved dogs--even Peetka's!"
10038-8{_}7754{_}Kurilla limped back to his place, but turned to the Ingaliks before he sat down, and bending painfully over his stick, "Not Kurilla," he said, as though speaking of one absent--"not _Dall_ make so great journey, no dogs.
10038-8{_}7755{_}Kurilla?
10038-8{_}7756{_}Best guide in Yukon forty year.
10038-8{_}7757{_}Kurilla say: 'Must have dogs--men like that!'"

10038-8{_}7759{_}"Shake!"
10038-8{_}7760{_}says he.
