10038-8{_}7762{_}The general murmur was arrested by a movement from Peetka--he took his pipe out of his mouth and says he, handsomely:  "No liars.
10038-8{_}7763{_}Sell dog," adding, with regretful eye on the apostate Leader, "Him bully dog!"
10038-8{_}7764{_}And that was how the tobacco famine ended, and how the white men got their team.
10038-8{_}7765{_}CHAPTER XV  THE ESQUIMAUX HORSE    "Plus je connais les hommes, plus j'aime les chiens."
10038-8{_}7766{_}It doesn't look hard to drive a dog-team, but just you try it.
10038-8{_}7767{_}In moments of passion, the first few days after their acquisition, the Colonel and the Boy wondered why they had complicated a sufficiently difficult journey by adding to other cares a load of fish and three fiends.
10038-8{_}7768{_}"Think how well they went for Peetka."
10038-8{_}7769{_}"Oh yes; part o' their cussedness.
10038-8{_}7770{_}They know we're green hands, and they mean to make it lively."
10038-8{_}7771{_}Well, they did.
10038-8{_}7772{_}They sat on their haunches in the snow, and grinned at the whip-crackings and futile "Mush, mush!"
10038-8{_}7773{_}of the Colonel.
10038-8{_}7774{_}They snapped at the Boy and made sharp turns, tying him up in the traces and tumbling him into the snow.
10038-8{_}7775{_}They howled all night long, except during a blessed interval of quiet while they ate their seal-skin harness.
10038-8{_}7776{_}But man is the wiliest of the animals, and the one who profits by experience.
10038-8{_}7777{_}In the end, the Boy became a capital driver; the dogs came to know he "meant business," and settled into submission.
10038-8{_}7778{_}"Nig," as he called the bully dog for short, turned out "the best leader in the Yukon."
10038-8{_}7779{_}They were much nearer Kaltag than they had realised, arriving after only two hours' struggle with the dogs at the big Indian village on the left bank of the river.
10038-8{_}7780{_}But their first appearance here was clouded by Nig's proposal to slay all the dogs in sight.
10038-8{_}7781{_}He was no sooner unharnessed than he undertook the congenial job.
10038-8{_}7782{_}It looked for a few minutes as if Peetka's bully dog would chew up the entire canine population, and then lie down and die of his own wounds.
10038-8{_}7783{_}But the Kaltags understood the genus Siwash better than the white man, and took the tumult calmly.
10038-8{_}7784{_}It turned out that Nig was not so much bloodthirsty as "bloody-proud"--one of those high souls for ever concerned about supremacy.
10038-8{_}7785{_}His first social act, on catching sight of his fellow, was to howl defiance at him.
10038-8{_}7786{_}And even after they have fought it out and come to some sort of understanding, the first happy thought of your born Leader on awakening is to proclaim himself boss of the camp.
10038-8{_}7787{_}No sooner has he published this conviction of high calling than he is set upon by the others, punishes them soundly, or is himself vanquished and driven off.
10038-8{_}7788{_}Whereupon he sits on his haunches in the snow, and, with his pointed nose turned skyward, howls uninterruptedly for an hour or two, when all is forgiven and forgotten--till the next time.
10038-8{_}7789{_}Order being restored, the travellers got new harness for the dogs, new boots for themselves, and set out for the white trading post, thirty miles above.
10038-8{_}7790{_}Here, having at last come into the region of settlements, they agreed never again to overtax the dogs.
10038-8{_}7791{_}They "travelled light" out of Nulato towards the Koyukuk.
10038-8{_}7792{_}The dogs simply flew over those last miles.
10038-8{_}7793{_}It was glorious going on a trail like glass.
10038-8{_}7794{_}They had broken the back of the journey now, and could well afford, they thought, to halt an hour or two on the island at the junction of the two great rivers, stake out a trading post, and treat themselves to town lots.
10038-8{_}7795{_}Why town lots, in Heaven's name!
10038-8{_}7796{_}when they were bound for Min√≥ok, and after that the Klondyke, hundreds of miles away?
10038-8{_}7797{_}Well, partly out of mere gaiety of heart, and partly, the Colonel would have told you gravely, that in this country you never know when you have a good thing.
10038-8{_}7798{_}They had left the one white layman at Nulato seething with excitement over an Indian's report of still another rich strike up yonder on the Koyukuk, and this point, where they were solemnly staking out a new post, the Nulato Agent had said, was "dead sure to be a great centre."
10038-8{_}7799{_}That almost unknown region bordering the great tributary of the Yukon, haunt of the fiercest of all the Indians of the North, was to be finally conquered by the white man.
10038-8{_}7800{_}It had been left practically unexplored ever since the days when the bloodthirsty Koyukons came down out of their fastnesses and perpetrated the great Nulato massacre, doing to death with ghastly barbarity every man, woman, and child at the post, Russian or Indian, except Kurilla, not sparing the unlucky Captain Barnard or his English escort, newly arrived here in their search for the lost Sir John Franklin.
10038-8{_}7801{_}But the tables were turned now, and the white man was on the trail of the Indian.
10038-8{_}7802{_}While the Colonel and the Boy were staking out this future stronghold of trade and civilisation it came on to snow; but "Can't last this time o' year," the Colonel consoled himself, and thanked God "the big, unending snows are over for this season."
10038-8{_}7803{_}So they pushed on.
10038-8{_}7804{_}But the Colonel seemed to have thanked God prematurely.
10038-8{_}7805{_}Down the snow drifted, soft, sticky, unending.
10038-8{_}7806{_}The evening was cloudy, and the snow increased the dimness overhead as well as the heaviness under foot.
10038-8{_}7807{_}They never knew just where it was in the hours between dusk and dark that they lost the trail.
10038-8{_}7808{_}The Boy believed it was at a certain steep incline that Nig did his best to rush down.
10038-8{_}7809{_}"I thought he was at his tricks," said the Boy ruefully some hours after.
10038-8{_}7810{_}"I believe I'm an ass, and Nig is a gentleman and a scholar.

10038-8{_}7820{_}The odd thing about the Boy was that it was only with these Indian curs--Nig in particular, who wasn't the Boy's dog at all--only with these brute-beasts had he seemed to recover something of that buoyancy and ridiculous youngness that had first drawn the Colonel to him on the voyage up from 'Frisco.

10038-8{_}7823{_}It was, perhaps, this that the Colonel disliked most of all.
10038-8{_}7824{_}Whether the U.S.
10038-8{_}7825{_}Agent at Nulato was justified or not in saying all the region hereabouts was populous in the summer with Indian camps, the native winter settlements, the half-buried ighloo, or the rude log-hut, where, for a little tea, tobacco, or sugar, you could get as much fish as you could carry, these welcome, if malodorous, places seemed, since they lost the trail, to have vanished off the face of the earth.
10038-8{_}7826{_}No question of the men sharing the dogs' fish, but of the dogs sharing the men's bacon and meal.

10038-8{_}7828{_}The next afternoon it stopped snowing and cleared, intensely cold, and that was the evening the Boy nearly cried for joy when, lifting up his eyes, he saw, a good way off, perched on the river bank, the huts and high caches of an Indian village etched black against a wintry sunset--a fine picture in any eye, but meaning more than beauty to the driver of hungry dogs.

10038-8{_}8048{_}It was short work getting down to the village.
10038-8{_}8049{_}They had one king salmon and two white fish from the first Indian they saw, who wanted hootch for them, and got only tabak.
10038-8{_}8050{_}In the biggest of the huts, nearly full of men, women, and children, coughing, sickly-looking, dejected, the natives made room for the strangers.
10038-8{_}8051{_}When the white men had supped they handed over the remains of their meal (as is expected) to the head of the house.
10038-8{_}8052{_}This and a few matches or a little tobacco on parting, is all he looks for in return for shelter, room for beds on the floor, snow-water laboriously melted, use of the fire, and as much wood as they like to burn, even if it is a barren place, and fuel is the precious far-travelled "drift."
10038-8{_}8053{_}It is curious to see how soon travellers get past that first cheeckalko feeling that it is a little "nervy," as the Boy had said, to walk into another man's house uninvited, an absolute stranger, and take possession of everything you want without so much as "by your leave."
10038-8{_}8054{_}You soon learn it is the Siwash[*] custom.
10038-8{_}8055{_}[Footnote: Siwash, corruption of French-Canadian _sauvage_, applied all over the North to the natives, their possessions and their customs.]
10038-8{_}8056{_}Nothing would have seemed stranger now, or more inhuman, than the civilized point of view.
10038-8{_}8057{_}The Indians trailed out one by one, all except the old buck to whom the hut belonged.
10038-8{_}8058{_}He hung about for a bit till he was satisfied the travellers had no hootch, not even a little for the head of the house, and yet they seemed to be fairly decent fellows.
10038-8{_}8059{_}Then he rolls up his blankets, for there is a premium on sleeping-space, and goes out, with never a notion that he is doing more than any man would, anywhere in the world, to find a place in some neighbour's hut to pass the night.
10038-8{_}8060{_}He leaves the two strangers, as Indian hospitality ordains, to the warmest places in the best hut, with two young squaws, one old one, and five children, all sleeping together on the floor, as a matter of course.
10038-8{_}8061{_}The Colonel and the Boy had flung themselves down on top of their sleeping-bag, fed and warmed and comforted.
10038-8{_}8062{_}Only the old squaw was still up.
10038-8{_}8063{_}She had been looking over the travellers' boots and "mitts," and now, without a word or even a look being exchanged upon the subject, she sat there in the corner, by the dim, seal-oil light, sewing on new thongs, patching up holes, and making the strange men tidy--men she had never seen before and would never see again.
10038-8{_}8064{_}And this, no tribute to the Colonel's generosity or the youth and friendly manners of the Boy.
10038-8{_}8065{_}They knew the old squaw would have done just the same had the mucklucks and the mitts belonged to "the tramp of the Yukon," with nothing to barter and not a cent in his pocket.
10038-8{_}8066{_}This, again, is a Siwash custom.

10038-8{_}8068{_}The children coughed in their sleep.

10038-8{_}8354{_}Having disposed of their letters, the miners crowded round the courier to hear how the black business ended--matter of special interest to Min√≥ok, for the population here was composed chiefly of men who, by the Canadian route, had managed to get to Dawson in the autumn, in the early days of the famine scare, and who, after someone's panic-proposal to raid the great Stores, were given free passage down the river on the last two steamers to run.
10038-8{_}8355{_}When the ice stopped them (one party at Circle, the other at Fort Yukon), they had held up the supply boats and helped themselves under the noses of Captain Ray and Lieutenant Richardson, U. S. A.
10038-8{_}8356{_}"Yes, sir," McGinty had explained, "we Min√≥ok boys was all in that picnic.
10038-8{_}8357{_}But we give our bond to pay up at mid-summer, and after the fun was over we dropped down here."
10038-8{_}8358{_}He pushed nearer to Windy to hear how it had fared with the men who had stayed behind in the Klondyke--how the excitement flamed and menaced; how Agent Hansen of the Alaska Commercial Company, greatest of the importers of provisions and Arctic equipment, rushed about, half crazy, making speeches all along the Dawson River front, urging the men to fly for their lives, back to the States or up to Circle, before the ice stopped moving!
10038-8{_}8359{_}But too many of these men had put everything they had on earth into getting here; too many had abandoned costly outfits on the awful Pass, or in the boiling eddies of the White Horse Rapids, paying any price in money or in pain to get to the goldfields before navigation closed.
10038-8{_}8360{_}And now!

10038-8{_}8365{_}All very well for Hansen to try to relieve the congestion at the Klondyke--the poor devils knew that to go either way, up or down, as late as this meant death.
10038-8{_}8366{_}Then it was whispered how Captain Constantine of the Mounted Police was getting ready to drive every man out of the Klondyke, at the point of the bayonet, who couldn't show a thousand pounds of provisions.

10038-8{_}8678{_}They found a place even more ragged and desolate than McGinty's, where smoke was rising sullenly from underground fires and the smell of burning wood filled the air, the ground turned up and dotted at intervals with piles of frozen gravel that had been hoisted from the shafts by windlass, forlorn little cabins and tents scattered indiscriminately, a vast number of empty bottles and cans sown broadcast, and, early as it was, a line of sluices upon Salaman's claim.
10038-8{_}8679{_}They had heard a great deal about the dark, keen-looking young Oregon lawyer, for Salaman was the most envied man in Min√≥ok.
10038-8{_}8680{_}"Come over to my dump and get some nuggets," says Mr. Salaman, as in other parts of the world a man will say, "Come into the smoking-room and have a cigar."
10038-8{_}8681{_}The snow was melted from the top of Salaman's dump, and his guests had no difficulty in picking several rough little bits of gold out of the thawing gravel.
10038-8{_}8682{_}It was an exhilarating occupation.
10038-8{_}8683{_}"Come down my shaft and see my cross-cuts"; and they followed him.

10038-8{_}8686{_}When he had got his guests thoroughly warmed up:  "Yes, I took out several thousand last fall, and I'll have twenty thousand more out of my first summer clean-up."

10038-8{_}8827{_}CHAPTER XVII  THE GREAT STAMPEDE  "Die Menchen suchen und suchen, wollen immer was Besseres finden.... Gott geb' ihnen nur Geduld!"

10038-8{_}9106{_}"No," and his absent smile seemed to remove him leagues away.
10038-8{_}9107{_}"No, not here."
10038-8{_}9108{_}"I could a' told you----" she began savagely.
10038-8{_}9109{_}"I don't know for certain whether any--what you call good women come up here, but I'm dead sure none stay."
10038-8{_}9110{_}"When do you leave for home, Maudie?"
10038-8{_}9111{_}he said gently.
10038-8{_}9112{_}But at the flattering implication the oddest thing happened.
10038-8{_}9113{_}As she stood there, with her fists full of gold, Maudie's eyes filled.
10038-8{_}9114{_}She turned abruptly and went out.
10038-8{_}9115{_}The crowd began to melt away.
10038-8{_}9116{_}In half an hour only those remained who had more hootch than they could carry off the premises.
10038-8{_}9117{_}They made themselves comfortable on the floor, near the stove, and the greatest night Min√≥ok had known was ended.
10038-8{_}9118{_}CHAPTER XVIII  A MINERS' MEETING  "Leiden oder triumphiren Hammer oder Amboss sein."--Goethe.
10038-8{_}9119{_}In a good-sized cabin, owned by Bonsor, down near the A. C., Judge Corey was administering Miners' Law.
10038-8{_}9120{_}The chief magistrate was already a familiar figure, standing on his dump at Little Min√≥ok, speculatively chewing and discussing "glayshal action," but most of the time at the Gold Nugget, chewing still, and discussing more guardedly the action some Min√≥ok man was threatening to bring against another.
10038-8{_}9121{_}You may treat a glacier cavalierly, but Miners' Law is a serious matter.
10038-8{_}9122{_}Corey was sitting before a deal table, littered with papers strewn round a central bottle of ink, in which a steel pen stuck upright.
10038-8{_}9123{_}The Judge wore his usual dilapidated business suit of brown cheviot that had once been snuff-coloured and was now a streaky drab.
10038-8{_}9124{_}On his feet, stretched out under the magisterial table till they joined the jury, a pair of moccasins; on his grizzled head a cowboy hat, set well back.
10038-8{_}9125{_}He could spit farther than any man in Min√≥ok, and by the same token was a better shot.
10038-8{_}9126{_}They had unanimously elected him Judge.
10038-8{_}9127{_}The first-comers had taken possession of the chairs and wooden stools round the stove.
10038-8{_}9128{_}All the later arrivals, including Keith and his friends, sat on the floor.
10038-8{_}9129{_}"There's a good many here."
10038-8{_}9130{_}"They'll keep comin' as long as a lean man can scrouge in."
10038-8{_}9131{_}"Yes," said Keith, "everybody's got to come, even if it's only the usual row between pardners, who want to part and can't agree about dividing the outfit."
10038-8{_}9132{_}"Got to come?"
10038-8{_}9133{_}Keith laughed.
10038-8{_}9134{_}"That's the way everybody feels.
10038-8{_}9135{_}There'll be a debate and a chance to cast a vote.
10038-8{_}9136{_}Isn't your true-born American always itching to hold a meeting about something?"
10038-8{_}9137{_}"Don't know about that," said McGinty, "but I do know there's more things happens in a minute to make a man mad in Alaska, than happens in a year anywhere else."
10038-8{_}9138{_}And his sentiment was loudly applauded.
10038-8{_}9139{_}The plaintiff had scored a hit.
10038-8{_}9140{_}"I don't know but two partnerships," the ex-Governor was saying, "of all those on my ship and on the Muckluck and the May West--just two, that have stood the Alaska strain.
10038-8{_}9141{_}Everyone that didn't break on the boats, or in camp, went to smash on the trail."
10038-8{_}9142{_}They all admitted that the trail was the final test.
10038-8{_}9143{_}While they smoked and spat into or at the stove, and told trail yarns, the chief magistrate arranged papers, conferred with the clerk and another man, wrinkled deeply his leathery forehead, consulted his Waterbury, and shot tobacco-juice under the table.
10038-8{_}9144{_}"Another reason everybody comes," whispered Keith, "is because the side that wins always takes the town up to the Nugget and treats to hootch.
10038-8{_}9145{_}Whenever you see eighty or ninety more drunks than usual, you know there's either been a stampede or else justice has been administered."
10038-8{_}9146{_}"Ain't Bonsor late?"
10038-8{_}9147{_}asked someone.
10038-8{_}9148{_}"No, it's a quarter of."
10038-8{_}9149{_}"Why do they want Bonsor?"
10038-8{_}9150{_}"His case on the docket--McGinty v. Burt Bonsor, proprietor of the Gold Nugget."
10038-8{_}9151{_}"If they got a row on----"  "If they got a row?
10038-8{_}9152{_}Course they got a row.
10038-8{_}9153{_}Weren't they pardners?"
10038-8{_}9154{_}"But McGinty spends all his time at the Gold Nugget."
10038-8{_}9155{_}"Well, where would he spend it?"
10038-8{_}9156{_}"A Miners' Meetin's a pretty poor machine," McGinty was saying to the ex-Governor, "but it's the best we got."
10038-8{_}9157{_}"----in a country bigger than several of the nations of Europe put together," responded that gentleman, with much public spirit.
10038-8{_}9158{_}"A Great Country!"
10038-8{_}9159{_}"Right!"
10038-8{_}9160{_}"You bet!"
10038-8{_}9161{_}"----a country that's paid for its purchase over and over again, even before we discovered gold here."
10038-8{_}9162{_}"Did she?
10038-8{_}9163{_}Good old 'laska."
10038-8{_}9164{_}"----and the worst treated part o' the Union."
10038-8{_}9165{_}"That's so."
10038-8{_}9166{_}"After this, when I read about Russian corruption and Chinese cruelty, I'll remember the way Uncle Sam treats the natives up----"  "----and us, b'gosh!
10038-8{_}9167{_}White men that are openin' up this great, rich country fur Uncle Sam----"  "----with no proper courts--no Government protection--no help--no justice--no nothin'."
10038-8{_}9168{_}"Yer forgittin' them reindeer!"
10038-8{_}9169{_}And the court-room rang with derisive laughter.
10038-8{_}9170{_}"Congress started that there Relief Expedition all right," the josher went on, "only them blamed reindeer had got the feed habit, and when they'd et up everything in sight they set down on the Dalton Trail--and there they're settin' yit, just like they was Congress.
10038-8{_}9171{_}But I don't like to hear no feller talkin' agin' the Gover'ment."
10038-8{_}9172{_}"Yes, it's all very funny," said McGinty gloomily, "but think o' the fix a feller's in wot's had a wrong done him in the fall, and knows justice is thousands o' miles away, and he can't even go after her for eight months; and in them eight months the feller wot robbed him has et up the money, or worked out the claim, and gone dead-broke."
10038-8{_}9173{_}"No, sir!
10038-8{_}9174{_}we don't wait, and we don't go trav'lin'.
10038-8{_}9175{_}We stay at home and call a meetin'."
10038-8{_}9176{_}The door opened, and Bonsor and the bar-tender, with great difficulty, forced their way in.
10038-8{_}9177{_}They stood flattened against the wall.
10038-8{_}9178{_}During the diversion McGinty was growling disdainfully, "Rubbidge!"
10038-8{_}9179{_}"Rubbidge?
10038-8{_}9180{_}Reckon it's pretty serious rubbidge."
10038-8{_}9181{_}"Did you ever know a Miners' Meetin' to make a decision that didn't become law, with the whole community ready to enforce it if necessary?
10038-8{_}9182{_}Rubbidge!

10038-8{_}9187{_}This tribunal's final."
10038-8{_}9188{_}"I ain't disputin' that it's final.

10038-8{_}9198{_}repeated a Circle City man.

10038-8{_}9202{_}McGinty looked at him.
10038-8{_}9203{_}Was this a possible adherent?

10038-8{_}9206{_}"Why, 'fore this yere town was organised, when we hadn't got no Court of Arbitration to fix a boundary, or even to hang a thief, we had our 'main Push,' just like we was 'Frisco."
10038-8{_}9207{_}He lowered his voice, and leaned towards his Circle friend.

10038-8{_}9209{_}"What about the other?"

10038-8{_}9213{_}"Oh, Bonsor, over there, he lit out on a stampede 'bout Christmas, and while he was gone a feller by the name o' Lawrence quit the game.
10038-8{_}9214{_}Fanned out one night at the Gold Nugget.

10038-8{_}9217{_}There was unseemly laughter behind the stove-pipe.

10038-8{_}9228{_}"An' McGinty weakens," laughed the mocker behind the stove-pipe.

10038-8{_}9230{_}"Mino√≥k doesn't mind arbitrating," says Keith low to the Colonel, "but there isn't a man in camp that would give five cents for the interest of the heirs of Lawrence in that fifteen hundred dollars."
10038-8{_}9231{_}A hammering on the clerk's little table announced that it was seven p.m.
10038-8{_}9232{_}The Court then called for the complaint filed by McGinty v. Bonsor, the first case on the docket.
10038-8{_}9233{_}The clerk had just risen when the door was flung open, and hatless, coatless, face aflame, Maudie stood among the miners.
10038-8{_}9234{_}"Boys!"
10038-8{_}9235{_}said she, on the top of a scream, "I been robbed."
10038-8{_}9236{_}"Hey?"
10038-8{_}9237{_}"Robbed?"
10038-8{_}9238{_}"Golly!"

10038-8{_}9240{_}They spoke all together.
10038-8{_}9241{_}Everybody had jumped up.
10038-8{_}9242{_}"While we was on that stampede yesterday, somebody found my--all my----" She choked, and her eyes filled.
10038-8{_}9243{_}"Boys!
10038-8{_}9244{_}my nuggets, my dust, my dollars--they're gone!"

10038-8{_}9248{_}"Mean shame."
10038-8{_}9249{_}"Dirt mean."

10038-8{_}9251{_}"An' when we do, we'll hang him on the cottonwood."

10038-8{_}9253{_}she screamed hysterically, and then fell into weak crying.
10038-8{_}9254{_}"Can't think who could have been such a skunk."

10038-8{_}9256{_}persisted the Judge.
10038-8{_}9257{_}"How do I know?"
10038-8{_}9258{_}she retorted angrily.
10038-8{_}9259{_}"I suspect everybody till--till I know."
10038-8{_}9260{_}She clenched her hands.
10038-8{_}9261{_}That a thief should be "operating" in Mino√≥k on somebody who wasn't dead yet, was a matter that came home to the business and the bosoms of all the men in the camp.
10038-8{_}9262{_}In the midst of the babel of speculation and excitement, Maudie, still crying and talking incoherently about skunks, opened the door.
10038-8{_}9263{_}The men crowded after her.
10038-8{_}9264{_}Nobody suggested it, but the entire Miners' Meeting with one accord adjourned to the scene of the crime.
10038-8{_}9265{_}Only a portion could be accommodated under Maudie's roof, but the rest crowded in front of her door or went and examined the window.
10038-8{_}9266{_}Maudie's log-cabin was a cheerful place, its one room, neatly kept, lined throughout with red and white drill, hung with marten and fox, carpeted with wolf and caribou.
10038-8{_}9267{_}The single sign of disorder was that the bed was pulled out a little from its place in the angle of the wall above the patent condenser stove.
10038-8{_}9268{_}Behind the oil-tank, where the patent condensation of oil into gas went on, tiers of shelves, enamelled pots and pans ranged below, dishes and glasses above.
10038-8{_}9269{_}On the very top, like a frieze, gaily labelled ranks of "tinned goods."
10038-8{_}9270{_}On the table under the window a pair of gold scales.
10038-8{_}9271{_}A fire burned in the stove.
10038-8{_}9272{_}The long-lingering sunlight poured through the "turkey-red" that she had tacked up for a half-curtain, and over this, one saw the slouch-hats and fur caps of the outside crowd.
10038-8{_}9273{_}Clutching Judge Corey by the arm, Maudie pulled him after her into the narrow space behind the head-board and the wall.
10038-8{_}9274{_}"It was here--see?"

10038-8{_}9279{_}"And way in, underneath, I had this box.
10038-8{_}9280{_}I always set it on a flat stone."
10038-8{_}9281{_}She spoke as if this oversight were the thief's chief crime.

10038-8{_}9286{_}"Boys!"

10038-8{_}9289{_}it was full."

10038-8{_}9623{_}CHAPTER XIX  THE ICE GOES OUT  "I am apart of all that I have seen."
10038-8{_}9624{_}It had been thawing and freezing, freezing and thawing, for so long that men lost account of the advance of a summer coming, with such balked, uncertain steps.
10038-8{_}9625{_}Indeed, the weather variations had for several weeks been so great that no journey, not the smallest, could be calculated with any assurance.
10038-8{_}9626{_}The last men to reach Mino√≥k were two who had made a hunting and prospecting trip to an outlying district.
10038-8{_}9627{_}They had gone there in six days, and were nineteen in returning.
10038-8{_}9628{_}The slush was waist-deep in the gulches.
10038-8{_}9629{_}On the benches, in the snow, holes appeared, as though red-hot stones had been thrown upon the surface.
10038-8{_}9630{_}The little settlement by the mouth of the Mino√≥k sat insecurely on the boggy hillside, and its inhabitants waded knee-deep in soaking tundra moss and mire.
10038-8{_}9631{_}And now, down on the Never-Know-What, water was beginning to run on the marginal ice.
10038-8{_}9632{_}Up on the mountains the drifted snow was honey-combed.
10038-8{_}9633{_}Whole fields of it gave way and sunk a foot under any adventurous shoe.
10038-8{_}9634{_}But although these changes had been wrought slowly, with backsets of bitter nights, when everything was frozen hard as flint, the illusion was general that summer came in with a bound.
10038-8{_}9635{_}On the 9th of May, Mino√≥k went to bed in winter, and woke to find the snow almost gone under the last nineteen hours of hot, unwinking sunshine, and the first geese winging their way up the valley--sight to stir men's hearts.
10038-8{_}9636{_}Stranger still, the eight months' Arctic silence broken suddenly by a thousand voices.
10038-8{_}9637{_}Under every snow-bank a summer murmur, very faint at first, but hourly louder--the sound of falling water softly singing over all the land.
10038-8{_}9638{_}As silence had been the distinguishing feature of the winter, so was noise the sign of the spring.
10038-8{_}9639{_}No ear so dull but now was full of it.
10038-8{_}9640{_}All the brooks on all the hills, tinkling, tumbling, babbling of some great and universal joy, all the streams of all the gulches joining with every little rill to find the old way, or to carve a new, back to the Father of Waters.
10038-8{_}9641{_}And the strange thing had happened on the Yukon.
10038-8{_}9642{_}The shore-edges of the ice seemed sunken, and the water ran yet deeper there.
10038-8{_}9643{_}But of a certainty the middle part had risen!
10038-8{_}9644{_}The cheechalkos thought it an optical illusion.
10038-8{_}9645{_}But old Brandt from Forty-Mile had seen the ice go out for two-and-twenty years, and he said it went out always so--"humps his back, an' gits up gits, and when he's a gitten', jest look out!"
10038-8{_}9646{_}Those who, in spite of warning, ventured in hip-boots down on the Never-Know-What, found that, in places, the under side of the ice was worn nearly through.
10038-8{_}9647{_}If you bent your head and listened, you could plainly hear that greater music of the river running underneath, low as yet, but deep, and strangely stirring--dominating in the hearer's ears all the clear, high clamour from gulch and hill.
10038-8{_}9648{_}In some men's hearts the ice "went out" at the sound, and the melting welled up in their eyes.
10038-8{_}9649{_}Summer and liberty were very near.

10038-8{_}9657{_}Not at Min√≥ok alone: at every wood camp, mining town and mission, at every white post and Indian village, all along the Yukon, groups were gathered waiting the great moment of the year.
10038-8{_}9658{_}No one had ever heard of the ice breaking up before the 11th of May or later than the 28th.
10038-8{_}9659{_}And yet men had begun to keep a hopeful eye on the river from the 10th of April, when a white ptarmigan was reported wearing a collar of dark-brown feathers, and his wings tipped brown.
10038-8{_}9660{_}That was a month ago, and the great moment could not possibly be far now.
10038-8{_}9661{_}The first thing everybody did on getting up, and the last thing everybody did on going to bed, was to look at the river.
10038-8{_}9662{_}It was not easy to go to bed; and even if you got so far it was not easy to sleep.
10038-8{_}9663{_}The sun poured into the cabins by night as well as by day, and there was nothing to divide one part of the twenty-four hours from another.
10038-8{_}9664{_}You slept when you were too tired to watch the river.

10038-8{_}9666{_}Through all your waking hours you kept an eye on the window overlooking the river.
10038-8{_}9667{_}In your bed you listened for that ancient Yukon cry, "The ice is going out!"
10038-8{_}9668{_}For ages it had meant to the timid: Beware the fury of the shattered ice-fields; beware the caprice of the flood.
10038-8{_}9669{_}Watch!
10038-8{_}9670{_}lest many lives go out with the ice as aforetime.
10038-8{_}9671{_}And for ages to the stout-hearted it had meant: Make ready the kyaks and the birch canoes; see that tackle and traps are strong--for plenty or famine wait upon the hour.
10038-8{_}9672{_}As the white men waited for boats to-day, the men of the older time had waited for the salmon--for those first impatient adventurers that would force their way under the very ice-jam, tenderest and best of the season's catch, as eager to prosecute that journey from the ocean to the Klondyke as if they had been men marching after the gold boom.
10038-8{_}9673{_}No one could settle to anything.

10038-8{_}9676{_}It was by fits and starts that they even drank deeper or played for higher stakes.

10038-8{_}10320{_}CHAPTER XX  THE KLONDYKE  "Poverty is an odious calling."
10038-8{_}10321{_}--Burton's Anatomy of Melancholy.
10038-8{_}10322{_}On Monday morning, the 6th of June, they crossed the British line; but it was not till Wednesday, the 8th, at four in the afternoon, just ten months after leaving San Francisco, that the Oklahoma's passengers saw between the volcanic hills on the right bank of the Yukon a stretch of boggy tundra, whereon hundreds of tents gleamed, pink and saffron.
10038-8{_}10323{_}Just beyond the bold wooded height, wearing the deep scar of a landslide on its breast, just round that bend, the Klondyke river joins the Yukon--for this is Dawson, headquarters of the richest Placer Diggings the world has seen, yet wearing more the air of a great army encampment.
10038-8{_}10324{_}For two miles the river-bank shines with sunlit canvas--tents, tents everywhere, as far as eye can see, a mushroom growth masking the older cabins.
10038-8{_}10325{_}The water-front swarms with craft, scows and canoes, birch, canvas, peterboro; the great bateaux of the northern lumberman, neat little skiffs, clumsy rafts; heavy "double-enders," whip-sawed from green timber, with capacity of two to five tons; lighters and barges carrying as much as forty tons--all having come through the perils of the upper lakes and shot the canon rapids.
10038-8{_}10326{_}As the Oklahoma steams nearer, the town blossoms into flags; a great murmur increases to a clamour; people come swarming down to the water-front, waving Union Jacks and Stars and Stripes as well----What does it all mean?
10038-8{_}10327{_}A cannon booms, guns are fired, and as the Oklahoma swings into the bank a band begins to play; a cheer goes up from fifteen thousand throats: "Hurrah for the first steamer!"
10038-8{_}10328{_}The Oklahoma has opened the Klondyke season of 1898!
10038-8{_}10329{_}They got their effects off the boat, and pitched the old tent up on the Moosehide; then followed days full to overflowing, breathless, fevered, yet without result beyond a general stringing up of nerves.
10038-8{_}10330{_}The special spell of Dawson was upon them all--the surface aliveness, the inner deadness, the sense of being cut off from all the rest of the world, as isolated as a man is in a dream, with no past, no future, only a fantastic, intensely vivid Now.
10038-8{_}10331{_}This was the summer climate of the Klondyke.
10038-8{_}10332{_}The Colonel, the Boy, and Captain Rainey maintained the illusion of prosecuting their affairs by frequenting the offices, stores, and particularly saloons, where buyers and sellers most did congregate.
10038-8{_}10333{_}Frequent mention was made of a certain valuable piece of property.
10038-8{_}10334{_}Where was it?
10038-8{_}10335{_}"Down yonder at Min√≥ok;" and then nobody cared a straw.
10038-8{_}10336{_}It was true there was widespread dissatisfaction with the Klondyke.
10038-8{_}10337{_}Everyone agreed it had been overdone.
10038-8{_}10338{_}It would support one-quarter of the people already here, and tens of thousands on their way!
10038-8{_}10339{_}"Say Klondyke, and instantly your soberest man goes mad; say anything else, and he goes deaf."
10038-8{_}10340{_}Min√≥ok was a good camp, but it had the disadvantage of lying outside the magic district.
10038-8{_}10341{_}The madness would, of course, not last, but meanwhile the time went by, and the people poured in day and night.
10038-8{_}10342{_}Six great steamers full came up from the Lower River, and still the small craft kept on flocking like coveys of sea-fowl through the Upper Lakes, each party saying, "The crowd is behind."
10038-8{_}10343{_}On the 14th of June a toy whistle sounded shrill above the town, and in puffed a Liliputian "steel-hull" steamer that had actually come "on her own" through the canon and shot the White Horse Rapids.
10038-8{_}10344{_}A steamer from the Upper River!
10038-8{_}10345{_}after that, others.
10038-8{_}10346{_}Two were wrecked, but who minded?
10038-8{_}10347{_}And still the people pouring in, and still that cry, "The crowd's behind!"
10038-8{_}10348{_}and still the clamour for quicker, ampler means of transport to the North, no matter what it cost.
10038-8{_}10349{_}The one consideration "to get there," and to get there "quickly," brought most of the horde by the Canadian route; yet, as against the two ocean steamers--all-sufficient the year before to meet the five river boats at St. Michael's--now, by the All-American route alone, twenty ocean steamers and forty-seven river boats, double-deckers, some two hundred and twenty-five feet long, and every one crowded to the guards with people coming to the Klondyke.
10038-8{_}10350{_}Meanwhile, many of those already there were wondering why they came and how they could get home.
10038-8{_}10351{_}In the tons of "mail matter" for Dawson, stranded at Skaguay, must be those "instructions" from the Colonel's bank, at home, to the Canadian Bank of Commerce, Dawson City.
10038-8{_}10352{_}He agreed with the Boy that if--very soon now--they had not disposed of the Min√≥ok property, they would go to the mines.
10038-8{_}10353{_}"What's the good?"
10038-8{_}10354{_}rasped Mac.
10038-8{_}10355{_}"Every foot staked for seventy miles."
10038-8{_}10356{_}"For my part," admitted the Boy, "I'm less grand than I was.
10038-8{_}10357{_}I meant to make some poor devil dig out my Min√≥ok gold for me.
10038-8{_}10358{_}It'll be the other way about: I'll dig gold for any man on Bonanza that'll pay me wages."
10038-8{_}10359{_}They sat slapping at the mosquitoes till a whistle screamed on the Lower River.
10038-8{_}10360{_}The Boy called to Nig, and went down to the town to hear the news.
10038-8{_}10361{_}By-and-by Mac came out with a pack, and said he'd be back in a day or two.
10038-8{_}10362{_}After he had disappeared among the tents--a conquering army that had forced its way far up the hill by now--the Colonel got up and went to the spring for a drink.
10038-8{_}10363{_}He stood there a long time looking out wistfully, not towards the common magnet across the Klondyke, but quite in the other direction towards the nearer gate of exit--towards home.
10038-8{_}10364{_}"What special brand of fool am I to be here?"

10038-8{_}10644{_}"If you're in any doubt, come and see," he said.
10038-8{_}10645{_}They stood together, leaning over the sluice, looking in at one of the things human industry has failed to disfigure, nearly as beautiful to-day as long ago on Pactolus' banks when Lydian shepherds, with great stones, fastened fleeces in the river that they might catch and gather for King Croesus the golden sands of Tmolus.
10038-8{_}10646{_}Improving, not in beauty, but economy, quite in the modern spirit, the Greeks themselves discovered that they lost less gold if they led the stream through fleece-lined water-troughs--and beyond this device of those early placer-miners we have not progressed so far but that, in every long, narrow sluice-box in the world to-day, you may see a Lydian water-trough with a riffle in the bottom for a golden fleece.
10038-8{_}10647{_}The rich Klondyker and the poor one stood together looking in at the water, still low, still slipping softly over polished pebbles, catching at the sunlight, winking, dimpling, glorifying flint and jasper, agate and obsidian, dazzling the uncommercial eye to blind forgetfulness of the magic substance underneath.
10038-8{_}10648{_}Austin gathered up, one by one, a handful of the shining stones, and tossed them out.
10038-8{_}10649{_}Then, bending down, "See?"
10038-8{_}10650{_}There, under where the stones had been, neatly caught in the lattice of the riffle, lying thick and packed by the water action, a heavy ridge of black and yellow--magnetic sand and gold.
10038-8{_}10651{_}"Riffles out!"
10038-8{_}10652{_}called Seymour, and the men, who had been extracting the rusty nails that held them firm, lifted out from the bottom of each box a wooden lattice, soused it gently in the water, and laid it on the bank.
10038-8{_}10653{_}The Boy had turned away again, but stood an instant noticing how the sun caught at the countless particles of gold still clinging to the wood; for this was one of the old riffles, frayed by the action of much water and the fret of many stones.

10038-8{_}10655{_}Meanwhile, Seymour had called to the gateman for more water, and himself joining the gang, armed now with flat metal scoops, they all began to turn over and throw back against the stream the debris in the bottom of the boxes, giving the water another chance to wash out the lighter stuff and clean the gold from all impurity.
10038-8{_}10656{_}Away went the last of the sand, and away went the pebbles, dark or bright, away went much of the heavy magnetic iron.
10038-8{_}10657{_}Scowl Austin, at the end of the line, had a corn-whisk with which he swept the floor of the box, always upstream, gathering the contents in a heap, now on this side, now on that, letting the water play and sort and carry away, condensing, hastening the process that for ages had been concentrating gold in the Arctic placers.

10038-8{_}11145{_}CHAPTER XXII  THE GOING HOME    "Despair lies down and grovels, grapples not   With evil, casts the burden of its lot.

10038-8{_}11150{_}--George Meredith   Everybody on Bonanza knew that the Colonel had left off struggling to get out of his bed to go to work, had left off calling for his pardner.
10038-8{_}11151{_}Quite in his right senses again, he could take in Maudie's explanation that the Boy was gone to Dawson, probably to get something for the Colonel to eat.
10038-8{_}11152{_}For the Doctor was a crank and wouldn't let the sick man have his beans and bacon, forbade him even such a delicacy as fresh pork, though the Buckeyes nobly offered to slaughter one of their newly-acquired pigs, the first that ever rooted in Bonanza refuse, and more a terror to the passing Indian than any bear or wolf.
10038-8{_}11153{_}"But the Boy's a long time," the Colonel would say wistfully.
10038-8{_}11154{_}Before this quieter phase set in, Maudie had sent into Dawson for Potts, O'Flynn and Mac, that they might distract the Colonel's mind from the pardner she knew could not return.
10038-8{_}11155{_}But O'Flynn, having married the girl at the Moosehorn Caf√©, had excuse of ancient validity for not coming; Potts was busy breaking the faro bank, and Mac was waiting till an overdue Lower River steamer should arrive.
10038-8{_}11156{_}Nicholas of Pymeut had gone back as pilot of the Weare, but Princess Muckluck was still about, now with Skookum Bill, son of the local chief, now alone, trudging up and down Bonanza like one looking for something lost.

10038-8{_}11408{_}And if you leave your home too long, your home leaves you."
10038-8{_}11409{_}"Home doesn't seem so important as it did when I came up here."
10038-8{_}11410{_}The Colonel fastened one hand feverishly on his pardner's arm.
10038-8{_}11411{_}"I've been afraid of that.
10038-8{_}11412{_}It's magic; break away.
10038-8{_}11413{_}Promise me you'll go back and stay.
10038-8{_}11414{_}Lord, Lord!"
10038-8{_}11415{_}he laughed feebly, "to think a fella should have to be urged to leave the North alone.
10038-8{_}11416{_}Wonderful place, but there's Black Magic in it.
10038-8{_}11417{_}Or who'd ever come--who'd ever stay?"
10038-8{_}11418{_}He looked anxiously into the Boy's set face.
10038-8{_}11419{_}"I'm not saying the time was wasted," he went on; "I reckon it was a good thing you came."
10038-8{_}11420{_}"Yes, it was a good thing I came."
10038-8{_}11421{_}"You've learned a thing or two."
10038-8{_}11422{_}"Several."
10038-8{_}11423{_}"Specially on the Long Trail."
10038-8{_}11424{_}"Most of all on the Long Trail."
10038-8{_}11425{_}The Colonel shut his eyes.
10038-8{_}11426{_}Maudie came and held a cup to his lips.
10038-8{_}11427{_}"Thank you.
10038-8{_}11428{_}I begin to feel a little foggy.
10038-8{_}11429{_}What was it we learned on the Trail, pardner?"
10038-8{_}11430{_}But the Boy had turned away.
10038-8{_}11431{_}"Wasn't it--didn't we learn how near a tolerable decent man is to bein' a villain?"
10038-8{_}11432{_}"We learned that a man can't be quite a brute as long as he sticks to another man."
10038-8{_}11433{_}"Oh, was that it?"
10038-8{_}11434{_}*       *       *       *       *  In the night Maudie went away to sleep.
10038-8{_}11435{_}The Boy watched.
10038-8{_}11436{_}"Do you know what I'm thinking about?"
10038-8{_}11437{_}the sick man said suddenly.
10038-8{_}11438{_}"About--that lady down at home?"
10038-8{_}11439{_}"Guess again."
10038-8{_}11440{_}"About--those fellas at Holy Cross?"
10038-8{_}11441{_}"No, I never was as taken up with the Jesuits as you were.
10038-8{_}11442{_}No, Sah, I'm thinkin' about the Czar."
10038-8{_}11443{_}(Poor old Colonel!
10038-8{_}11444{_}he was wandering again.)
10038-8{_}11445{_}"Did I ever tell you I saw him once?"
10038-8{_}11446{_}"No."
10038-8{_}11447{_}"Did--had a good look at him.
10038-8{_}11448{_}Knew a fella in Petersburg, too, that--" He rested a moment.
10038-8{_}11449{_}"That Czar's all right.
10038-8{_}11450{_}Only he sends the wrong people to Siberia.
10038-8{_}11451{_}Ought to go himself, and take his Ministers, for a winter on the Trail."
10038-8{_}11452{_}On his face suddenly the old half-smiling, half-shrewd look.
10038-8{_}11453{_}"But, Lord bless you!
10038-8{_}11454{_}'tisn't only the Czar.
10038-8{_}11455{_}We all have times o' thinkin' we're some punkins.
10038-8{_}11456{_}Specially Kentuckians.
10038-8{_}11457{_}I reckon most men have their days when they're twelve feet high, and wouldn't stoop to say 'Thank ye' to a King.
10038-8{_}11458{_}Let 'em go on the Winter Trail."
10038-8{_}11459{_}"Yes," agreed the Boy, "they'd find out--" And he stopped.
10038-8{_}11460{_}"Plenty o' use for Head Men, though."
10038-8{_}11461{_}The faint voice rang with an echo of the old authority.
10038-8{_}11462{_}"No foolishness, but just plain: 'I'm the one that's doin' the leadin'--like Nig here--and it's my business to lick the hind dog if he shirks.'"
10038-8{_}11463{_}He held out his hand and closed it over his friend's.
10038-8{_}11464{_}"I was Boss o' the Big Chimney, Boy, but you were Boss o' the Trail."
10038-8{_}11465{_}*       *       *       *       *  The Colonel was buried in the old moose pasture, with people standing by who knew that the world had worn a friendlier face because he had been in it.
10038-8{_}11466{_}That much was clear, even before it was found that he had left to each of the Big Chimney men five hundred dollars, not to be drawn except for the purpose of going home.
10038-8{_}11467{_}They thought it was the sense of that security that made them put off the day.
10038-8{_}11468{_}They would "play the game up to the last moment, and see--"  September's end brought no great change in fortune, but a change withal of deep significance.
10038-8{_}11469{_}The ice had begun to run in the Yukon.
10038-8{_}11470{_}No man needed telling it would "be a tuhble wintah, and dey'd better move down Souf."
10038-8{_}11471{_}All the late boats by both routes had been packed.
10038-8{_}11472{_}Those men who had failed, and yet, most tenacious, were hanging on for some last lucky turn of the wheel, knew the risk they ran.
10038-8{_}11473{_}And now to-day the final boat of the year was going down the long way to the Behring Sea, and by the Canadian route, open a little longer, the Big Chimney men, by grace of that one left behind, would be on the last ship to shoot the rapids in '98.
10038-8{_}11474{_}Not only to the thousands who were going, to those who stayed behind there was something in the leaving of the last boat--something that knocked upon the heart.
10038-8{_}11475{_}They, too, could still go home.
10038-8{_}11476{_}They gathered at the docks and told one another they wouldn't leave Dawson for fifty thousand dollars, then looked at the "failures" with home-sick eyes, remembering those months before the luckiest Klondyker could hear from the world outside.
10038-8{_}11477{_}Between now and then, what would have come to pass up here, and what down there below!
10038-8{_}11478{_}The Boy had got a place for Muckluck in the A. C. Store.
10038-8{_}11479{_}She was handy at repairing and working in fur, and said she was "all right" on this bright autumn morning when the Boy went in to say good-bye.
10038-8{_}11480{_}With a white woman and an Indian boy, in a little room overlooking the water-front, Muckluck was working in the intervals of watching the crowds on the wharf.
10038-8{_}11481{_}Eyes more experienced than hers might well stare.
10038-8{_}11482{_}Probably in no other place upon the globe was gathered as motley a crew: English, Indian, Scandinavian, French, German, Negroes, Chinese, Poles, Japs, Finns.
10038-8{_}11483{_}All the fine gentlemen had escaped by earlier boats.
10038-8{_}11484{_}All the smart young women with their gold-nugget buttons as big as your thumb, lucky miners from the creeks with heavy consignments of dust to take home, had been too wary to run any risk of the Never-Know-What closing inopportunely.
10038-8{_}11485{_}The great majority here, on the wharf, dazed or excited, lugging miscellaneous possessions--things they had clung to in straits so desperate they knew no more how to relax their hold than dead fingers do--these were men whose last chance had been the Klondyke, and who here, as elsewhere, had failed.
10038-8{_}11486{_}Many who came in young were going out old; but the odd thing was that those worst off went out game--no whining, none of the ostentatious pathos of those broken on the wheel of a great city.
10038-8{_}11487{_}A man under Muckluck's window, dressed in a moose-skin shirt, straw hat, broadcloth trousers, and carpet slippers, in one hand a tin pail, in the other something tied in a handkerchief, called out lustily to a ragged individual, cleaving a way through the throng, "Got your stuff aboard?"
10038-8{_}11488{_}"Yes, goin' to get it off.
10038-8{_}11489{_}I ain't goin' home till next year."
10038-8{_}11490{_}And the face above the moose-skin shirt was stricken with a sudden envy.
10038-8{_}11491{_}Without any telling, he knew just how his pardner's heart had failed him, when it came to turning his tattered back on the possibilities of the Klondyke.
10038-8{_}11492{_}"Oh, I'm comin' back soon's I get a grub-stake."
10038-8{_}11493{_}"I ain't," said another with a dazed expression--a Klondyker carrying home his frying-pan, the one thing, apparently, saved out of the wreck.
10038-8{_}11494{_}"You think you ain't comin' back?
10038-8{_}11495{_}Just wait!
10038-8{_}11496{_}Once you've lived up here, the Outside ain't good enough fur yer."
10038-8{_}11497{_}"Right!"
10038-8{_}11498{_}said an old Forty-miler, "you can try it; but Lord!
10038-8{_}11499{_}how you'll miss this goll-darn Yukon."
10038-8{_}11500{_}Among the hundreds running about, talking, bustling, hauling heterogeneous luggage, sending last letters, doing last deals, a score of women either going by this boat or saying good-bye to those who were; and Potts, the O'Flynns, and Mac waiting to hand over Kaviak to Sister Winifred.
10038-8{_}11501{_}The Boy at the open window above, staring down on the tatterdemalion throng, remembered his first meeting with the Big Chimney men as the Washington City steamed out of San Francisco's Golden Gate a year and a month before.
10038-8{_}11502{_}Of course, even in default of finding millions, something stirring might have happened, something heroic, rewarding to the spirit, if no other how; but (his own special revelation blurred, swamped for the moment in the common wreck) he said to himself that nothing of the sort had befallen the Big Chimney men any more than to the whipped and bankrupt crew struggling down there on the wharf.
10038-8{_}11503{_}They simply had failed--all alike.
10038-8{_}11504{_}And yet there was between them and the common failures of the world one abiding difference: these had greatly dared.
10038-8{_}11505{_}As long as the meanest in that crowd drew breath and held to memory, so long might he remember the brave and terrible days of the Klondyke Rush, and that he had borne in it his heavy share.
10038-8{_}11506{_}No share in any mine save that--the knowledge that he was not among the vast majority who sit dully to the end beside what things they were born to--the earnings of other men, the savings of other women, afraid to go seeking after better lest they lose the good they have.
10038-8{_}11507{_}They had failed, but it could never be said of a Klondyker that he had not tried.
10038-8{_}11508{_}He might, in truth, look down upon the smug majority that smiles at unusual endeavour, unless success excuses, crowns it.
10038-8{_}11509{_}No one there, after all, so poor but he had one possession treasured among kings.
10038-8{_}11510{_}And he had risked it.
10038-8{_}11511{_}What could a man do more?
10038-8{_}11512{_}"Good-bye, Muckluck."
10038-8{_}11513{_}"Goo'-bye?
10038-8{_}11514{_}Boat Canada way no go till Thursday."
10038-8{_}11515{_}"Thursday, yes," he said absently, eyes still on the American ship.
10038-8{_}11516{_}"Then why you say goo'-bye to-day?"
10038-8{_}11517{_}"Lot to do.
10038-8{_}11518{_}I just wanted to make sure you were all right."
10038-8{_}11519{_}Her creamy face was suddenly alight, but not with gratitude.
10038-8{_}11520{_}"Oh, yes, all right here," she said haughtily.
10038-8{_}11521{_}"I not like much the Boston men--King George men best."
10038-8{_}11522{_}It was so her sore heart abjured her country.
10038-8{_}11523{_}For among the natives of the Klondyke white history stops where it began when George the Third was King.
10038-8{_}11524{_}"I think"--she shot sideways a shrewd look--"I think I marry a King George man."
10038-8{_}11525{_}And at the prospect her head drooped heavily.
10038-8{_}11526{_}"Then you'll want to wear this at your wedding."
10038-8{_}11527{_}The Boy drew his hand out of his pocket, threw a walrus-string over her bent head, and when she could see clear again, her Katharine medal was swinging below her waist, and "the Boston man" was gone.
10038-8{_}11528{_}She stared with blinded eyes out of the window, till suddenly in the mist one face was clear.
10038-8{_}11529{_}The Boy!
10038-8{_}11530{_}Standing still down there in the hurly-burly, hands in pockets, staring at the ship.
10038-8{_}11531{_}Suddenly Sister Winifred, her black veil swirling in the wind.
10038-8{_}11532{_}An orderly from St. Mary's Hospital following with a little trunk.
10038-8{_}11533{_}At the gangway she is stopped by the purser, asked some questions, smiles at first and shakes her head, and then in dismay clasps her hands, seeming to plead, while the whistle shrieks.
10038-8{_}11534{_}Muckluck turned and flew down the dark little stair, threaded her way in and out among the bystanders on the wharf till she reached the Sister's side.
10038-8{_}11535{_}The nun was saying that she not only had no money, but that a Yukon purser must surely know the Sisters were forbidden to carry it.
10038-8{_}11536{_}He could not doubt but the passage money would be made good when they got to Holy Cross.
10038-8{_}11537{_}But the purser was a new man, and when Mac and others who knew the Yukon custom expostulated, he hustled them aside and told Sister Winifred to stand back, the gangway was going up.
10038-8{_}11538{_}It was then the Boy came and spoke to the man, finally drew out some money and paid the fare.
10038-8{_}11539{_}The nun, not recognising him, too bewildered by this rough passage with the world even to thank the stranger, stood motionless, grasping Kaviak's hand--two children, you would say--her long veil blowing, hurrying on before her to that haven in the waste, the mission at Holy Cross.
10038-8{_}11540{_}Again the Boy was delaying the upward swing of the gangway: the nun's trunk must come on board.
10038-8{_}11541{_}Two men rushed for it while he held down the gang.
10038-8{_}11542{_}"Mustn't cry," he said to Muckluck.
10038-8{_}11543{_}"You'll see Sister Winifred again."
10038-8{_}11544{_}"Not for that I cry.
10038-8{_}11545{_}Ah, I never shall have happiness!"
10038-8{_}11546{_}"Yes, that trunk!"
10038-8{_}11547{_}he called.
10038-8{_}11548{_}In the babel of voices shouting from ship and shore, the Boy heard Princess Muckluck saying, with catches in her breath:  "I always knew I would get no luck!"
10038-8{_}11549{_}"Why?"
10038-8{_}11550{_}"Ah!
10038-8{_}11551{_}I was a bad child.
10038-8{_}11552{_}The baddest of all the Pymeut children."
10038-8{_}11553{_}"Yes, yes, they've got it now!"
10038-8{_}11554{_}the Boy shouted up to the Captain.
10038-8{_}11555{_}Then low, and smiling absently: "What did you do that was so bad.
10038-8{_}11556{_}Princess?"
10038-8{_}11557{_}"Me?
10038-8{_}11558{_}I--I mocked at the geese.
10038-8{_}11559{_}It was the summer they were so late; and as they flew past Pymeut I--yes, I mocked at them."
10038-8{_}11560{_}A swaying and breaking of the crowd, the little trunk flung on board, the men rushing back to the wharf, the gang lifted, and the last Lower River boat swung out into the ice-flecked stream.
10038-8{_}11561{_}Keen to piercing a cry rang out--Muckluck's:  "Stop!
10038-8{_}11562{_}They carry him off!
10038-8{_}11563{_}It is meestake!
10038-8{_}11564{_}Oh!
10038-8{_}11565{_}Oh!"
10038-8{_}11566{_}The Boy was standing for'ard, Nig beside him.
10038-8{_}11567{_}O'Flynn rushed to the wharf's edge and screamed at the Captain to "Stop, be the Siven!"
10038-8{_}11568{_}Mac issued orders most peremptory.
10038-8{_}11569{_}Muckluck wept as excitedly as though there had never been question of the Boy's going away.
10038-8{_}11570{_}But while the noise rose and fell, Potts drawled a "Guess he means to go that way!"
10038-8{_}11571{_}"No, he don't!"
10038-8{_}11572{_}"Stop, you--------, Captain!"
10038-8{_}11573{_}"Stop your----boat!"
10038-8{_}11574{_}"Well," said a bystander, "I never seen any feller as calm as that who was bein' took the way he didn't want to go."
10038-8{_}11575{_}"D'ye mean there's a new strike?"
10038-8{_}11576{_}The suggestion flashed electric through the crowd.
10038-8{_}11577{_}It was the only possible explanation.
10038-8{_}11578{_}"He knows what he's about."
10038-8{_}11579{_}"Lord!
10038-8{_}11580{_}I wish I'd 'a' froze to him!"
10038-8{_}11581{_}"Yep," said Buck One, "never seen that young feller when he looked more like he wouldn't give a whoop in hell to change places with anybody."
10038-8{_}11582{_}As O'Flynn, back from his chase, hoarse and puffing, stopped suddenly:  "Be the Siven!
10038-8{_}11583{_}Father Brachet said the little divil 'd be coming back to Howly Cross!"
10038-8{_}11584{_}"Where's that?"
10038-8{_}11585{_}"Lower River camp."
10038-8{_}11586{_}"Gold there?"
10038-8{_}11587{_}"No."
10038-8{_}11588{_}"Then you're talking through your hat!"
10038-8{_}11589{_}"Say, Potts, where in hell is he goin'?"
10038-8{_}11590{_}"Damfino!"
